column2: LEAD: Margarine, the spread millions use instead of butter in hopes of preventing heart disease, contains fatty acids formed during processing that actually increase coronary risk, according to a study published yesterday.

LEAD: Genentech Inc. and Abbott Laboratories reached an out-of-court agreement today to drop their respective claims about Abbott's patents on plasminogen activator.

LEAD: Michael Cooper, the graceful defensive specialist who was a key performer on five National Basketball Association championship teams in the 1980's, parted company with the Los Angeles Lakers yesterday to seek a new basketball career in Italy.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump's accountants and bankers have concluded that his empire is worth far less than he contended late last year - and that if he had been forced to sell his assets this spring he might not have realized enough money to get out of debt.

LEAD: The promise of free travel across the tightly sealed border between North and South Korea faded today as about 10,000 South Korean radicals clashed with riot policemen and the authorities continued to haggle over procedural details.

LEAD: Automotive output dropped sharply in July, leaving overall industrial production unchanged from June, the Federal Reserve reported today. It noted that the economy continued its slow growth in most other areas of manufacturing.

LEAD: CALL it romantic, bucolic, rustic, nostalgic, but don't call it Harbor Country. ''I despise that name,'' said Ken Schroeder, an architect, echoing many Chicago cognoscenti who drive an hour and a half - 70 miles from the Loop - to second homes along the woodsy stretch of Lake Michigan shoreline that the regional Chamber of Commerce insisted on christening Harbor

LEAD: Two former state prosecutors pleaded guilty to cocaine charges in Federal court today. One of them, Michael Trant, a former associate deputy attorney general, pleaded guilty to one count of cocaine possession, and the other, Richard Guida, who headed the state attorney general's criminal division until 1986, admitted one count of cocaine distribution.

LEAD: In the clearest signal yet of the importance the Federal Reserve Board places on banks maintaining high levels of capital, the nation's central bank today rejected a proposal by the Bank of New York to acquire a $2.7 billion Connecticut bank-holding company, citing concerns that the resulting institution would not have sufficient capital reserves.
LEAD: William F. Farley, chairman of Fruit of the Loom Inc., sold 3.75 million Fruit of the Loom class B common shares to a single buyer for $11.50 a share, or more than $43.1 million.

LEAD: State Attorney General Robert Abrams and his wife, Diane Schulder Abrams, earned $206,034 in 1989 and paid more than $50,000 in taxes, according to tax returns made public today. The couple paid $36,002 in Federal income taxes, $10,719 in New York State taxes and $4,693 in New York City taxes. The couple earned more than $80,000 in partnerships and interest, $112,457 from his job and $14,904 from Mrs.
LEAD: Thousands of East German farmers shook their fists at their first freely elected Government today, protesting against increasingly desperate economic conditions.

LEAD: Formal Dinner may be only the second- or third-best 2-year-old in D. Wayne Lukas's stable, but that was good enough to make him an easy winner over a very weak field today in the $92,100 Sanford Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

LEAD: Ines Mendoza de Munoz, the widow of Luis Munoz Marin, the longtime Governor of Puerto Rico, died Monday at a hospital in Rio Piedras, a suburb of San Juan. She was 82 years old and lived in San Juan.
LEAD: If it lasts, the peace settlement shaping up today between Iraq and Iran, once its arch-enemy, could significantly prolong the stay of American troops in the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: There have been two Summer National Championships in the last month: Shortly after the American Contract Bridge League concluded its 10 days of play in Boston last month, the smaller American Bridge Association began 11 days of competition in Philadelphia, which ended on Saturday.

LEAD: Because of continuing data-transmission difficulties as a result of the Monday fire at a Consolidated Edison plant in lower Manhattan, The Associated Press was unable to provide data on trading yesterday in several futures and options contracts. They are identified in the tables today on page D17.

LEAD: Increased sales of video game products and non-electronic toys raised the earnings of Toys ''R'' Us by 12.8 percent in the second quarter compared with the corresponding period in 1989, company officials said today. Net earnings for the quarter ended July 29 were $26.5 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with $23.5 million, or 8 cents a share, for the second quarter of last year.

LEAD: By failing to end this week's correction officers' job action before it mushroomed into a major disturbance at Rikers Island, Mayor David N. Dinkins has fueled further criticism of his cautious, deliberate style.

LEAD: Since the onset of the Persian Gulf crisis two weeks ago, most prominent Arab-Americans have joined the chorus of denunciation against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq for his invasion and annexation of Kuwait. Yet at the end of the chorus, Arab-American voices add one word: but.

LEAD: TWO nights after it happened, I saw a nicely dressed young couple laying roses at the foot of the telephone booth. There are many such shrines to the suddenly-departed all over New York - a name scrawled on a wall, a heap of flowers, a candle or two - but this was the first that I had seen. The small mound of pink and red blooms was curiously reminiscent of the plaques on Paris buildings that commemorate someone lost to gunfire during the Liberation.

LEAD: * Bank of America, San Francisco, a subsidiary of BankAmerica Corp., appointed Ed Hall senior vice president and head of marketing for its consumer banking group. Sheryl L. Bartolucci, the director of human resources of its world banking group, was appointed senior vice president. Erich Goodbody, director of the Orange County-San Diego region of its real estate industries division, was named executive vice president.

LEAD: More than 20,000 General Motors Corporation workers are returning to their jobs after a six-day strike at a parts plant in Flint, Mich., that idled 16 other plants across the country. LEAD: When the Yankee partners at a meeting yesterday in Cleveland named Robert Nederlander as the general partner of the team to replace George Steinbrenner, the first question was, ''Who?''

LEAD: Consumers will see some relief from record meat prices as production increases next year, the Agriculture Department said today. Retail pork prices are expected to decline about 1 percent to 3 percent in 1991 from this year's record level, the department's Economic Research Service said. Poultry prices may be down 4 percent to 6 percent.
LEAD: A chart in Sports Pages yesterday listing the leading home run hitters among rookies this season misidentified Greg Vaughn's team. It is the Milwaukee Brewers.

LEAD: Thomas J. McDermott, an independent television producer who created many popular shows, including ''Father Knows Best'' and the daytime serials ''As the World Turns'' and ''The Edge of Night,'' died on Saturday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: A 19-year-old man who shot a knife-wielding burglar attacking a pregnant woman in an East Harlem apartment has been indicted on charges of second-degree murder and illegal gun possession, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said last night.

LEAD: The eating disorders anorexia and bulimia are well known as afflictions of adolescent girls and women. But experts now say many more boys and men suffer from these problems than doctors or the public realize.
LEAD: The solution to Mark Langston's problems? Simple. Give him the Yankees.
LEAD: Herbert Yalof, the 53-year old president and chief operating officer of R. H. Macy & Company's Northeast division, is giving up those posts and taking early retirement.
LEAD: Florence Rubin Garfunkel, a social worker and a trustee of the Educational Alliance for 33 years, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83 years old.

LEAD: As Iraq mends its political fences with Iran, Baghdad expects to free some of its large forces along the Iranian border for possible redeployment to the southern part of the country where they would confront United States forces. But analysts do not believe major Iraqi troop or tank movements are imminent.

LEAD: Geoffrey Leon, an actor and lyricist, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 44 years old. He died of complications of AIDS, said a friend, Robert Poterelli. Mr. Leon graduated from the University of California at Santa Barbara in 1967 and moved to New York the same year. He appeared on Broadway in ''Georgy'' and was a founder of a vocal group, Twentieth Century.

LEAD: Zeke Mowatt, the former Giant tight end who was signed in the off season as a Plan B free agent by the New England Patriots, is scheduled to have surgery on a ruptured tendon in his left little finger and may be lost for eight weeks. The 6-foot-3-inch, 240-pound lineman injured his finger during practice on Monday.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Iraq appealed for peace with Iran, accepting virtually all of Teheran's conditions to settle the issues remaining from their eight-year war. The move underscores Baghdad's growing sense of isolation. Page A1

LEAD: About 60 radical students hurled firebombs and shouted anti-American slogans in an attack today on a United States Army building near downtown Seoul, the police and officials said.

LEAD: In Spike Lee's ''Do the Right Thing,'' there is a scene he refers to in the published screenplay as ''The Racial Slur Montage.'' One by one, a range of ethnic characters stare into the camera and spit out vicious, stereotypical descriptions of some other ethnic group. The black man played by Mr. Lee says, ''Dago, wop, garlic-breath''; an Italian comes back with, ''Gold-chain-wearing, fried-chicken-and-biscuit-eatin' monkey,'' and a Hispanic man sneers at Koreans as ''slanty-eyed, me-no-speak-American, own every fruit and vegetable stand in New York.
LEAD: Lucinda Wierenga and Walter McDonald, who live on South Padre Island in Texas, make a living building sand castles. They aren't rich yet, they admit, but they say they are having a lot of fun.

LEAD: In the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, some siren voices are inviting Congress to quit cutting the defense budget and restore money for threatened programs like the B-2 bomber and the Osprey transport plane. LEAD: Dorothy Mackaill, an actress who starred in silent and sound films in the 1920's and 30's, died on Sunday in her room at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel in Honolulu. She was 87 years old. She died of liver failure, The Associated Press said. Miss Mackaill lived in Hawaii for the last 35 years. She was born in Hull, England, and came to Broadway as a Ziegfeld girl and soon went to Hollywood.

LEAD: The Republican National Chairman, Lee Atwater, has received additional radiation treatment as an inoperable brain tumor has worsened, party officials said today.
LEAD: One man who is taking seriously the rumors that Thomas Hearns may defect from Emanuel Steward, the only manager and trainer he has had since turning pro in 1977, is Steward himself.

LEAD: The Hearst Corporation yesterday announced the appointment of Terry McDonell, the founder and editor in chief of Smart magazine, to be the new editor of Esquire, the venerable men's magazine that helped establish both the ''new journalism'' of the 1960's and the ''new man'' of the 1980's.

LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

LEAD: Christie's has been asked to sell major collections of Old Master paintings and 18th- and early 19th-century English silver owned by the Philippine Government, to benefit the needs of the Philippine people.

LEAD: In recent years, the Ambassador Grill, a cosmopolitan French restaurant next to the United Nations, has been a favorite haunt of people in the diplomatic community. With its commodious setting, agreeable food and remarkably low prices, it has been an underappreciated find in this otherwise barren gastronomic domain.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, a higher-than-expected gain that came despite a sharp drop in energy prices just before the Middle East crisis. The increase was a sign of inflation's persistent grip on the economy. [Page A1.] Housing starts fell 2.6 percent last month from June, the sixth straight monthly decline, cutting building activity to its weakest pace in nearly eight years, the Government said.

LEAD: Dr. Lawrence A. Frost, a podiatrist and a historian who published several books on Gen. George A. Custer, died on Tuesday at Mercy Memorial Hospital in Monroe, Mich. He was 83 years old and lived in Monroe. His family said he died of cardiac arrest.

LEAD: Gov. Jim Florio, who has thus far resisted pressure to change any part of his $2.8 billion tax program, is prepared to rescind the sales tax on heavy trucks if the Legislature can find other sources for the $44 million in revenue that the tax was expected to produce, administration officials and legislative leaders say.

LEAD: Louis Barron, editor in chief of Barnes & Noble Books, died on Monday at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan while undergoing surgery for renal failure, his family said. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan and Downsville, N.Y.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about New York's efforts to dispose of low-level radioactive waste described two companies incorrectly. LEAD: Empire Federal Savings of America has sold its $900 million portfolio of automobile loans to a General Electric Company subsidiary as part of the Federal Government's restructuring of the seized savings institution. LEAD: Imagine you are seated in a rustic railroad passenger car, near a majestic river. The whistle blows, and you're under way - behind the nostalgic chuffing of steam power. You emerge alongside the shore of a pristine reservoir, surrounded by wooded mountains, and skirt its banks for several miles.

LEAD: Try as it might, Little Feat can't escape the ghost of Lowell George, who died in 1979. With Mr. George as its main songwriter and singer, Little Feat brought wordplay and musical gamesmanship to 1970's Southern rock, skewing country with New Orleans polyrhythm and cutting blues with funk. The reconstituted Little Feat, which has made two albums since 1988, still boasts a rhythm section that can swing, strut, boogie and kick in ordinary or odd meters.

LEAD: A film premiere in East Hampton and a hospital benefit in Southampton had partygoers shuttling between the two Long Island resort towns on Aug. 11. About 1,500 guests arrived at 6 P.M. for the Southampton Hospital cocktail buffet dance under a 39-pole tent.

LEAD: It was the fizzy 50's in Hollywood, the era of Hedda Hopper and Louella Parsons, pouty starlets in strapless evening gowns, and industry kingpins in rumpled suits. Harry Cohn ruled the roost at Columbia Pictures, where Rita Hayworth was the resident love goddess. But all was not quiet in the hallowed executive suites.

LEAD: A review of ''Time of Change: An Insider's View of Russia's Transformation'' on Aug. 12 misidentified the reviewer, Abraham Brumberg. He is the editor of ''Chronicle of a Revolution: A Western-Soviet Inquiry Into Perestroika,'' not its author.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Barry Bonds hit a home run and a double and drove in two runs today, leading Zane Smith and the Pittsburgh Pirates past the Cincinnati Reds, 3-1. It was the fourth straight victory for the Pirates.

LEAD: One day in 1988 I found myself strapped into a kind of canvas sling behind the machine gun in the open side of a helicopter gunship, scooting along above the hot, flat jungle known as the Chapare - the principal coca-growing region of Bolivia. We were looking for clandestine landing strips, clandestine laboratories.

LEAD: Nostalgia and legend surround Les Ballets 1933, the first company that George Balanchine founded in the West. A more tangible and revealing reminder is the trailblazing exhibition that the four-year-old National Museum of Dance in Saratoga Springs is devoting to Balanchine's short-lived ballet troupe of 57 years ago.
LEAD: Given the sharp rise in world oil prices, what are the prospects for mutual funds that invest heavily in oil and other energy companies?
LEAD: Going all the way back to 1823, the Monroe Doctrine has been invoked at the slightest suggestion of outside interference on the American continent.

LEAD: During the blackouts between scenes in Ted Whitehead's play ''The Man Who Fell in Love With His Wife,'' excerpts of golden oldies ranging from Nat (King) Cole to the Beatles to David Bowie are played over the Quaigh Theater's sound system. This hit parade from the past is the best part of an otherwise tedious tale of a Liverpool docker's midlife crisis, which he is handling rather badly.

LEAD: A 20-year-old Bronx woman was killed early yesterday when she tried to break up an argument between her brother and a 16-year-old boy who was brandishing a pistol, the police said.

LEAD: Roderick Cook, the British-born stage and film actor who was perhaps best known for his 1972 Off Broadway revue ''Oh Coward!'' in which he adapted and performed the works of Sir Noel Coward, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles at the age of 58. Dan V. Fuller, his business manager, said Mr. Cook died of what appeared to be a heart attack.

LEAD: Because of the India Day Parade, Lexington Avenue will be closed today between 26th and 47th Streets from 1:30 to 4 P.M.

LEAD: Sailor and Lula, the strangely sympathetic misfits in David Lynch's ''Wild at Heart,'' drive a big old convertible from Cape Fear, N.C., through New Orleans and on to Big Tuna, Tex. They are preoccupied with making love and steering clear of the law, but they always keep an eye on the yellow brick road.

LEAD: The end of the line has come for a couple elements of design. After viewing the Paris fall couture collections, it is clear that skirts cannot get any shorter and clothes cannot get any tighter. Anyone interested in fashion could sense that the time has come for shifts of both ambiance and silhouette.

LEAD: CONTINUING a 28-year practice of serving nontraditional adult students, Sarah Lawrence College is offering a new one-year program this fall to help those who earned bachelor's degrees 10, 20, even 30 years ago to update job skills for today's marketplace.
LEAD: Modern America has turned facades inside out.

Etchero), a family-style restaurant behind the market, where a meal for two with wine is $40.

LEAD: The Yorkshire dales afford so many pleasures, from Wensleydale cheese to medieval abbeys, that artistic connections seem superfluous. They exist, although for most recent travelers they begin and end with James Herriot, the local veterinarian whose books inspired the television series ''All Creatures Great and Small.

LEAD: It's getting so crowded in Long Island wine country that some of the pioneers have already moved on. It's true; Pat and Peter Lenz, who built one of the first showcase wineries on Long Island in 1978, sold out more than a year ago and moved to Calistoga, in the Napa Valley. Now, is that a sign of a maturing wine region or not?

Now comes word that hundreds of priceless drawings and watercolors that were thought to have disappeared forever from Germany during World War II have actually been kept safe in Moscow and will soon go back to the museum whence they came.

LEAD: At least once a season, it seems, a fashion item appears and almost at once asserts itself. This summer that item is a cotton canvas jacket from the designer Isaac Mizrahi that comes in a variety of graphic black-and-white patterns: checks, diamonds, spots, stripes and abstract flowers. Besides the boldness of its racing-pattern prints, what sets this jacket apart is its signature solid-black collar.
LEAD: An article on Aug. 5 about Gov. Jim Florio's response to critics of his tax program misidentified the chairman of the Democratic State Committee. He is Philip Keegan.

LEAD: A set of 16 deals played in the Summer Nationals in Boston three weeks ago made a solid imprint on bridge history. The setting was the last act of the 1990 Spingold Knockout Team Championship. The scenario was a mirror image of many comparable occasions.
LEAD: Catherine Ann Christensen and Paul J. Duffy Jr. were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York by the Rev. Joseph A. Latella.
LEAD: IN late summer and early fall, political signs sprout like ragweed, promoting candidates for every office from town council to Congress. But not in Mansfield.

LEAD: A mosaic of marsh, woods and upland fields, Prime Hook National Wildlife Refuge on the southwest shore of Delaware Bay is a welcome relief from the crush of the Eastern Seaboard. Its 8,800 acres of rich land draw tens of thousands of migratory birds and relatively few people. Flocks of geese and ducks gather in the fall, shorebirds and warblers in the spring.

LEAD: Put yourself, for a moment, inside the mind of Jesse Helms. Imagine a scrubbed, manicured neighborhood, a pocket of decency in the heart of our sinful land. The music is by Wayne Newton, the paintings are by Norman Rockwell, and sex takes place only between married men and women in beds at night.

LEAD: Basketball United States Wins Bronze Medal: The United States used another comeback yesterday to take the bronze medal at the world championships in Buenos Aires, beating Puerto Rico by 107-105 in overtime. Kenny Anderson scored 34 points and made two free throws with one second left to send the game into overtime after Puerto Rico led by 8 points with 1 minute 34 seconds to play in the second half.

LEAD: For visitors, the 130-acre Bayard Cutting Arboretum's informal gardens provide a respite along the Connetquot River here in Suffolk County, about 50 miles east of Manhattan. In addition to its conifer collection, some of which is unique to Long Island, the arboretum offers a network of well-maintained nature trails, an architecturally notable mansion and a carriage house where concerts, meetings and art exhibits are held.

LEAD: Forty student members of a gay rights advocacy organization in Ann Arbor staged their second demonstration of the summer on Thursday to demand the resignation of a university regent they accuse of making anti-gay remarks.

LEAD: Child prodigies should be permitted to develop their talents and share them with the world from the moment those talents become evident. The children should be encouraged, supported, nourished, nurtured. Certainly any child with minimum talents should not be pushed to try to reach a goal that is impossible or unlikely.

LEAD: On the rocky border with Afghanistan, where millions of exiles might be expected to rejoice in the news that Moscow and Washington are nearing agreement on their political future, there is no joy. Among the Afghans, guerrillas and refugees alike, there is tension, mounting hardship and despair.

LEAD: As the best-known producer-director in Bali, Made Bandem (pronounced MAH-day BAHN-dem) is dealing in a world most of his Western counterparts pray for: an abundance of talented dancers and musicians, audiences sophisticated in the lore of the theater and a society that welcomes great performances.

LEAD: Pearl Bailey, the entertainer whose distinctive singing style was enhanced by her mischievous witticisms and warm personality, died on Friday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia after collapsing at a hotel where she had been staying. LEAD: THE Bellport is made for summer. This white, gingerbread Victorian house with cornflower blue shutters has open doorways, swirling ceiling fans and herb, vegetable and cutting gardens. It is a perfect backdrop for the season.

LEAD: Decisions about medical research belong in the realm of cool, unemotional scientific logic. LEAD: A shabby, mice-ridden worker's cottage may seem an unlikely dwelling for a Romantic poet and his family, but such a cottage in the Somerset village of Nether Stowey was, during the final three years of the 18th century, the place where Samuel Taylor Coleridge's imagination took flight. Or, rather, took to sea.

LEAD: In his 90th birthday year, Kurt Weill remains an increasingly emblematic 20th-century composer. Before most anyone else, he abandoned modernist dissonance and abstraction in favor of a style that delicately balanced formal integrity with popular appeal.

LEAD: For This Week: Patch seed the thin established lawn; repair smaller bare areas with sections of sod or seed a new lawn promptly. Last call to dig, divide and replant iris rhizomes. Cut out browned stalks and seed pods of hostas and day lilies. Don't delay making plans for next spring's garden, and mail hardy bulb orders for delivery in early fall.
LEAD: Jewelry and fashion designers are rediscovering anodized aluminum, a metal that lends itself to delicate shaping and subtle coloration in the electrochemical process that gives it its name.

LEAD: It happened. The dollar fell last week to its lowest level against the German mark since that currency was created 42 years ago. There was no celebration. With the United States facing a possible recession, there is little the Federal Reserve can do to counter the fall, which can add to inflationary pressures by raising the cost of imported goods.

LEAD: Corazon Cojuangco Aquino glides into the reception room, smartly dressed in a pastel peach suit. Smiling warmly, she radiates serenity and self-confidence as she chats about her family, her travels, the weather. I have known her for two decades, and she has always appeared to be extraordinarily poised, even under enormous stress - a trait she attributes to her fatalism.

LEAD: Below the small plane the results of the brief Arctic summer could be seen: inlets of clear water covered with broken patches of melting ice that looked like white lace tossed over the bright blue water. The landscape itself was austere and barren, covered with bare stone scoured out of the earth by ancient glaciers.

LEAD: PHOTOGRAPHY was officially born with the daguerreotype in the Paris of 1839, but its birth pangs began as early as 1826. In that year, Joseph Niepce (also in France) made an eight-hour exposure of the view from his house on a plate of pewter. Then there was the Englishman William Fox Talbot, who, in 1835, produced the first image on sensitized paper, calling it a calotype and, later on, a talbotype, but not unveiling it until 18 days after the debut of the daguerreotype.

LEAD: An attack on correction officers Aug. 10 at Trenton State Prison was part of a plan by a group of inmates to kill staff members at the maximum-security institution, state officials said.

LEAD: In the evening of April 2, millions of sports fans tuned in to the telecast of college basketball's championship game with one question in mind: How's Brent feeling? Brent wasn't injured, physically anyway; he wasn't even playing. Brent Musburger was CBS's lead sportscaster for the game and - as nearly everyone had learned from headlines the day before - CBS had dumped him.
LEAD: Three young men were convicted last night of raping and beating a jogger in Central Park but were acquitted on the most serious charge they faced, attempted murder.

LEAD: In the past, computers were linked together by networks made of wire or fiber-optic cables that were placed under the floors and under the ground. Now, engineers at the Photonics Corporation in Campell, Calif., are linking them with light. The new networking system - Photolink (right) - works very much like the remote control unit of a television set.

LEAD: The deadline for submitting applications for deer-management permits in New York State is Sept. 7. These permits allow hunters to take a deer of either sex in addition to the antlered buck to which their big-game licenses entitle them.

LEAD: DR. MATTHEW L. CARTTER, an epidemiologist with the preventable diseases division of the State Department of Health Services, is in charge of surveillance for Lyme disease. He was the editor of an edition of the Connecticut State Medical Society magazine last year devoted to the disease.Lyme disease was originally believed to cause only the characteristic rash and arthritis, but doctors now know that it can cause cardiological and neurological problems.

LEAD: The Countee Cullen Regional Library, the New York Public Library branch with the largest circulating collection on black culture and history, reopened yesterday after a five-year, $2.8 million renovation and expansion.

LEAD: The two ''Other Views'' (Letters to the New Jersey editor, July 15) in response to Pete Dunne's article on gypsy moth spraying raise questions of judgment and fact that call for at least one additional letter.

LEAD: ''You know how your leg goes to sleep sometimes?'' Sarah East says. ''That's what it feels like.'' Sarah, an 11-year-old from Anadarko, Okla., whose congenitally deformed left leg was amputated when she was an infant, is describing the tingling on her thigh provided by a new device aimed at helping amputees ''feel'' their feet.

LEAD: I recently returned to New Jersey after an absence of about 10 years. It won't come as a surprise to anyone that I was met with utter amazement every time I told people where I was going, and that I was doing it by choice. ''But why New Jersey? It is so dirty,'' was the general message.

LEAD: Bill Bryson's delightful article ''A Taste for Scrambled English'' (On Language, July 22) brought a friend's anecdote to mind. Her son and his musical group were flown to Japan to make a commercial for a Japanese fast-food emporium. The name of the place was ''D Cup Soup.'' Translation? A large cup of soup.

LEAD: UTRILLO'S MOTHER, by Sarah Baylis. (Fawcett Columbine, $8.95.) Suzanne Valadon, the mother of the artist Maurice Utrillo, worked as a model for the likes of Degas and Renoir; but she was an artist herself, forgotten, in no small part, because she was female. This imagined autobiography often comes off like ''an antimale polemic,'' Richard Goodman said here last year, but the author, who died in 1987, ''was very good indeed at re-creating the ambiance of life in the rural France of 100 years ago.

LEAD: THE idea of smoking fish and game to preserve them has been around since the discovery of fire. But recently customers at the new West Street Grill in Litchfield, Conn. (203-567-3885) have been intrigued by the subtle, smoky flavor of unexpected foods such as tomatoes, corn and even lentils.

LEAD: With pitch-roofed, chimney-topped, brick buildings that look more like homes than most homes do, a condominium office park is being planned for the Toms River section of Dover Township, N.J. Its 27 buildings will range from a 1,200-square-foot, one-story unit (for $192,000) to a 2,400-square-foot, two-story unit (for $475,000).

LEAD: Take a 26-year-old building that never had any architectural distinction and that was made even more anonymous by its identification for many years with a single, none-too-glamorous tenant, and put it on the Avenue of the Americas, where vacancy rates are among the highest in mid-Manhattan. It would seem to be a recipe for leasing disaster.

LEAD: In declaring that he would use foreigners as a shield against Western attack, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has placed these captives at the forefront of the Persian Gulf crisis in just the manner the Bush Administration hoped to avoid. Mr. Hussein and Mr. Bush are now engaged in a struggle within a struggle, namely over whether the fate of the Americans and other foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq will weaken the international resolve to squeeze Baghdad hard enough to force a withdrawal from Kuwait.

LEAD: Writers filling history textbooks with accounts of blacks in America's slave days often omit stories about the ones who were never slaves. But the University of Maryland and the Historic Annapolis Foundation plan to piece together part of this forgotten history from broken glass, ceramics and other artifacts unearthed in a parking lot here.

LEAD: In his desperation to keep his debt-riddled empire afloat, William Farley is borrowing money on terms that would make a loan shark blush. And the lender seems to be the investment banker who was advising Mr. Farley when he got into the mess.

LEAD: A man who apparently jumped off the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday was saved by quick teamwork between the crew of a Manhattan sightseeing boat, officers on a police rescue launch and ambulance technicians.

LEAD: In his years as Oklahoma's highly successful head football coach, Barry Switzer may have made his share of mistakes, but three he denied ever making were being in a hotel room in Las Vegas, Nev., where cocaine was used, betting on his team's games and manipulating the Sooner drug-testing program.

LEAD: Things are easier to remember when they are named after something familiar, and what could be more familiar than food? It comes in every color, shape and size. And everybody eats. Noticing strange noises coming from the chests of some sick people, Hippocrates described the sound to his students as ''bubbling like boiling vinegar.

LEAD: The low-visibility four-way contest for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Surrogate has turned into a race for money: the candidate with the most is likely to be the strongest contender in the Sept. 11 Democratic primary. (The nomination virtually assures election.) The feverish quest for campaign money tends to reinforce the court's already questionable image - that of an institution that oversees billions of dollars in estates while dispensing millions of dollars in fees to favorite lawyers to serve as guardians in estates and trusts.

LEAD: Leonard Bernstein has long been the most intensely emotional, the most nakedly human of conductors. That means all his concerts are suffused with a power of personality that focuses attention on himself. LEAD: The crimes, conflicts and assorted calamities that populate each evening's local news shows give the same kick as prime-time dramas. The pictures of shaken victims, filled bodybags, grieving relatives, handcuffed suspects, the agitated reporting, the little jolts of excitement and of pathos are plainly aimed at viewers' emotions.

LEAD: IT is an old tradition on Wall Street that even an ill wind can whip up a nice profit for someone.

LEAD: Gerald F. Stevens, a lawyer, former Connecticut legislator and a 1978 Republican candidate for governor of Connecticut, died on Monday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 52 years old and lived in Milford, Conn.

LEAD: CAROLYN SKELLY was robbed of more than $1 million in jewelry over the weekend, the sixth time she has been robbed. Rings, necklaces and a diamond bracelet were stolen from her jewelry box 15 feet from where she slept early Saturday night in her mansion in Newport, R.I.

LEAD: A rare operation has left a man with two functioning human hearts and a clean bill of health, the University of Wisconsin Hospital said today. Surgeons placed a human donor heart in William Rammer, 53 years old, of Kaukauna, on July 21 to supplement his diseased heart, said Dr. Barry Fields, the hospital's chief heart transplant surgeon.

LEAD: In the most ambitious plan yet to give parents a choice of schools for their children, an Oregon proposal would grant tax credits to cover tuition for private school or expenses for educating a child at home.

LEAD: EVERYONE knows that America's rapidly aging baby boomers are burning the candle at both ends, consuming when they should be saving for retirement. Everyone also knows the boomers are depending on the rapid accumulation of cash in the Social Security trust fund to save their bacon.

LEAD: The Oil Jolt

LEAD: Albert E. Whitaker, a retired special agent of the Secret Service who was in charge of the New York district for many years, died on Monday in Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Wantaugh, L.I.

LEAD: Just a day before a 39-year-old convict was to die in the electric chair, the Supreme Court granted a stay of execution today, and hours later the Georgia Board of Pardons and Paroles granted clemency and commuted the man's sentence to life imprisonment.
LEAD: On the first day of the rest of the Yankees' life without George Steinbrenner, Stump Merrill said that things would be different.

LEAD: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said it had extended its $857 million tender offer for Kansas Gas and Electric Company stock until Sept. 14, saying that about 43 percent of Kansas Gas shares had been tendered. According to a survey by Wine and Spirits magazine, a trade publication, they are the wines American diners order most: as Wine and Spirits put it, ''the most popular wines in the most popular restaurants.

LEAD: When the five members of the Federal Trade Commission return from recess after Labor Day, they may have on their minds a subject dear to many at this time of year both inside and outside the Washington Beltway: college football on television.

LEAD: The Jets announced no progress with their three unsigned players yesterday but they did cut a corner in an effort to get down to next Tuesday's 60-man roster limit.

LEAD: Gerard A. Fulham, former chairman of the Pneumo Corporation, a concern with holdings in the aerospace and military industries and food and drug distribution, died Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 70 years old and lived in Oyster Harbors, Mass.
LEAD: Baseball
LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq sent his Foreign Minister here to propose peace talks with the United States today, then delivered another slashing attack on President Bush.
LEAD: Richard Little Purdy, a retired professor of English at Yale University, died on Aug. 7 in a nursing home in Chatham Township, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in New Haven.

LEAD: When the Tijuana River ripples down the hillside from Mexico into the United States, it brings each day millions of gallons of raw sewage, a thick black stream that meanders, bubbling and stinking, past stables and farmland to empty into the ocean off San Diego.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE emphasis is on the olive in many restaurants here these days, with glass bowls of olive oil replacing crocks of butter on tables. Traditional sauces have been displaced by olive-oil vinaigrettes, and house-made olive breads, laced with olive oil and studded with green and black flecks of kneaded-in olives, are the bread of choice.

LEAD: The trim little port here, Jordan's only outlet to the sea and historically an important site for Iraq, was virtually at a standstill today as a result of United Nations sanctions and a United States naval blockade.

LEAD: The European Community's executive body today endorsed a blueprint for forming tighter economic and monetary links that would include an American-style central bank in 1993. It would also lead to creation of a single currency to be used throughout the dozen nations of the trading bloc. The plan was offered to guide the nations at a special conference opening in December to make any needed changes in their founding Treaty of Rome to forge an economic and monetary union.

LEAD: The hundreds of millions of dollars that poured into Hartford in the 1980's changed the skyline and tripled the amount of office space downtown, but the makeover appears now to have only masked a continuing decline in the heart of Connecticut's capital.

LEAD: After years of calm under Gov. Thomas Kean, New Jersey suddenly seethes with revolt. It was prompted by his successor, Jim Florio, with a bold but highly complex package of stiff new taxes. Widespread resistance demonstrates that Mr. Florio has so far failed to convince New Jerseyans that the new taxes are necessary.

LEAD: In the international museum world, there is at this moment no hotter seat than the one occupied by Dr. Wolf-Dieter Dube, who has been director general of the West Berlin Museums since 1983. In a matter not of months but of weeks, he and his colleagues in both West and East Berlin have to agree on a master plan for the unification of the Berlin museums.

LEAD: The following report was filed under the ground rules that govern American correspondents accredited to the Pentagon who are working in Saudi Arabia. The ground rules prohibit the reporting of exact numbers of troops or weapons, their exact locations or the names of enlisted personnel.

LEAD: A cluster of noisy teen-agers clad in Bart Simpson T-shirts, the uniform of the moment, gathered in the convenience store parking lot to show off their modified Mohawk haircuts and just hang out on a hot August night.
LEAD: The Circle K Corporation has begun closing 201 unprofitable stores and will complete the job by the end of the month, Ray Cox, a company spokesman, said.

LEAD: To fill gaps in the United States military buildup in the Persian Gulf region, President Bush on Wednesday is expected to order a mobilization of reserves that will initially place about 40,000 Americans on active duty, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: Trump Surviving at the Top By Donald J. Trump with Charles Leerhsen Illustrated. 236 pages. Random House,$21.95.
LEAD: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt made an emotional appeal today to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw his occupying troops from Kuwait.
LEAD: Mayor W. Wilson Goode says Philadelphia is not bankrupt and can avoid a $206.4 million deficit if the state and City Council work with him to raise taxes and cut spending.
LEAD: An official of the Los Angeles Raiders says they will be staying put this year.

LEAD: A panel of experts told the White House today that smaller, simpler satellites that can monitor the Earth's climate should soon take priority over the huge Earth Observing System, an elaborate $30 billion array of six large satellites the space agency plans to place in orbit starting in 1997 or 1998.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''THE Rhone,'' said Francois Perrin, ''will be the new Bordeaux.''

LEAD: ''Pump Up the Volume'' asks the question: what's a poor younger generation to do when the traditional modes of teen-age rebellion -sex, drugs and radical politics - have already been used up by its elders? A fanciful, romantic solution, proposed by the film's writer and director, Allan Moyle, is that the M
LEAD: In the first field test of a genetically engineered rabies vaccine in the United States, 26 scientists took boats to Parramore Island on Monday and put out 4,000 baited doses of the vaccine.
LEAD: A United Airlines Boeing 737 jetliner with 107 people aboard was unable to lock its right landing gear but skidded to a safe emergency landing at Los Angeles International Airport today.

LEAD: New York City welfare officials continue to place homeless families in unauthorized welfare hotels despite a court order prohibiting their placement in any but three designated welfare hotels, city officials and advocates for the homeless said last night.

LEAD: As New York City's Board of Estimate continued its fade into oblivion early this morning, it approved the creation of a biomedical research center on the site of the Audubon Ballroom in Washington Heights and, early yesterday, a plan by the developer Peter S. Kalikow to demolish part of a tenement complex designated a landmark.
LEAD: Stocks gyrated wildly yesterday in heavy trading amid fears of war in the Middle East, with the New York Stock Exchange intervening three times to keep the price decline from feeding on itself.

LEAD: In the strongest language it has used so far, the top Federal advisory panel on AIDS issued a three-part report today assailing the Government's drug testing programs, the nation's rural health care system and the ''shocking number'' of medical professionals it said were unwilling to treat people infected with the virus.
LEAD: Five West African nations began sending troops to Liberia today amid indications that negotiations for a cease-fire in the eight-month-long civil war were deadlocked, African diplomats said.

LEAD: Moss Hart's love affair with the theater, so movingly chronicled in his memoir, ''Act One,'' did not blind him to the inequities of his profession. In the theater, a private or collaborative act of creativity is subjected to the capriciousness of actors, producers, audiences and, of course, critics.

LEAD: Space agency engineers said today that initial images of the ruptured surface of Venus sent by the Magellan space probe were better than expected and that the craft appeared to be functioning normally again after last week's surprising radio blackout.

LEAD: The Indian Army dispatched tanks and troop reinforcements today to the frontier with Pakistan, where soldiers from the two nations have been exchanging artillery fire for two days, officials and witnesses said.
LEAD: Armenia's parliament debated a declaration of independence today and considered setting up its own army for protection from neighboring Azerbaijan, the Soviet new outlets reported.

LEAD: No, birds don't do it. Neither do bees. Nor educated fleas. Fall in love, that is. According to this week's Science Times section, falling in lust is more like it. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 President Bush will call up reserves, Administration officials said. He is expected to order 40,000 Americans placed on active duty in the first call-up since the Vietnam War. Page A1

LEAD: Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc. announced that it would sell electronic reference products in Japan under a distribution agreement with Seiko Instruments Inc. The publishing company, based in Mount Holly, will export electronic speaking dictionaries intended for students of English as a foreign language.

LEAD: ON a blistering August day the lounge chairs around the swimming pool at the Rainbow Mountain Resort here are overflowing with bare arms and legs. The smell of coconut oil and the sounds of ''I Got You Babe'' fill the air. Everything about this middle-class enclave seems typical of life in a Pocono Mountain resort except for one thing: nearly all the guests are gay.

LEAD: At an ARCO station on a busy corner in suburban Torrance, Calif., drivers are lining up this week to buy regular unleaded gasoline for $1.13 a gallon - 8 cents less than at the Exxon station across the street. Throughout the West, people have been flocking to other ARCO stations to buy gasoline at prices 4 to 12 cents below those of competing stations.

LEAD: For the second time in five days, Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, ambushed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today by making a surprise appearance at one of the Governor's public events.

LEAD: ''How many intelligent people are in the house?'' K. R. S.-One, the rapper who leads Boogie Down Productions, asked a packed house on Monday night at S.O.B.'s. When not enough hands went up. he asked it again. K. R. S.-One, otherwise known as Kris Parker, wants to use rap, as he said onstage, to ''defend the side of the light, the side of truth and justice.

LEAD: An obituary on Sunday about Lee J. Richmond, a poet and teacher at St. John's University, misstated part of his background as an author. He did not write the novel ''High on Gold''; the author was Lee M. Richmond.
LEAD: Federal regulators today approved what once might have seemed unthinkable -guidelines for giving away property the Government has seized from the wreckage of the savings industry.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that Britain would not negotiate over the thousands of Western nationals trapped in Iraq and Kuwait and that she was considering sending more forces to the Persian Gulf.
LEAD: LETTER from our friend, the fearless gourmet:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Despite a widespread belief to the contrary, girls are just as likely as boys to have the reading impairment dyslexia, three studies say.

LEAD: Goran Ivanisevic, the tempestuous 18-year-old Yugoslav who most reminded Boris Becker of a young, ruthless Boris Becker just after defeating him in the first round of the French Open, has decided to exchange his temper for a top-10 ranking.
LEAD: A top Federal health officer today denied a Congressional charge that the Reagan White House had interfered with a study of the chemical Agent Orange's effects on soldiers in Vietnam.
LEAD: Harry Adelberg, founder of the law firm of Adelberg, Rudow, Dorf, Hendler & Sameth in Baltimore, died Sunday at his home in Baltimore. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: OH, the green bean. The sensible, long-suffering legume. Requiring little for itself in terms of glory or kid-glove treatment, Phaseolus vulgaris is the unsung handmaiden of cuisine. The green bean sings to the cook: ''Steam me, boil me, blanch me, do what you want to do; pickle me, stir-fry me. .

LEAD: Venezuela's public foreign debt will be lowered by more than 20 percent under an agreement reached with creditor banks, Venezuelan officials announced today. The deal covers $20.5 billion of the nation's $26 billion of public-sector debt. The country owes about $35 billion in public- and private-sector debt.

LEAD: Rick Dempsey, the Los Angeles Dodger catcher, was suspended for one game by the National League yesterday and was fined an undisclosed amount for fighting. Dempsey and Len Dykstra of the Philadelphia Phillies were ejected in the seventh inning of Monday's game in Los Angeles.(AP)
LEAD: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission unanimously, if somewhat reluctantly, approved a bank loan package yesterday to help rescue Donald J. Trump's real estate and gambling empire.

LEAD: Experts frequently ask themselves this question during the play: ''Why didn't so-and-so do such-and-such?'' The answer can be illuminating, and was on the diagramed deal for Sidney Lazard of New Orleans, who has been one of America's most formidable performers for four decades.
LEAD: Viktor Tsoi, the lead singer and songwriter for Kino, one of the Soviet Union's most popular rock bands, died in a car crash outside Leningrad on Aug. 15. He was 28 years old.

LEAD: * Advertising pages for the magazines monitored by the Publishers Information Bureau were down by 5.8 percent last month, compared with the corresponding period last year. Ad pages for January to July fell by 3.6 percent, compared with the 1989 period. But because of large rate increases, revenues for the first seven months of the year were up by 1.6 percent from the period last year.
LEAD: A Government program offering wild horses for adoption is becoming increasingly costly, with no evidence that Federal rangeland has benefited, a Congressional study has said.

LEAD: IN a recent rerun of ''Thirtysomething,'' Melissa, a main character, suggested that a friend use margarine rather than butter because it was ''less caloric.'' The fact is, margarine and butter have the same number of calories, and a study released since the program was rerun has cast doubt on margarine's role in reducing cholesterol.

LEAD: The All Nippon Airways Company of Japan has ordered 17 more Boeing 747-400's in a deal valued at $3.5 billion, including parts and related equipment, the Boeing Company said on Monday. Delivery of the aircraft, the world's largest passenger jetliners, is scheduled to begin in 1995.
LEAD: New strategies for developing the next generation of vaccines are resurrecting investment in a medical field that has been in the doldrums for years.
LEAD: George Steinbrenner has been kicked out of Yankee Stadium, but he does not seem to know it. The question is: does everybody else?

LEAD: The mounting confrontation between American warships and two loaded Iraqi oil tankers in waters near the Persian Gulf was at least temporarily defused today when Yemen said it would not allow the tankers to unload their cargo in its port of Aden.
LEAD: Senator Alan K. Simpson, an incumbent Republican, and Gov. Mike Sullivan, an incumbent Democrat, handily won their primary races today.

LEAD: Iraq called today for negotiations on ending the Persian Gulf crisis, but did not offer to pull its troops out of Kuwait. The White House quickly responded that no talks were possible until Iraq unconditionally carried out the United Nations demand that it withdraw its forces from Kuwait.
LEAD: For more than a week, a student protest has been growing steadily on the campuses of this and other Indian cities, spilling onto roads and railway tracks, parks and bazaars.

LEAD: Eleven convicts from a Siberian labor camp who hijacked a Soviet jetliner to Pakistan and requested political asylum will go on trial here, Pakistani television said today. But the Soviet press agency Tass reported that the hijackers would be extradited to the Soviet Union. There was no explanation for the differing reports.

LEAD: Elden Campbell, a 6-foot-11-inch former Clemson star who was the Los Angeles Lakers' first-round draft choice in June, spent last week in Europe, practicing with an Italian team and spawning rumors that he would spurn the Lakers and join the Italian League. Yesterday, Campbell cashed in on the rumors.

LEAD: The Japan External Trade Organization has named Tetsuo Matsufuji president of its New York office. Jetro is one of the leading Japanese Government agencies that promote trade relations between Japan and other countries.
LEAD: Nevilles on the Record
LEAD: A man who went into a coma after drinking a Colombian soft drink that had been laced with cocaine died Monday after doctors turned off his life support equipment.

LEAD: The New York debut of the Richard Tee Committee, a jazz ensemble, will open the season at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater, Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street, on Sept. 22. The group features Mr. Tee, a pianist; Steve Gadd, a drummer; Lenny Pickett, a saxophonist; Will Lee, a bassist; John Tropea, a guitarist, and Ralph Ma

LEAD: Trying to end a dispute over the timetable for German unity, the East German Prime Minister, Lothar de Maiziere, said today that a majority of the parties in East Germany's Parliament had agreed on Oct. 14 as the date for formal merger with West Germany.

LEAD: Anxious to demonstrate full support for American moves to isolate Iraq, Western European governments decided today to increase and coordinate their naval activities in the Persian Gulf and to reject Baghdad's demands that they close their embassies in Kuwait.
LEAD: Mitchell R. Cutler, a dealer in rare art books, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: United States officials have been dogged politically by the problems of freeing Americans held hostage abroad since even before George Washington took the oath of office as President.
LEAD: Fields Medals, the most prestigious international awards in mathematics, were bestowed yesterday upon two mathematicians from the United States and one each from Japan and the Soviet Union.
LEAD: Robert W. Trombino, chief of stadium and marina operations for the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, died on Sunday at his home in East Elmhurst, Queens. He was 39 years old.
LEAD: A listing of books by B. F. Skinner on Monday, with his obituary, misstated the date of ''Walden Two'' in some copies. It was published in 1948.

LEAD: At least 50 prison inmates and 30 guards were injured last night in a melee at the Correctional Institution for Men on Rikers Island after prisoners barricaded themselves inside a dormitory and set fires, a prison spokeswoman said.

LEAD: Given the cold, blustery, intermittently rainy evening, Monday's final free summer parks concert by the New York Philharmonic in Central Park turned out to be more ceremonial and technical than musical. But what music there was sounded nice enough, in two senses of the word ''sound.''

LEAD: Steve Huffman, a former lineman for Notre Dame who quit the team during preseason practice in 1987, has charged there was widespread steroid use on the football team and that Coach Lou Holtz ''had to have known'' about it.
LEAD: A Dartmouth College music professor who frequently clashed with a student newspaper has resigned, putting an end to one of the college's most painful public quarrels.

LEAD: Kuwait City was described in a Washington Post article today as quiet, with Iraqi troops advancing toward the border with Saudi Arabia past hundreds of empty houses, ruined royal palaces and smoldering trash fires in vacant lots.
LEAD: The Tokyo stock market plummeted today in reaction to the continued tensions in the Middle East and the tumbling prices on Wall Street.
LEAD: In the dark, dreary terrain of Romania's impoverished economy, Anda Baldau, a secretary turned shopowner, and Petru Rares, a Western-educated economist turned technocrat, are two bright spots.
LEAD: Frank J. Viola, a former Postmaster of Bronx County, died yesterday at his home in New Fairfeld, Conn. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: The preliminary jousting over President Bush's nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court continued today, with a conservative coalition calling for quick and unanimous confirmation.

LEAD: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, has named the agency's highest-ranking black field agent to investigate allegations that evidence of widespread racial discrimination within the bureau was covered up by white supervisors, F.B.I. officials said today.

LEAD: QUEEN ELIZABETH II dusted off a rare honor and gave it to her baby sister yesterday. The Queen invested PRINCESS MARGARET with the Insignia of the Royal Victorian Chain, as a personal honor on her 60th birthday. ELIZABETH, THE QUEEN MOTHER, is the only other member of the royal family to have received the insignia.

LEAD: Prices for oil and gasoline rose slightly yesterday after swinging sharply during the day. They surged early in the day but then fell back after a statement by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that traders said was less aggressive than expected.
LEAD: John Fox, a novelist and short-story writer, died of AIDS on Aug. 14 at his home in Manhattan, a family spokesman said. He was 38 years old.

LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to deploy an all-digital long-distance network by the end of next year, and might take a charge of $500 million to $550 million against this quarter's earnings to cover the cost of retiring older network equipment.

LEAD: Dr. Leo I. Dana, a former Union Carbide research executive who specialized in low-temperature physics, died on Thursday in Canton, Ohio, at the age of 94.

LEAD: In a bargain with prosecutors, a 46-year-old Denver man today pleaded guilty to manslaughter for rigging a shotgun booby trap that killed a young man who had broken into his machine tool shop. He was placed on six years' probation and ordered to pay $9,500 in fines and restitution.
LEAD: Engineers lost radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft tonight for the second time in five days, the national Aeronautics and Space Administration said late tonight.

LEAD: The Washington Post Company and American Personal Communications Inc., a small cellular telephone company in Baltimore, said yesterday that they had agreed to form a limited partnership to develop a new generation of cellular telephone service in Washington.

LEAD: Just four months after being named president of the 3Com Corporation, Eric P. Benhamou has been elected chief executive. On Sept. 20, Mr. Benhamou will succeed L. William Krause, who will continue as chairman of the computer networking company based in Santa Clara, Calif.

LEAD: The following report was transmitted under rules imposed in Saudi Arabia by the Defense Department for American correspondents accredited to the Pentagon. The rules prohibit reporting of exact numbers of troops or weapons, their exact locations or the names of enlisted personnel.

LEAD: Three days after beginning regular operation, the Seabrook nuclear reactor closed down today, its eighth unplanned shutdown since connecting to the regional power grid on May 29. LEAD: WITH the opening of U.S.E.D. last Sunday, it feels as if it is 1976 again in Greenwich Village. That was the year Jerry Harmyk opened Johnny Jupiter on West 10th Street, a strange new breed of shop that seemed to combine garage sale, flea market and toy store.

LEAD: Why should wine drinkers be esteemed as nobs while beer drinkers are put down as slobs? This one is an Englishman who lives up to his title, ''The Bard of Beer,'' in the six-part series, sensibly called ''Beer,'' that begins tonight at 10:30 on the Discovery Channel.

LEAD: THE 400-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average since mid-July has captured headlines, but the real carnage is taking place in the over-the-counter market. Investors describe the activity of recent weeks as the worst since the October 1987 crash.

LEAD: Kuwaitis remain defiant in the wake of the Iraqi occupation of their country, and an underground armed resistance has sprung up, according to an article in the Wednesday issue of The Washington Post. The paper said that the article was ''an eyewitness account of recent events.''

LEAD: Boston is one of those places where religion and politics sometimes merge to the point of being indistinguishable. Such was the case during one of Representative Joe Moakley's visits to the streets of the South Boston district that has been his base since he entered politics 37 years ago.

Mr. Cate, a Hilo High School teacher, was protesting state-backed plans for geothermal energy plants in Wao Kele O Puna Rainforest.

Seventeen guys in dark glasses are playing electric guitars and keyboards on the stage of a small club in Finland. All of these men are named Frank, and some of them have died earlier in the film, ''Calamari Union,'' which is not about a rock band at all, but about the Franks' meandering attempts to get to the other side of Helsinki. Yet here they are, alive and singing what could be the director Aki Kaurismaki's anthem: ''Bad boys are coming to break all your toys.'' Mr. Kaurismaki, who has written and directed eight mischievous, society-tweaking films in the last seven years, is the highly successful bad boy of Finnish cinema. In fact, he and his older brother Mika almost are the Finnish cinema; each directs, and together they produce their own works and distribute foreign films. Now Aki Kaurismaki's films are arriving in the United States in one great wave, and they demonstrate that, at the age of 33, he is more than a prolific upstart or a local curiosity; he is an original and commanding talent among international film makers.

LEAD: TRACK AND FIELD Nehemiah Earns Revenge in Hurdles The former world record-holder, Renaldo Nehemiah, beat the current record-holder, Roger Kingdom, today in the 110-meter high hurdles at an international meet at Linz, Austria. LEAD: Most of the big airlines said yesterday that they would delay a planned 5.3 percent fare increase until Aug. 30.
LEAD: Bernard Wex, designer of the world's longest suspension bridge span, died on July 31, The Independent newspaper reported today. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: Amid a growing tax revolt and criticism within his own party of his slow response in defusing it, Gov. Jim Florio today removed his chief of staff. Top Democrats saw the move as a shakeup among the Governor's political advisers.

LEAD: THE OIL JOLT The price of oil topped $31 a barrel, the highest price since November 1985, when the oil markets were still recovering from the Iranian revolution five years earlier. The current Middle East crisis has now raised prices higher than they were when Iran and Iraq were trying to sink each other's tankers.

LEAD: Differences between the Soviet Union and the United States on when to use force to uphold economic sanctions against Iraq are troublesome. But they scarcely threaten the remarkable international consensus that increasingly isolates Saddam Hussein.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Property and Casualty Insurance Company is asking workers to retire, but its general counsel says a report that the company wants 80 percent of its work force to leave was exaggerated. ''In no way would there be an 80 percent reduction in our work force,'' said, Richard W. Berstein, a vice president, in regard to an article in The Providence Journal

LEAD: With their preseason game against the Giants coming up Saturday, the Jets still have three players out of camp. They are the running back Blair Thomas and the wide receiver Reggie Rembert - the top two draft picks - and Jim Sweeney, the seventh-year center.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The most excruciating choice faced by ethical people is called triage. When a field hospital is overwhelmed with casualties, someone has to decide which of the wounded can be saved before allocating scarce medicine and treatment -denying it to those with little chance of survival.

LEAD: * Tasco Sales Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a distributor of consumer optics, to W.B. Doner and Co., Baltimore and St. Petersburg, Fla., for a reported billing of more than $1 million. Advertsing had previously been done in house.

LEAD: The Persian Gulf crisis has brought Defense Secretary Dick Cheney into new prominence in the White House, strengthening his relationships with President Bush and with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser.

LEAD: In a blistering opinion, a Federal judge today dismissed the lawsuit brought by Charles H. Keating Jr. to regain control of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. The judge said that the Government seizure of Lincoln was ''fully justified'' and that the actions of Mr. Keating and his associates amounted to a ''looting'' of the institution.

LEAD: Bozell, the giant New York advertising agency, has created a series of commercials for Valvoline Oil, but the real news is that the campaign will be broadcast next week during a special television program the agency also created for its client.

LEAD: Luigi Cardinal Dadaglio, a Vatican diplomat who played a major role in liberalizing the Roman Catholic Church in Spain in the waning years of Franco's rule, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Rome at the age of 75. The Vatican said he died of a heart ailment.

LEAD: Even as commodity traders extended the upward march of oil prices in the futures market, investors continued to unload their holdings in oil companies and oilfield service companies, for the third consecutive day.
LEAD: American French and British representatives have agreed on the text of a Security Council resolution endorsing military action to enforce the embargo against Iraq, diplomats said today.

LEAD: Ed Reynolds, a linebacker for the New England Patriots who is also a captain in the United States Army Reserves, was informed Wednesday that he could be called to action after President Bush announced a call-up of 40,000 reserve units because of the crisis in the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: The U.S. has accomplished its original military objective in the Middle East: We stepped in with a strong presence in Saudi Arabia and stopped Saddam Hussein's march south to control the Middle East oilfields. That was a bold and proper action. It was a brilliant performance.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: The Nippon Steel Corporation of Japan has formed a new American subsidiary, Librex Computer Systems Inc., to manufacture and market computer products. The unit, based in San Jose, Calif., plans to introduce its first products, notebook computers, in the fourth quarter of the year. Many Japanese companies in basic industries like steel and chemicals have been diversifying into electronics and biotechnology.
LEAD: After the boom years of the 1980's, New York City tourism is down slightly this summer, a dip that is being closely monitored by the local tourist industry.
LEAD: * Allied-Lyons P.L.C., London, the beverage company, said Suntory Ltd., the Japanese beverage maker, had increased its Allied stake to almost 5 percent from 2.5 percent.

LEAD: Presidents Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Najibullah of Afghanistan met today and discussed the problems their nations face, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. They also discussed events in Iraq, but Tass provided few details.

LEAD: James Foley's ''After Dark, My Sweet'' is a brisk, entertaining contemporary melodrama about the kind of sleazy characters who populated California crime literature 35 years ago. That's no surprise, since the screenplay, adapted by Robert Redlin and Mr. Foley, is based on Jim Thompson's novel, published in 1955.

LEAD: Tens of thousands of people were caught today in a vast stretch of scorching desert no man's land between Iraq and Jordan as this country struggled to cope with a tidal wave of refugees fleeing the threat of war in Iraq and Kuwait.

LEAD: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, who has faced criticism over awarding lucrative state contracts to campaign contributors, relied on a New York consultant firm that contributed $10,000 to his campaign in investing state pension funds in a Boston office building. The property's appraised value has since declined by slightly more than a third.

LEAD: When Wesley Snipes was preparing for the role of the jazz saxophonist Shadow Henderson in Spike Lee's film ''Mo' Better Blues,'' he studied the moves of some of the greatest jazz legends of all time.

LEAD: Bobby Bonilla hit a grand slam to cap Pittsburgh's six-run fifth inning and Barry Bonds hit a two-run homer as the Pirates won their fifth in a row over Cincinnati, beating the Reds by 9-3 tonight in a battle of National League division leaders.

LEAD: Biologists have documented the first catch of an Atlantic salmon in Alaska waters, raising fears that escaped fish from commercial farms will introduce diseases dangerous to the state's valuable native species.
LEAD: American, French and British representatives agreed on the text of a Security Council resolution endorsing military action to enforce the embargo against Iraq, diplomats said.
LEAD: While the Mets sleepwalk through the West, the Kid and the Mex are looking better and better, in retrospect.
LEAD: With Big Bugs

LEAD: A teen-ager was sentenced today to life in prison without hope of parole for stabbing and strangling a friend in a crime he said was influenced by repeated viewings of the movie ''A Clockwork Orange.'' On June 21, the defendant, Michale Anderson, who turned 18 years old today, was convicted of first-degree murder in the death of 17-year-old Karen Hurwitz, who died on Oct.

LEAD: Listening to ''Angels: Visions and Apparitions'' at Damrosch Park on Wednesday night, one longed for childhood. Give the very young a little melodrama, a spooky sound or two, even the barest of props, and innocent imaginations will have no trouble building their own private worlds of wonder.

LEAD: In a ceremony yesterday in Canberra, SIR GEOFFREY HOWE, the Deputy Prime Minister of Britain, handed over Australia's birth certificate, Reuters reported. The document, with its faded writing on vellum, officially ended Australia's status as a British colony in 1901 and recognized it as a nation. The country is a member of the Commonwealth.

LEAD: Al Davis was quoted in a published report today as having told a Raider team meeting it was ''100 percent certain'' the club would return to its old home in Oakland to play the 1990 season. The Raiders, however, vehemently denied it. ''We fully expect to play our 1990 home games in Los Angeles,'' said Al LoCasale, the Raiders' executive assistant.
LEAD: In the midst of the Persian Gulf oil crisis, much of the world's money is fleeing to safe harbors in Britain, Australia and Canada.
LEAD: The third trial of Richard W. Miller, the only agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who has ever been charged with spying against the United States, opened here on Wednesday.

LEAD: The National Endowment for the Arts is creating a panel to investigate complaints from ''any reliable source'' that grant recipients are violating the law by using Federal money to produce obscene art.
LEAD: A private airplane crashed on takeoff and burned at Houston Intercontinental Airport today, killing three men and injuring 12 others, officials said.

LEAD: As the third day of a water shortage on Rikers Island threatened the fragile mood there, relations between Mayor David N. Dinkins and the head of the correction officers' union turned even more bitter yesterday, with the union chief accusing the Mayor of siding with rebellious inmates because most of them are black.

LEAD: A New York Times/CBS News Poll found that Americans had turned decidedly sour in their perceptions about the state of the economy. Such a sentiment frequently worsens the nation's actual economic condition.
LEAD: Valerie B. Salembier, president of The New York Post for nearly 17 months, announced yesterday that she was resigning as of today.

LEAD: Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies raided a house here Wednesday night and rescued 92 illegal aliens who were being held captive by nine smugglers demanding ransom from the aliens' relatives, the authorities said today.
LEAD: The Rangers announced yesterday that they had signed Mike Gartner to a new contract. The deal, said a source familiar with the negotiations, is for two years and is worth roughly $1.2 million.
LEAD: The regional airline subsidiary of the AMR Corporation will become the largest operator of ATR aircraft in the world with its order this week for $1 billion worth of aircraft.

LEAD: When Tom Bradley realized that the illness inside him was going public, he envisioned headlines: ''GAY AIDS TEACHER! PARENTS REVOLT! CLASSROOM MAYHEM!''

LEAD: A group of former employees and associates of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the defunct brokerage house, have arranged what amounts to a secured loan to William Farley, a former Drexel client who controls Fruit of the Loom Inc., filings made yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission show.

LEAD: Talented 2-year-olds have been so slow to emerge this year that it seems possible the eventual champion juvenile has yet to make his debut. It is more comforting to think that the best are yet to run than to pronounce the crop a dull one already, and there is a theory to support that notion.
LEAD: The Ryland Group, the nation's second-largest home builder, took analysts by surprise earlier this summer when it said it would earn less in the second quarter than it had expected.

LEAD: He is round and chubby, and he wears eyeglasses now, and his left arm has pitched baseballs for 2,300 innings in the last 10 years in a career that seemed finished two summers ago.
LEAD: The most active people on the baseball field during a session of the Little League World Series today were the dozen groundskeepers who battled rain and mud in a losing cause.

LEAD: Warner Brothers Inc. has agreed to move its film, television, comic book and licensing divisions from 75 Rockefeller Center to 140,000 square feet of office space at 1325 Avenue of the Americas. The new 35-story tower, which Warner will move into next spring, was developed by Edward J. Minskoff Equities Inc.

LEAD: Priva Gross, a retired chairwoman of the art department of Queensborough Community College of the City University of New York, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan. She died of cancer, a spokesman for the family said. Professor Gross, whose specialty was medieval art, taught at the college for 20 years, retiring in 1981.

LEAD: The man is sitting in his office at a fitness center, looking at the figure on the television screen. The television is on a chair, resting upon the book ''Secrets of Soviet Sports Fitness and Training.'' The figure on the screen is throwing footballs, viewed from the side and the front in normal and slow motion.

LEAD: New York may be the archetypal cosmopolitan city, but New Yorkers are notoriously provincial when it comes to acknowledging the extent of cultural life beyond the Hudson River or across the Throgs Neck Bridge. The fact is that while much of Manhattan dozes through August, museums and galleries at nearby points north, south, east and west offer the summer's most substantive and inventive exhibitions.
LEAD: An article on Aug. 16 about Texas' use of prisoners in training dogs to track escaped inmates misstated the position taken by Ann Richards, the Democratic candidate for governor.
LEAD: Heavy selling sent prices of high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' sharply lower yesterday as traders reacted to the uncertainty in the Middle East and the sharp decline in the stock market.

LEAD: Victor J. Siegel, former adminstrative vice president of the Bank Street College of Education, a private school for teachers, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: On the edge of Nairobi's industrial park sits one of the most visible manufacturing ventures in Kenya. Founded after independence in 1963 by the Jumas, an Asian family who came to Kenya from Uganda, the company, Orbitsports, makes soccer balls, rugby balls - indeed, all kinds of balls - dart boards, boxing gloves, and a wide range of sports clothing and leisure wear.

LEAD: A robbery suspect was killed last night in an exchange of gunfire with two undercover police officers in a Bronx school yard, the police said. LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration said in a study to be published on Friday that a genetically engineered growth hormone that increases milk production in dairy cows was harmless to human health.
LEAD: Six ships carrying 3,000 West African soldiers sailed from here today to enforce a cease-fire in Liberia, where a 10,000-man rebel army has rejected a proposed truce.

LEAD: Actors' Equity and Cameron Mackintosh, the producer of ''Miss Saigon,'' agreed yesterday to meet in New York City in early September ''in an effort to establish a working relationship'' that would clear the way for the hit London musical to come to Broadway.

LEAD: Stump Merrill, the manager of the Yankees, said yesterday that he had full confidence in the ability of Dave Righetti, the left-handed closer who will become a free agent at the end of the season, and that he couldn't or wouldn't imagine a bullpen without him next season.

LEAD: An airplane parts distributor is being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Federal Aviation Administration for possibly misrepresenting the condition and source of the parts it sold to airlines, aircraft operators and other aviation vendors.
LEAD: Slavomir Stracer, Czechoslvakia's Minister of Foreign Trade, died of a heart attack Tuesday. He was 55 years old.

LEAD: A woman in a black-and-white movie called ''The Icicle Thief'' leaps into a river and emerges from a washing machine in a full-colored television commercial for detergent. A family half-watching this movie on television doesn't notice anything strange. Maurizio Nichetti's ''Icicle Thief,'' the work that includes the film within a film, the commercials within a film and more, sounds too strained and clever for its own good.
