LEAD: World Yacht is a rather grandiose name for a craft that rarely ventures beyond the Statue of Liberty. Yet for a dazzling sightseeing tour of New York Harbor combined with music, dancing and a surprisingly good meal, World Yacht can be enthusiastically recommended.
LEAD: Pearl Bailey was remembered at her funeral today as an extraordinary entertainer and a woman who loved life and everyone she met.

LEAD: A headline on the Media Business page on Aug. 6 about an investment by the Times Mirror Company in La Opinion, one of the United States' largest Spanish-language daily newspapers, referred to the action incorrectly in some editions. Times Mirror is purchasing 50 percent of the newspaper; it is not buying the whole paper.

LEAD: Recorded votes in Congress have a habit of becoming campaign nightmares. To avoid them, lawmakers often jockey for voice votes on controversial legislation, so as not to have to risk going on the record.

LEAD: Imagine the Middle East with Saddam Hussein in command of a multimillion-man army, equipped with chemical, biological and nuclear weapons, and intercontinental missiles to deliver them.

LEAD: SEAN CONNERY, who quickened pulses in the 60's and 70's as James Bond and set a new standard as sophisticated-hero-with-humor, will be 60 years old tomorrow. LEAD: * Bio-Rad Laboratories Inc., Hercules, Calif., named Tony R. Brown vice president and chief operating officer.
LEAD: A report in the Business People column on Monday about Andre Danesh, an investor in distressed companies, referred incorrectly to one of his investments. He invested in Revco D.S.

LEAD: Renault S.A., the French state-owned automobile maker, is reconsidering its $6-a-share offer for all remaining shares of Mack Trucks Inc. because of the company's revised forecast of losses for the year. The shares of Mack Trucks fell by $1.125 each today, to $5.25, in over-the-counter trading.

LEAD: Legend has it that the Iroquois who once populated this area believed that the Great Spirit observed the world from behind the thick curtain of Horseshoe Falls. If so, the Spirit has been a backstage witness to a summer that might have been a script by David Lynch: an eerie season of intrigue, dark comedy and tragedy that has been unusual even by Niagara Falls standards.

LEAD: Of all this summer's movies, ''Darkman'' is the one aimed most directly at the audience for ''Batman.'' From its title to the organ-swelling music by Danny Elfman (who seems to have borrowed his own score for ''Batman''), on to its dim, foggy, comic-book look, this film lives in the shadow of last year's hit.
LEAD: Donald J. Trump said yesterday that the Trump Shuttle was no longer for sale. In a separate announcement, the airline said it would raise its fares by $10, effective Monday.

LEAD: Honeywell Inc. announced today that its Defense and Marine Systems unit plans to cut 120 of its 8,300 employees effective Sept. 6. The staff cuts are in preparation for the planned spinoff of the Defense and Marine Systems unit.

LEAD: For the last 127 years, the remains of a man named Pierre Toussaint have been lying in a cemetery in what is now New York City's Little Italy. If the State Supreme Court agrees, they are about to be disturbed. The Catholic Church wants to unearth the grave to make sure it does indeed embrace Mr. Toussaint, and to find out whether he is, perhaps, in a miraculous state of preservation.
LEAD: Philip M. Boffey will become the deputy editorial page editor of The New York Times on Nov. 1. The appointment was announced yesterday by Jack Rosenthal, the editorial page editor.
LEAD: The selloff in the credit markets continued yesterday and interest rates rose, as dealers reacted to a further rise in oil prices by marking down the price of most Treasury securities.

LEAD: Traditionally, tourists coming to New York City have braved the noise , the crime and the people. They are doing so this summer as well, but in smaller numbers than they did during the boom years of the 1980's.

LEAD: Reversing a recommendation made last year, a five-judge panel appointed by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist today called for allowing television, radio and photographic coverage of civil proceedings in Federal courts in an experiment.

LEAD: The tumultuous combination of democracy and unrest that has swept East Germany into an October reunification with West Germany reaches beyond the nation's much-publicized crumbling economy. The toppling of Communist rule last year has also brought turmoil in the criminal justice system.

LEAD: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, assured a conservative writer that President Bush's Supreme Court nominee, David H. Souter, would offer a strong conservative voice on the Court if confirmed, according to a memorandum made public today.

LEAD: Flora Staal Hartog, who founded F. Staal, the Fifth Avenue jewelry store, 50 years ago and ran it until she retired in 1983, died yesterday at her home in Forest Hills, Queens. She was 87 years old.
LEAD: Steady radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft orbiting Venus was re-established yesterday, but the reason for the on-again, off-again communications continued to mystify project engineers.
LEAD: On the fourth Monday in July, Marcella David was supposed to start preparing for the first Monday in October.

LEAD: Crude oil prices climbed 71 cents yesterday, reaching $31.93 a barrel. Analysts attributed the increase to momentum from Wednesday's leap of $2.51 and anxiety over today's deadline set by Iraq for closing all embassies in Kuwait.

LEAD: Anne Wheeler's ''Bye Bye Blues'' has the tone and texture of a dreamy pop ballad from World War II spun out over nearly two hours. Reflecting the wide-open spaces of western Canada where most of it was shot, the slow-moving, beautifully photographed film takes its time in telling the story of a young woman who finds self-sufficiency as a band singer during World War II while her husband is a prisoner of the Japanese.

LEAD: A state agency has asked its employees to collect unused soap bars and shampoo bottles from hotels and motels when they are on trips and save them for the state's homeless. LEAD: A Federal district judge on the Pacific island of Guam has struck down the nation's most restrictive abortion law, one that directly challenged the constitutional right to abortion established in the landmark Roe v. Wade case.

LEAD: Odilon Redon's name does not often appear near the top of lists of 19th-century artists who influenced 20th-century art, but before the Surrealists - before many of the Surrealists were born, in fact - he was exploring the dark side of the subconscious.

LEAD: CYCLING Two Americans Sprint to Final Connie Young and Renee Duprel won their sprint semifinals yesterday at the world championships in Maebashi, Japan, setting up an all-American final. LEAD: Hit by a worldwide advertising slump and heavy losses at its British satellite-television service, the News Corporation reported yesterday that its profits had fallen 27 percent in the fourth quarter and 43 percent for the fiscal year.

LEAD: Iraq warned the United States and more than two dozen other nations Thursday that if they challenged a deadline today and tried to keep their embassies in Iraq-occupied Kuwait open, as they have vowed to do, Baghdad would take it as an ''act of aggression.''

Verrecchia chief operating officer of domestic toy operations and manufacturing services.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who succeeded Mr. Johns at the church.

LEAD: It's one thing to hand over an unfamiliar bill or a few strange coins after a pleasant hour at a Paris sidewalk cafe. It's quite a different thing to find that you've just spent $10 for a Coke and sandwich and a touch of ambiance.

LEAD: Cancer deaths among people 55 and older are climbing steeply and steadily, according to a new study. The increases are occurring in all six countries analyzed in the study: the United States, Japan and four European nations.

LEAD: David W. Peck, a retired Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court who played a leading role in court reform in the late 1940's and 1950's, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 520 money market mutual funds increased $6.22 billion, to $408 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. At the 162 institutional funds, assets rose $1.15 billion, to $99.48 billion. The assets of the 253 general-purpose funds were up $2.40 billion, to $142.45 billion.

LEAD: A solemn little boy comes out of his house one rainy morning to find the sun shining. His mother, practical and no-nonsense, looks up at the sky and says that foxes hold their wedding processions in such weather. ''They don't like to be seen by people,'' she says, and goes about her business.
LEAD: The Zapata Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement to sell 90 percent of its drilling-rig fleet to a European group for $280 million.

LEAD: ''The Witches'' resembles a brilliantly told bedtime story, though the teller of this children's tale may well be the slightly cracked relative who can't judge when scary stories become nightmares. This tale about a witches' plot to turn every child in England into a mouse is based on the novel by Roald Dahl, who does not write cuddly sugarcoated books.

LEAD: PRINCE CHARLES faces a second operation on his right arm, which was broken earlier this summer when he fell off his pony during a polo match. Since undergoing surgery at Circencester Hospital, Wiltshire, after the fall, he has continued to have pain and it has led him to cancel public engagements.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Investors continued to unload their holdings in oil companies and oilfield service companies for the third consecutive day.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After more than a week of uncertainty, thousands of military reservists throughout the country will begin hearing today whether they are among the more than 40,000 ordered to leave their jobs and homes and report for active duty.

LEAD: Top American military commanders here are recommending that Washington respond to any Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia with a punishing, all-out attack against Iraqi military forces and installations.

LEAD: As the call-up of reservists began, the Pentagon yesterday discarded a policy that had prohibited journalists from publishing or broadcasting the names and hometowns of enlisted men and women stationed in the Persian Gulf region.

LEAD: A basic principle of bidding that is learned by beginners and observed quite strictly by experts is this: If your partner shows a five-card major suit and you have three-card support, you must show it, either immediately or on the next round, unless perhaps you uncover a good fit elsewhere.

LEAD: In two weeks Democrats will choose in a primary for governor between a challenger whose strategy for victory counts on as few voters as possible going to the polls and a convention-endorsed candidate who rarely acknowledges there is a race at all.

LEAD: International events are now influencing the interest rates that banks pay more than the economy is influencing them. Yields on certificates of deposit have been falling for more than three months, but the Middle East situation could mean higher yields in the near future. Bank rate analysts suggest watching rates on certificates of deposit closely for the next three weeks and holding some money in a federally insured bank money market account to be ready to shift to C.D.

LEAD: Chief Judge Antoinette Loiacono Dupont and Judge Albert W. Cretella Jr. of the Connecticut State Appellate Court were married yesterday in New London. The Rev. Joseph Castaldi officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, assisted by the Rev. Felix H. McGuire and the Rev. Vincent E. Lyddy.

LEAD: A headline yesterday about a New York Times/CBS News Poll on Americans' view of the economy referred incorrectly in some copies to the segment who believe the nation is now in a recession. It was slightly more than 6 in 10, not ''nearly.''

LEAD: He spent Thursday night in Greenwich Village, shopping for clothes - just another 19-year-old. He got the call at 11:30 P.M. By this afternoon he was in an olive drab flight suit with an American flag insignia on one arm, checking in at the Air National Guard base here, 60 miles north of New York City.

LEAD: Officials at Sematech, the private industry and Federal Government chip-making consortium, said yesterday that they were now making semiconductor chips with half-micron-wide circuit lines on American-made equipment.
LEAD: The contest between oil and natural gas for supremacy in the home heating market has been long and bitter. Now the confrontation between the United States and Iraq has made it more intense.

LEAD: Because of the Pakistan Day Parade, Lexington Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 26th to 47th Streets from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M. For a related street fair, Madison Avenue will be closed from 23d to 26th Streets from 3 P.M. to 8 P.M.
LEAD: A financial adviser afraid to face his clients admitted in a videotape message that he lost about $100 million of investors' money by making risky trades in stock options.

LEAD: A Federal district judge in Reading, Pa., today struck down several provisions of a restrictive abortion law that was enacted in Pennsylvania last year with the intention that it become a vehicle for the Supreme Court to reconsider the issue of abortion.

LEAD: Long-term Treasury bond yields continued to edge higher yesterday in a trading session marked by volatile price swings. The Treasury debt market was buoyed after the opening by weakness in oil prices and the absence of any signifcant worsening of the situation in the Middle East, as well as by the expected slowing in the growth rate of the second-quarter gross national product.

LEAD: Federal Reserve policy makers concluded in July that inflation remained high enough to require that current interest rates be maintained despite a ''relatively slow'' economy, records released today show.

LEAD: A judge today dismissed charges against a Greenwich millionaire arrested in July in the spray painting of a real-estate sign that he contended was offensive and illegal. The 64-year-old man, Rene Anselmo, who was charged with third-degree criminal mischief, said that he thought he had made his point.

LEAD: Iraqi soldiers are shooting at carloads of people trying to drive overland out of Kuwait, while occasional attacks on the occupied forces continue in urban areas, according to two Kuwaitis who fled to Saudi Arabia.

LEAD: Federal regulators, fresh from their experience taking over distressed property elsewhere in the nation, are facing new legal challenges and deep resentment as they move into the troubled market for New York area cooperative apartments.

LEAD: Tamzin Ellen Anderson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael W. Anderson of Bozeman, Mont., was married there yesterday to Nicholas Andrew White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard D. White Jr. of New York. The Rev. Charles Willming performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church. Mrs. White, 23 years old, expects to graduate from Montana State University in June.
LEAD: Six ships carrying 3,000 West African soldiers arrived off Monrovia today, but did not attempt to dock as gunfire erupted in the port of the Liberian capital.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today that the Iraqi leader will face additional international sanctions if he does not withdraw his troops from Kuwait and release foreign nationals under his control.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered - or ''short interest'' - fell one-half of 1 percent for actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-August. The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered - or ''short interest'' - fell one-half of 1 percent for actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-August. A total of 255.5 million shares were held short and not yet covered in mid-August, the association said, compared with a revised total of 256.9 million in the period that ended in mid-July. The August activity represents short selling in 2,335 stocks; in July the short selling was spread among 2,299 issues. Short-sellers expect a stock's price to decline, so they sell borrowed stock in anticipation of buying back an equal number of shares later at a lower price, thereby making a profit. Views of Analysts Differ Some traders and analysts consider a large short position to be bearish, because it presumably represents a strong cumulative belief that the market will turn down. Under this reasoning, a large jump in the position would also be bearish.

LEAD: A picture on the Law page yesterday with an article about volunteer prosecutors was published in error.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to announce on Sept. 5 its plans for introducing mainframe computers twice as powerful as the current systems, a market research group said.

LEAD: Before the Persian Gulf crisis began, the Staten Island home port was almost ready to open, or almost ready to close, depending on who was asked. Now, the prospects for the port are even more confused.

The most telling condemnation comes from Moscow, Iraq's longtime ally.

LEAD: In a move that analysts said amounted to a concession that its new cars and trucks may be priced too high in a soft market, the General Motors Corporation said today that it was offering incentives on many of its 1991 models, including several that go on sale this month for the first time.

LEAD: Two female Soviet athletes - the former world high-jump champion Tamara Bykova and the heptathlete Larisa Nikitina - have been suspended for using banned drugs at the Goodwill Games last month in Seattle and will miss next week's European championships, the Soviet Athletics Federation said in Moscow yesterday.

LEAD: LIV ULLMANN and JEREMY IRONS won the Francois Truffaut Award at the Giffoni Film Festival recently. The jury was made up of 120 children. The festival, near Salerno, Italy, is devoted to films for children 10 14 years old. Ms. Ullmann won for her 10 years of work with children as good-will ambassador for Unicef and as vice president of the International Rescue Committee.

LEAD: Sergei Dovlatov, a leading Soviet emigre writer noted for the laconic irony and graceful irreverence of his stories about his homeland, died of heart failure yesterday at Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 48 years old.
LEAD: The Data General Corporation said it would lay off more than 2,000 workers, or 4.9 percent of its work force, in the next several weeks.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In the final weeks of their dry season, the Yankees seem ready to begin laying more groundwork for the future. They are talking with other clubs about trades, pondering the possibility of moving veterans and looking closely at prospects who might offer help as early as next summer. They are also still losing.

LEAD: Saying that Nassau County had broken an agreement that would have enabled it to meet a deadline to stop dumping sewage sludge in the ocean by the end of 1991, Federal prosecutors today asked a Federal judge to declare the county in contempt of court.

LEAD: Four people, three of them teen-agers, were charged yesterday with murdering a mentally retarded man who suffocated inside a closet while they caroused in his Bronx apartment for nearly six days and sold his belongings, the police said.
LEAD: Ernest Gladstone, a retired teacher in Brooklyn, has patented a two-chambered cork that he says makes it possible to purify champagne without exposing it to the air.

LEAD: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.29 percent this week, up from 10.05 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the highest level since a similar 10.29 percent rate was posted last June 1. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.36 percent, up from 8.31 percent last week.
LEAD: Texas and Texas A&M announced today that they would stay in the Southwest Conference, the league the two schools helped form 76 years ago.
LEAD: What has led President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, long viewed in the West as an intractable adversary, to align his nation with the United States in the Persian Gulf crisis?

LEAD: Researchers at the Celgene Corporation in Warren, N.J., obtained patent approval this week for a method of determining whether molecules are, in effect, left-handed or right-handed.
LEAD: The Federal Government shifted its strategy on toy safety this week, filing lawsuits against seven major companies in the United States that distribute or sell imported toys.

LEAD: Reports this week that the State Comptroller had invested state money on the advice of consultants who had given money to his campaign have raised questions again about the influence of campaign contributions in government decisions.

The 48-year-old singer-songwriter was accompanied by his wife and son.

LEAD: In a crackdown on factional bloodletting that has claimed more than 500 lives in 11 days, South African authorities today designated 27 black townships ''unrest areas'' and gave the police wide powers to arrest and search people without warrant and to seize weapons.

LEAD: Prime Minister MICHAEL MANLEY of Jamaica was released from a Manhattan hospital yesterday, nine days after doctors removed a benign growth from his prostate.

LEAD: Roosevelt Watson, one of five black youths who won dismissal of murder charges in a widely publicized case in rural Dawson, Ga., in the mid-1970's, died Tuesday at his home in Albany, Ga. He was 34 years old.

Nadel, president of Creative Philantrophic Resources in New York, had needs similar to those of many of her generation: She wanted to be sure her grandchild got a good education; she wanted to provide a nice memorial for her husband, a Holocaust victim, and she wanted as little of her money as possible to go to taxes.

The President's advisers had recommended raises of 22 percent to 40 percent to keep Civil Service pay abreast of salaries in the private sector.

Mr. Martinez could be sentenced to up to 30 years in prison without parole and fined up to $4 million.
LEAD: In what many analysts see as a further sign of a weakened economy, the Government confirmed today that growth was listless even before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait jolted oil prices.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The shadow cast by Black Monday is growing longer and longer through the canyons of lower Manhattan, where commercial vacancy rates continue to climb higher than they have in years.

LEAD: I was quite moved by the heart-rending description of how a family physically and emotionally survived the bombing of Hiroshima 45 years ago in ''Stories My Parents Told Me, From the Horror of Hiroshima'' (Westchester Opinion, Aug. 5). The oral testimony passed down from one generation to another is an important link to the human impacts of historic events -- impacts that are usually not described in the history texts from which our children learn of the past.

LEAD: Back in those carefree days when we could count on the college football season starting some time after the beginning of the fall semester, when we could make our tailgating plans based on 1:30 kickoffs that had been chiseled in stone months before, and when we didn't need an announcement to know who would be in the Southwest

LEAD: The Security Council overwhelmingly adopted a resolution early today giving the United States and other nations the right to enforce the economic embargo against Iraq by halting shipping to and from that country.

LEAD: The young man in the toque and clipped mustache, chatting with customers at what has become one of Vietnam's best restaurants, is a symbol of the economic strength and potential of the Vietnamese exiles in the United States, as well as of their ambivalence about closer ties between the two countries.

LEAD: ''YOU GOTTA HAVE HEART.'' By Richard Adler with Lee Davis. (Donald I. Fine, $21.95.) ''Hernando's Hideaway,'' ''Hey There,'' ''Steam Heat,'' ''Heart,'' ''Whatever Lola Wants'' - for such songs from his first two shows, ''The Pajama Game'' and ''Damn Yankees,'' which opened on Broadway within a year of each other in the mid-1950's, Richard Adler remains one of the more beloved names in American musical comedy.

LEAD: Mary Gallagher O'Connor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas David O'Connor of Loudonville, N.Y., and Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Smith Morgan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Phillip Morgan of Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Robert McNulty performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

LEAD: HARD CITY. By Clark Howard. (Dutton, $21.95.) Clark Howard's autobiographical novel is set in the slums of Chicago's West Side in the 1950's. Its hero, Richie, is a 12-year-old who escapes from a succession of malignant foster homes, as well as his heroin-ridden mother, to strike out on his own.
LEAD: President Bush's choppy locutions may remind some readers of the similar speech patterns of Alfred Jingle, a memorable if minor character found in Charles Dickens's ''Pickwick Papers.''
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: I'm in London standing in Harrods lower-level market - not the fabled Food Halls that take up maybe a quarter of the ground floor, but the much less touristy lower-level market. I'm staring in dismay at the tea display, which, to my eye, can be no less than 20 feet wide and 6 feet high.

LEAD: Saying he is determined to keep Michigan from becoming a haven for assisted suicides, the county prosecutor here has brought murder charges against a California man who the prosecutor says helped his wife take her own life at a suburban motel last Sunday.

LEAD: Jacqueline A. Kristan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Kristan of Austintown, Ohio, was married yesterday to Stephen J. LoPresti, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph D. LoPresti of Belmont, Mass., by the Rev. Fred Lukehart at the St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church in Austintown. Mrs. LoPresti, 28 years old and a graduate of Bowling Green State University in Ohio, worked until recently as an assistant treasurer at J.

LEAD: For years I had wanted to rent a cottage in the English countryside. I had a clear, if idealized, notion of my requirements: a thatched-roof cottage in a sleepy English village; a rustic stone fence bordering pastures and meadows; honeysuckle and roses by the front door; a pub just a short walk down the lane, and easy access to London should all the above ever become boring.
LEAD: Sea Theme In Disney Plan For Long Beach
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Emily Ruth Heimowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Heimowitz of Scarsdale, N.Y., and New York City, was married last evening to Mitchell Scott Spector, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Spector of Tinton Falls, N.J. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

LEAD: The public has grown increasingly disenchanted with President Bush's handling of the savings and loan crisis, but most Americans still place ultimate blame on the managers and owners in the industry, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

LEAD: A battle over proposed legislation to bar the export of pesticides banned in the United States has escalated, with top chemical industry executives warning that it could cause job losses in plants around the country and impede scientific research.

LEAD: I ARRIVED in the United States on Sept. 5, 1965. I had come as a foreign student in a Ph.D. program at a major American university and intended to return to India, my native land, after obtaining a doctorate. I stayed on to enjoy the freedom, an organized way of life and the creature comforts that were not available to me in my old country.

LEAD: AT MANHATTAN's Patricia Field, a quirky Greenwich Village emporium known for its radical street-chic fashions, a small, furry revolution is under way. All manner of wigs - the neo, the retro, the bizarre, even the downright pretty - are displayed like some rogue's gallery of pop-culture idols. Want to pass for Bart Simpson, America's reigning cartoon brat?

LEAD: The Jets reached agreement today with Blair Thomas, their No. 1 draft choice, and the running back from Penn State held a brief news conference, then suited up for did not play in the exhibition game against the Giants at Giants Stadium.

LEAD: The Rip Van Winkle Award for 1990 surely must go to Harold Jaffe (''Fine Art Museum Is Not Needed in Roslyn,'' Aug. 5) for his notion that Nassau County's Museum of Fine Art should be abandoned because ''we simply do not need another fine-art museum located at its present location.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: CHRYSLER'S minivan was an original that gonged out a knell for suburbia's well-entrenched station wagon, and I have long thought it was the only way to go. I raced a Plymouth Voyager around the perimeter of the country in the nutty race called One Lap of America and I fell in love. I liked the feel of it.
LEAD: A bystander was slain and four men wounded when a robbery attempt erupted into a gunfight on a Brooklyn street early yesterday morning, the police said.
LEAD: The question being asked in the eight-month-old Liberian civil war is no longer whether President Samuel K. Doe will be removed from office, but when and by whom.
LEAD: Eliot Weinberger's letter (''Farm Stand Story Is About One Person,''Aug. 19), about a retail farm stand in the residential zone of East Hampton, requires correcting.
LEAD: Ani Stern and Askold W. Buk were married yesterday at the New York Academy of Art in New York. M. Michael Grupp, a leader of the American Ethical Union, officiated.

LEAD: Lisa Marie Knoechel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Knoechel of Lake Carmel, N.Y., was married yesterday to Antony Leo Kerz, a son of Louise Kerz of Los Angeles and the late Leo Kerz. The Rev. Brian McWeeney officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. James the Apostle in Carmel, N.Y. Mrs.
LEAD: Allyn Sielaff had a progressive reputation when he took over New York City's jails. Now critics are asking whether isolation made him blind to tension at Rikers Island. Page 40.

LEAD: Grace Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Leah Vivian Rush, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Richard Rush of DeLand, Fla., to Ross Sinclair Cann, a son of Ross S. Cann and Laura Cann, both of Rochester. The Rev. Christopher Brown performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: CHANGES in society and in the law have brought changes in divorce, says Gaetano Ferro, a lawyer in Westport. Reasons for divorce as well as settlements and child-custody arrangements are changing, he said, yet many people are still dissatisfied with the process of of dissolving a marriage.
LEAD: DAN LAURIA is nothing like Jack Arnold, the grumpy character he plays on the ABC-TV series ''The Wonder Years.'' Nothing.

LEAD: Last week, college students began converging on America's campuses for the start of the fall semester. Among them were some four million freshmen. Nowadays, more and more colleges try to make the transition from high school easier with orientation programs. Here are reports from Southern Methodist University and Case Western Reserve University on their programs.

LEAD: Jennifer Mills Brown, the educational marketing manager in the children's book department at HarperCollins Publishers in New York, and John Philip Irwin 3d, who will become an associate at the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton next month, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Muskegon, Mich.

LEAD: The North Parish Unitarian Church in North Andover, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Cordelia Anne Ward, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Graham Ward of North Andover, to James P. Russell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Russell of Ashbourne, County Meath, Ireland. The Rev. David Blanchard performed the ceremony.

LEAD: AMID growing evidence that the county will have to lean more heavily on its property tax in difficult economic times, the Board of Legislators last week approved its first departmental budget of the new fiscal season and considered some unusual new sources of revenue.
LEAD: They're cheaper than a pair of fancy boots, but Janet Hasper's spats and gaiters are just as sexy.

LEAD: With no McDonald's, no movie theaters and only one exit off the Interstate, West could be any one of the dusty rural towns that dot central Texas. But as the Czech Point of Texas, as the town sometimes calls itself, West is the unofficial capital of a thriving Czechoslovak culture that came to Texas more than 150 years ago.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH state and local tourism officials say that the crowds have begun returning to the Jersey Shore after three years of being repelled by reports of coastal pollution, business somehow is just not the same, they say. The officials add that Shore tourism may never be what it once was.

LEAD: ANTIQUE fishing tackle and related paraphernalia, including fish decoys, continue to capture the fancy of collectors, but record-breaking prices are apparently a thing of the past, at least for the time being.
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has upheld rules requiring applicants for radio or television licenses to make only the briefest assertions that their programming will serve the public interest.

LEAD: Few wars have attracted film makers more than the sprawling epic of World War II. The movie industry enlisted massively and for the first time used war as an instrument of propaganda for a national cause. Years later, feature films about World War II might show the downside, but many of those made during the war and thereafter celebrate the crusade of good against evil.

LEAD: The lawsuit brought by Charles H. Keating Jr. to regain control of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Associaton bounced like a bad check last week. In what Federal officials called ''an extremely important victory,'' a Federal judge dismissed Mr. Keating's suit, accused him and other Lincoln executives of pillaging the Arizona institution and said the Government was ''fully justified'' in taking over Lincoln last year.

LEAD: The gardens at Jacob's Pillow are slug-eaten, and the mosquitoes have grown sharks' jaws. Samba drumbeats are heard from studio windows as classes in Afro-Brazilian dance finish out the summer school calendar. And the final entry of the 1990 concert schedule is performances by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane & Company in the barnlike Ted Shawn Theater through this
LEAD: At the field hospital here the nurses are engaged in a nervous waiting game.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Traveling to Aguilas in the Southeastern corner of Spain to learn how the caper finds its way from plant to table, I came away knowing how, but wondering why. Even as a lifelong fan who values the caper's sharp salinity in dishes of all sorts, I marveled, once again, at the trouble people go to for this tiny culinary adornment.

LEAD: With lots of American flags and a homemade sign that read ''Send a message to our troops in the Persian Gulf,'' Lydia Munger and her friends set out on a mission this week, a campaign to flood soldiers and sailors in the Middle East with cheerful postcards from back home.

LEAD: The Emergency Medical Service notified St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center on Friday that it would no longer bring trauma patients to St. Luke's because the hospital's trauma center does not meet the service's standards.
LEAD: Neither rain nor wind nor an abbreviated program kept thousands of picnickers from the giant, informal party on the Great Lawn of Central Park for a free outdoor concert.

LEAD: Uncle Miltie is also a father, and not just to the children mentioned in his ''Who's Who'' biography. In an interview with the National Enquirer last week, Milton Berle said he has an illegitimate son, now 51 years old, whom he sometimes sees at social gatherings but who is unaware of their connection.

LEAD: All it takes to give coal more luster is a crisis in the Middle East. With the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait cutting off about a fifth of the world's oil supplies, coal demand can only increase. But even before the recent jump in oil prices, the United States coal industry was growing enough in both size and efficiency to make healthy profits.

LEAD: When it comes to antiques, whether they be furniture or textiles, their history bespeaks a world of fashion and a way of life that affected the owners as well as the makers. But rare is the exhibition of antiques that takes this factor into account; if an exhibition does, objects appreciated for their beauty alone can also tell a story of commerce.

LEAD: Ask a fashion designer how she selects her business wardrobe, and she will mention the same concerns as other working women. Although she may have a greater array of stylish choices, she wants her clothes to be comfortable as well as chic, as practical as they are handsome. and she doesn't want to have to think about them twice.

LEAD: WITH only a few more weeks of summer on the calendar, tomatoes top the shopping list. Is it possible to indulge in enough of them, to become sated now so they will not be missed as sorely after the season?

LEAD: The annual round of fall boat shows, which begins with a major trade exhibit in Boston this weekend, brings with it grim forecasts for the marine industry. But in the midst of the manufacturers' quagmire exists an area where optimism rules the waves: in the marine export business.

LEAD: MEXICAN BOLERO. By Angeles Mastretta. Translated by Ann Wright. (Viking, $19.95.) The Mexican journalist Angeles Mastretta's debut novel is part of Latin America's literature of political repression: in ''Mexican Bolero,'' a young girl loses her innocence while corrupt politicians, generals, labor leaders and peasant bosses jockey for power in the years after the Mexican Revolution of 1911.

LEAD: In VISIONS OF ANCIENT AMERICA (Rizzoli, $50), the photographer Roberto Schezen turns his lens on archeological sites in Mexico and Central America. The cities he records were built by Aztecs, Toltecs, Olmecs and Mayans, but it is nearly impossible to imagine human creatures living amid these desolate twilight landscapes.

LEAD: Lisa Louise Radley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Radley of Pueblo, Colo., was married yesterday to Roger Tighe Mullarkey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. X. Mullarkey of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Richard Hendry, a Methodist minister, was assisted by the Rev. Eugene O'Brien, the executive vice president of Fordham University and a Roman Catholic priest, in performing the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Pueblo.

LEAD: Braxston Banks went for a job interview with the National Football League and was not hired. He was ''overqualified,'' or the N.F.L. ''just isn't hiring now,'' or the employer was simply not impressed.
LEAD: Jill Barrie Schwartzberg was married last evening at the Plaza in New York to Dennis Alexander Shields. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated.

LEAD: St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford Village, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Judith Ann Zunino and Gerald Anton Nielsen Jr. The Rev. Pierre Botton performed the ceremony.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article ''Memorable Gardens in England's Oxbridge'' by A. L. Rowse (Travel, May 29) described the very attractive botanic garden in Oxford, which goes back to about 1630. The garden was built over what had been a Jewish cemetery, a fact that is commemorated on a plaque at the stone entryway.
LEAD: THERE were times, Carl Harrison Merrill said, when he slept right over there.

LEAD: Q. Because our driveway slopes toward the garage and the drain is small, water collects during heavy rains. Also, since the garage floor is uneven, the rubber door bottom does not seal properly and water flows underneath.

LEAD: In the last week the United States crossed a threshold in confronting Iraq over its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It became more than a nation responding firmly to an international crisis; in its collective consciousness and in cold fact, it began preparing for war.
LEAD: BLACK IN SELMA The Uncommon Life of J. L. Chestnut Jr. By J. L. Chestnut Jr. and Julia Cass. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

LEAD: As this nation ponders its place in world markets, it is increasingly clear that the protection of intellectual property and the upholding of American patent laws are inexorably intertwined with competitiveness.

LEAD: The homebound crush through European airports in late August and early September will be made more difficult this year by security measures augmented because of the Persian Gulf crisis. In mid-August, cities that were checked - Athens, Frankfurt, London, Madrid, Paris and Rome - reported that security requirements so far had delayed no departures, but spokesmen for United
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

LEAD: David Rose, a composer and conductor whose work in television, films and recordings won four Emmy awards, 22 Grammys and an Oscar nomination, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 80 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

LEAD: Leslie Gayle Kahn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Kahn of Manhasset Hills, L.I., was married last evening to Mitchell Craig Tolep, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin B. Tolep of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Robert Jacobs performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I. The bride graduated from the University of Maryland and is an international account associate in the Latin American division of the Bank of Boston in New York.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a listing on Aug. 12 misstated telephone numbers for eating places and hotels in San Sebastian, Spain, and the immediate area. The correct numbers follow: Arzak, 27-8465; Akelarre, 21-2052; Nicolasa, 42-1762; Panier Fleuri, 42-4205; Chomin, 21-0705; Bodegon Alejandro, 42-7158; Kako, 55-1741; the Maria Cristina, 42-4900; the Hotel de Londres y de Inglaterra, 42-6989; Niza, 42-6663; Hostal Bahia, 46-1083, and Pension Lorea, 42-7258.

LEAD: Behind a pale brick fence on the outskirts of the Iraqi village of Qurna sits a small, gnarled apple tree with a double trunk. A bronze plaque tells visitors they have reached the Garden of Eden. But this unassuming shrine is little more than a tourist trap for weekend picnickers. There is, after all, another Garden of Eden in Syria, and nobody can be sure where the real site is.

LEAD: For a simple, undemanding and not-too-foreign week removed from the ruts of home and disciplines of office, renting a cottage in Ireland seemed ideal. After all, Ireland is about as close as Europe gets to America, the people speak our language, and my wife and I personally share, across uncertain generations, elements of the culture.

LEAD: Daisy L. Rasberry lives as if suspended in time. She has not been to work for two months. Nor has she slept a full night since the evening of June 23, when a Saturday shopping trip with two of her daughters ended with her 10-year-old ''baby,'' Shaniqua, bleeding in her arms from a fatal gunshot wound to the chest.
LEAD: It was not a good week for Dave Righetti.
LEAD: Two University of Colorado students who were tracking bighorn sheep in southwest Colorado have stumbled upon the virtually untouched ruins of a lost Indian village more than 1,100 years old.
LEAD: The Sri Lankan Army is closing in on Jaffna, the citadel and city that have symbolized Tamil resistance in an ethnic conflict that has torn apart South Asia's most developed nation.

LEAD: For This Week: Plan for next spring's flower garden; mail orders for hardy bulbs. Feed 'mums to support oncoming bloom. Last call to dig and divide bearded iris. Keep after weeds. Repair weak, established lawns and seed or sod new ones. Spray rosebushes with a fungicide to protect them from black spot.

LEAD: A man convicted of plotting to kill a Roman Catholic priest who had sexually abused him when he was a teen-age altar boy, was placed on probation for three years on Friday. The defendant, Gregory J. Riedle, 26 years old, of St. Paul, was arrested in May, and the police found a butcher knife and a 4-foot-long wooden club in his car.

LEAD: It is now 36 years since the mills of the Alexander Smith & Sons Carpet Company in Yonkers shut down. The factory, founded in 1845, was at its zenith during World War II, when with a work force of 7,000 people, it operated around the clock producing blankets and tents for the United States armed services.
LEAD: When President Bush made his offer to open a free-trade partnership with all of Latin America, President Luis Alberto Lacalle of Uruguay jumped to the telephone and said he would accept.

LEAD: Q. Because our driveway slopes toward the garage and the drain is small, water collects during heavy rains. Also, since the garage floor is uneven, the rubber door bottom does not seal properly and water flows underneath.

Payne of Dallas, was married yesterday in Rosemont, Pa., to Thomas Allen Hyde Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Hyde of Midland, Tex. The Rev. John M. Holt performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd.

LEAD: In the 11 years of Saddam Hussein's presidency, Iraq has produced no heir apparent, no viable domestic opposition, no democratic tradition and no popular leader in exile waiting to return in triumph.

LEAD: Old travel books occupy so many shelves in my apartment that a visitor might take me to be some kind of antiquarian nut. I am merely a travel nut, and the books are artifacts of that hobby. Just looking at their sonorous titles (''Forbidden Sands,'' ''Monsoon Seas,'' ''Dead Cities and Forgotten Tribes,'' ''They Reigned in Mandalay''), I am taken back to places in many parts of the world that I traveled far to see.

LEAD: Shortly after he took over New York City's jails, Allyn R. Sielaff brought in workers to remodel his suite so that a visitor must pass through two reception areas, and two sets of security buzzers, before getting to his corner office.

LEAD: Seekers after mystic signs had to be nonplused the other day when Joseph Volpe, the newly appointed general director of the Metropolitan Opera, made it his first public act to confirm the company's abandonment of a planned Werner Herzog staging of Mozart's ''Zauberflote'' next season. (It will be replaced by a David Hockney production borrowed from the San Francisco Opera.) This might be seen as an evil omen for Mr.
LEAD: Storefront design bubbled with vitality in the 1920's and early 30's as small shops sought an identity amid a rising group of chain operations and department stores.
LEAD: A new program to prepare American Indians for college careers has drawn 50 prospective students to the University of California at Irvine.

LEAD: Francis J. Sugrue, a writer for The New York Herald-Tribune for a quarter-century before the newspaper closed in 1966, died on Friday at the Ozanam Hall of Queens Nursing Home in Bayside. He was 72 years old and had lived in Flushing, Queens.

LEAD: Laurie A. Sappern, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Sappern of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Dean H. Gaugler, a son of Chester F. LEAD: Since the early 1900's a 14-acre peninsula in the west branch of Stamford Harbor has been a boat yard, a boat-building site and a marina, where forests of sailboat masts tower over yachts, speed boats and catamarans.

LEAD: To combat what they consider anti-student legislation passed by city and county officials, the Student Government Association at the University of Maryland has registered more than 800 students this year to vote in the fall county and state elections. And the president of the association, Daniel Cones, vows that it will continue its efforts.

LEAD: Nearly 20 years after Congress declared lead-based paint a health hazard and ordered it stripped from the nation's stock of federally subsidized housing, it remains on the walls and woodwork of dwellings across the nation, posing a lasting toxic threat that medical experts say afflicts as many as one in every six children.

LEAD: In his syndicated comic strip ''Farley,'' the cartoonist Phil Frank recently conjured a vision of the National Endowment for the Arts telling a grant applicant that his work is derivative, trite, pedantic, artless, spineless and the winner of a $2,500 grant.

LEAD: The Merce Cunningham Studio is spacious and looks out on an extraordinary New York skyscape. But it seemed impenetrably dark and cramped on Thursday night when Paula Hunter unfolded the strange, obsessive world of her dances.
LEAD: THE school has said no. The family has cried foul. The doctors -well, they have said different things. And so it appears that for Stephen Larkin, the courts will have the final say.

LEAD: The novels of Fyodor Dostoyevsky pack enough violence, sex and intrigue to make even Tosca blush, but they have inspired surprisingly few operas. Perhaps composers balk at their sheer mass. Or perhaps it's at all those feverish philosophical dialogues on the Essence of Being.

LEAD: The chief criminal investigator for the Internal Revenue Service in New Jersey retired and went to work the same week for George Steinbrenner, who hired him to look for evidence that a charitable foundation set up by Dave Winfield was involved in fraud and misappropriation of funds.

LEAD: Any pitcher who has 21 victories and 4 defeats is obviously having an outstanding season, but Bob Welch's performance grows even more impressive when it is placed in the context of his team's outstanding season.

LEAD: First there was medical imaging - electronic devices that produce video pictures of structures deep within the body using X-rays, sound waves or magnetic resonance techniques. Now there is a way to directly convert these electronic images into high-quality, instant, black and white photographs printed on film.

LEAD: For $2,500 in sweat equity, $1 for a vacant lot and a $1,500 cash contribution, nine families with two or more children and household incomes of at least $22,000 may be able to own their own homes in Hartford by next year. LEAD: THE number of people addicted to drugs or alcohol entering the criminal-justice system on Long Island has increased so rapidly that the agencies treating them are overwhelmed.

LEAD: When the founders of Space Services Inc. built a rocket and named it the Conestoga, they had in mind an image of dogged determination in the face of daunting risk. They never intended their pioneering enterprise to be facing that risk in the financial desert just short of the next watering hole.

LEAD: Tennis fans and players alike will notice some changes at the United States Open, which begins tomorrow at the National Tennis Center in Queens. Chris Evert, now retired, won't be there. And for the first time in over a decade, neither Jimmy Connors nor John McEnroe are among the seeded players. But the biggest and most welcome change will be the absence of the incessant roar of planes.

LEAD: It used to be easy to spot the rockers with good intentions. They had earnest expressions and dull wardrobes, and they put across their messages with an almost puritanical disdain for embellishment, clutching acoustic guitars as talismans of sincerity. A serious song might allow itself a singalong chorus, but it couldn't be seductive or sensual - that might seem too frivolous for important subjects.

LEAD: To the Editor: In Q & A (Travel, June 17) a reader asked about the danger of visiting Kilauea volcano on the island of Hawaii during an eruption. The geologist Christina Heliko of the Hawaiian volcano observatory stated that ''there is nothing to be worried about.''

LEAD: William Neal Moore was not the first murderer to find God on death row, but the sincerity of his conversion was particularly impressive. After appeals on his behalf by Mother Teresa, the Rev. LEAD: When, in the Summer of 1989, I moved from Connecticut to Cambridge, Mass., I found that I had difficulty urinating. I was like Portnoy, in ''Portnoy's Complaint,'' who couldn't fornicate in Israel. I had always wanted to live in Cambridge, and the thought passed through my mind that I couldn't urinate because - like Israel for Portnoy - Cambridge was a transcendent place for me.

LEAD: PUTTING OUT. By Neil Ferguson. (Penguin, Paper, $8.95.) New York - arguably the style capital of the world - is the setting for the English writer Neil Ferguson's ambitious first novel, which turns out to be sometimes promising and brilliant yet often exasperating. In ''Putting Out,'' Mr. Ferguson has taken on a formidable and intriguing topic, the rough and tumble of a New York mayoral campaign complicated by terrorism and murder in the garment district.

LEAD: A wedge of hard-driving bodies moves like a robot battalion in precision drill through ''Rhythm Nation,'' the title song of Janet Jackson's current national tour. Legs chop wide open, then close again. They shoot out abruptly to the sides, then kick into jazz spins and bouncing splits to the floor.

LEAD: Two weeks ago, Prof. William Julius Wilson stood up before 1,500 colleagues and called into question the usefulness of a term that has become a fixture of the American political vocabulary and one that he, more than anyone, helped legitimize: ''the underclass.''
LEAD: A man impersonating a park ranger approached five men who were target shooting in the mountains northwest of here on Friday and, after ordering them to march down a hill, started shooting them.

LEAD: Like other towns much visited by tourists, Chatham, Mass., reveals its many faces only to those who take time to look below the surface. To casual travelers who leave their cars in the public parking lot after surviving the summer traffic jam, a stroll along its gently curving Main Street with elegant low-key shops, restaurants and inns unobtrusively tucked into sea captains' houses, conjures up the picture of Olde New England charm, even when T-shirts are being sold.

LEAD: You don't have to be a romantic to sell men's clothing in Manhattan. But it helps. Consider Alan Flusser, whose recently opened Wall Street-area tailor shop is a florid evocation of old England. There are trellis-patterned carpets, chintz-covered chairs and an old-fashioned sofa in which customers can wallow as they ponder the distinction between a chalk and a pin stripe.

LEAD: Workers building a road in central China appear to have stumbled on an archeological treasure: a 2,100-year-old network of underground vaults said to contain tens of thousands of terra-cotta sculptures buried with a Han Dynasty emperor, during one of the greatest civilizations of ancient times.

LEAD: The mother and stepfather of a University of Texas fraternity member who died here in September 1988 after falling 150 feet from a cliff have filed a $30 million negligence suit against the fraternity.

LEAD: The Dalton School has added another town house to its diverse holdings on the Upper East Side, expanding by one the 91st Street row in which its lower school is conducted. LEAD: Wall Street learned its lesson at 1:13 P.M. on Aug. 13 when traders' computer screens went dead. A fire in a Consolidated Edison substation in lower Manhattan knocked out power to much of the financial district. The blackout served to demonstrate how important it is for companies to have a reliable backup power supply for their computers.

LEAD: Legs have it. The short skirts, leggings, jodhpurs and snug boots that are everywhere prove it. So do the taut bodysuits, dark or dazzling with patterns. Fabrics laced with stretch certainly have it, as do those that smolder to the touch - velvet, cashmere, spongy tweeds, mohairs and meltons. And sequins, paillettes and false gem stones never lost it.

LEAD: Kathleen Turner in the movies - a vocal oasis in a desert of sound. The Voice may be making a comeback. There is some evidence in movies and on television that we are headed toward an aural reawakening. Until Ms. Turner, there had been no distinctive voices in film for decades. In the old days, Katharine Hepburn and Bette Davis and Jimmy Stewart and Cary Grant pleased the ear as well as the eye.

LEAD: Late last month, Chinese fishermen spotted a small oceangoing fishing boat that was stranded and seemed to be in trouble. Upon boarding they discovered the problem: the boat contained 25 corpses and a few more gasping passengers locked in several cabins below deck.

LEAD: Nice, the largest city on the Cote d'Azur, has long had a double personality. It attracts tourists because of its beaches, but it also functions as a cultural center: the Chagall Museum, the Matisse Museum, the Museum of Fine Arts are all proof of this. These institutions, however, are not involved with living art.

LEAD: Under the rustling oak trees at John Hinkel Park, before performances of ''Cymbeline,'' ''Othello'' or ''The Merry Wives of Windsor,'' the audience at the Berkeley Shakespeare Festival is wildly applauding the nightly announcement that the company has refused a Federal grant rather than sign an anti-obscenity pledge.

LEAD: At a time when entrepreneurs from Korea have become New York City's leading food retailers and moved aggressively into other businesses, that country's largest furniture exporter is about to make a foray into the city from an 11-story building it has bought at 315 Fifth Avenue.

LEAD: In the 22d day of November this year, if all goes according to plan, an enigmatic and lonely 56-year-old man who has lived almost all his life in the shadow of his father will leave his modest home for the grounds of the Imperial Palace in downtown Tokyo. At 6:30 P.M., Akihito will bathe, put on white ceremonial robes and enter a shrine in a wooded glade.

LEAD: With German unity finally set for Oct. 3, West German Government officials are moving quickly to insure that resolution of the remaining internal aspects of unification does not turn into a political free-for-all like the dispute over the unification date. LEAD: The number of cows on New York State farms dropped last year to 776,000, the lowest level since the state began to record dairy statistics in 1930, the state Agricultural Statistics Service reported this week.

LEAD: ''This is the most uncomfortable I've ever been in a movie,'' said the actor Johnny Depp between puffs on a cigarette proferred by an assistant on a makeshift roach clip. Mr. Depp was clad in skintight black leather from Adam's apple to toes. His hair was a mass of black tangles, and his face was made up like a mime's, except that it was covered with prosthetic scars.

LEAD: Nancy Reagan may be out of the public eye, but one person who hasn't forgotten her is Terry Sweeney.
LEAD: Although the crisis in the Persian Gulf involves much broader and more crucial issues, it certainly has the potential to affect the sport of auto racing.

LEAD: Another week and another milestone for the dollar. First, the dollar set a new low against the German mark on Aug. 14. Then, last Thursday, it fell to a low against the Swiss franc, 1.2560, and set another low aganst the mark, 1.5444. At the same time, the weary dollar fell further against the three popular high-yield currencies that are backed by high interest rates and are also net energy exporters, making them less vulnerable to the Persian Gulf crisis.

LEAD: The United States and Japan have already traded places in the global financial hierarchy. Long the world's greatest exporter of capital, the United States over the past decade has become a capital importer on a gigantic scale to finance its chronic deficits. Japan's economic surge has made it the world's pre-eminent international creditor.

LEAD: Vacation time is when even serious readers ask, Is there something good and junky I can read? Good and junky are not necessarily opposites, and it is possible to guess what such readers are looking for, or at least what they are not looking for, always bearing in mind Andre Maurois's observation that ''in literature, as in love, we are astonished by what is chosen by others.

LEAD: Visualize a room with plenty of capacious, comfortable, welcoming sofas and chairs, not all of them occupied. In this room there are, too, a few straight-back chairs and someone is sitting in one of them. Someone with a bad back? Wrong guess. This person has a wonderful, healthy, much-to-be envied back.

LEAD: Until recently, people with free-standing fuel-oil storage tanks in their basements or beside their houses did not have to worry about rules designed to avoid environmental contamination. Spills from these above-ground tanks are not likely to seep into ground water or waterways because even a small leak is immediately visible and can be cleaned up before becoming an environmental hazard.

LEAD: TORNADO ALLEY, by Craig Nova. (Delta, $10.95.) Carrying a gun and a cylinder of her father's ashes, Marie Boule escapes from her dreary Pennsylvania hometown and heads for a complicated existence in San Francisco. '' 'Tornado Alley' is the kind of book one takes to the beach or to the mountains for the purpose of total immersion,'' Andrei Codrescu said here last year.

LEAD: Like most other aspects of life in the Soviet Union, bridge has been affected by perestroika. The number of tournament players in Moscow has more than doubled in the past year from 400 to 1,000. The progression is expected to continue.

LEAD: SOMETIMES ground covers other than grass are the best solution to protect bare earth. If soil is not covered with something, weeds move in rapidly. The goal is to plant cover that will establish itself quickly. This is especially true for areas like slopes or heavily shaded patches under mature trees.

LEAD: One of the Chinese Communist Party's proudest accomplishments is that it reunited a nation torn apart by warlords and recreated a central government that could lead the country. That achievement stands, but in these days of economic slowdown, it is somewhat undermined by provinces that are quietly carving up the vast national market into protectionist fiefs.

LEAD: At least one fact has become inescapably clear during the past two weeks. The world cannot afford a continuation of the steady increase in dependence on Persian Gulf oil. Means are available to reverse this trend. We can make our cars, buildings and industry far more fuel-efficient than they are today.

LEAD: Roger Clemens pitched a five-hitter and escaped a bases-loaded jam in the ninth inning today, and Dwight Evans hit a home run as the Boston Red Sox beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 1-0. Boston increased its lead in the American League East to three games over Toronto.

LEAD: Poland is awash in nostalgia this month as the nation revisits those simpler times of a decade ago, when an August strike at the Gdansk shipyard gave birth to the Solidarity union. To Solidarity's leaders, this anniversary has been an occasion for pleasant reminiscenses about the years when their lives were a straightforward morality play: dissidence against
LEAD: If you are fortunate enough to be able to grill a piece of tuna over charcoal, you know that it requires no seasonings at all for spectacular flavor.

LEAD: CHRONICLE OF A REVOLUTION: A Western-Soviet Inquiry Into Perestroika. Edited by Abraham Brumberg. (Pantheon, $24.95.) Just how the Soviet Union will emerge from the tumultuous events that are still shaking that country is still anybody's guess. But ''Chronicle of a Revolution,'' a collection of highly readable, provocative essays edited by Abraham Brumberg, a visiting scholar at Georgetown University, suggests that most of the changes that have swept across the country over the past five years were predictable.

LEAD: As Michael Furze sat in the bar of the elegant Polana Hotel overlooking the Indian Ocean, he could have been forgiven for thinking he was back home in South Africa. His can of beer came from Johannesburg, he was expected to pay in South African rands and the voices of Afrikaans speakers could be heard in the room.

LEAD: A FADED FAMILY photograph from 1944 shows my 6-foot-5 cousin Mel, on Army leave, stooping to hold me, a shy little girl, in my backyard. We are both in uniform: his a handsome olive drab with brass buttons; mine a spiffy ''junior'' WAC uniform in khaki twill with gold bars and braid. The skirt had already been lengthened twice.

LEAD: Amid charges and denials of interference by leaders of the Roman Catholic Church, the student-run Program Board at the Catholic University of America - a committee of one student at the time - has canceled a debate on abortion rights that would have involved Bill Baird, one of the most outspoken proponents of women's access to abortion.

LEAD: As jurors in New York City weighed the fate of three teen-agers charged with the rape and beating of a Central Park jogger, a jury 300 miles to the northwest heard the gruesome details of an attack on another jogger raped and left to die.

LEAD: Elected officials are supposed to put the public good ahead of narrow partisan interests. That is the common-sense reasoning behind a provision in New York City's new Charter that bars key officeholders from holding party jobs. But a disappointing court decision now casts doubt on whether that ban against political moonlighting can be enforced.

LEAD: SUNDAY: Some members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries plan to meet in Vienna. MONDAY: Personal income and expenditures for July. The Treasury auctions three- and six-month bills. TUESDAY: The Treasury auctions two-year notes. WEDNESDAY: Index of leading indicators for July.

LEAD: If Beethoven could hear a CD recording of his music (assuming he returned to this world with his hearing intact) he would probably throw one of his famous fits. The performance would seem to him consistently off key.

LEAD: HONG KONG TASTE, a new Chinese restaurant in Westport (formerly the Beansprout), is a benchmark of sorts: it does not bear the word Sichuan or Hunan in its title, and it presents the dishes of Hong Kong with Parisian flair, in a stylish setting as sophisticated as the presentations. With service as polished as the decor, each platter is set before you as a work of art, before being removed to a side table and dished up in individual servings.
LEAD: The settling of new conference affiliations, ones to resolve the makeup of major-college football in the East for a long time to come, is an important adjunct of the impending season.
LEAD: Country wine. what a beautiful concept. Like a Norman Rockwell painting. Innocence, naivete, freshness; what old-time virtues does it not evoke?

LEAD: The battles have ebbed today in these bleak townships on South Africa's gold-mining reef, where more than 500 people have died. And the lines of competing black factions have been frozen in place by a deployment of the police and soldiers in trucks intended for bush warfare and now imposing a kind of civilian peace.

LEAD: A hostage freed overnight from Lebanon said today he had recently seen three other Western hostages, including the American journalist, Terry A. Anderson, held for more than five years, and that all were well.
LEAD: Collector's Auctions, Ltd. will hold a two-day sale on Sept. 6 and 7. It is one of the largest collections of medals ever offered.

LEAD: Two patrol officers responding to a routine complaint surprised three suspected drug dealers in upper Manhattan early yesterday morning as they walked out of an apartment carrying shopping bags full of cocaine and cash, the police said.

LEAD: IN perhaps his most remarkable reversal of field, Emmitt Smith, the most prolific running back in University of Florida history, has said he is going to spend this fall seeking enlightenment instead of running for daylight.

LEAD: Many closed-end funds are selling at steep discounts these days, offering investors the tantalizing possibility of handsome profits. After all, a discount is a bargain, whether you buy a cartful of groceries or a basket of stocks. But in the arcane world of closed-end funds, some investors are finding that bargains can prove illusory and discounts don't necessarily turn into dollars.

LEAD: Naked Aggression,'' President Bush called the blitzkrieg seizure of Kuwait by Iraq; the United States, he said, had to ''draw a line in the sand'' to defend Saudi Arabia. News analysts called the presence of American troops in the path of Saddam Hussein's ''megalomaniacal and hegemonic'' ambitions a tripwire.

LEAD: THAI food has become commonplace on Long Island, but when the Bangkok Palace opened in Woodmere over five years ago, the restaurant was an exotic trailblazer. This Five Towns pioneer has recently changed ownership and renamed itself New Bangkok Palace.

LEAD: Golf Olazabal Surges On: Jose-Maria Olazabal continued his record-breaking assault on the Firestone Country Club yesterday, shooting a three-under-par 67 for an eight-stroke lead after three rounds of the NEC World Series of Golf in Akron, Ohio. Olazabal's bogey-free round gave him a 54-hole total of 195 and a commanding advantage over Hale Irwin going into the final round today.

LEAD: Bobby Shannon's two-run homer in the fifth inning lifted Shippensburg to a 5-4 victory today over Cypress, Calif., sending the Pennsylvania team into the championship game of the Little League World Series against powerful Taiwan.

LEAD: Crimes of violence up 30 percent in six years. Arrests up 20 percent. Five police officers killed in a year. Court calendars clogged. Citizens arming themselves. Racial tensions at a boil. Critics bewailing a ''carnival of murder.'' So it went in the New York City of the 1860's. Today's alarming crime rate and fearful populace have clear parallels in earlier eras of city history, although historians say they have to go back to the 19th century and earlier to find them.

LEAD: The other day a mysterious message was faxed to offices in the Saudi capital here ostensibly offering advice on how to deal with the deadly effects of chemical weapons. The fax soon became the talk of the town, fueling the already deep-seated worries over Iraq's poison gas capability.

LEAD: Last week, college students began converging on America's campuses for the start of the fall semester. Among them were some four million freshmen. Nowadays, more and more colleges try to make the transition from high school easier with orientation programs. Here are reports from Southern Methodist University and Case Western Reserve University on their programs.

LEAD: Faced with cuts in their budgets for the third consecutive year, the State University of New York and the City University of New York will continue to lose teaching positions, put off repairs and reduce purchases of everything from computers to paper clips, officials of both institutions say.

LEAD: This spring a California man symbolically took his life by using a computer program to seek out and destroy the contributions he had made over the years to a continuing electronic conversation run by a computer group called the Well. Several weeks later, he followed this ''virtual'' suicide by killing himself in the real world.
LEAD: Iraq promised today to release dependents of American diplomats from Kuwait who are being held in Baghdad, but not the diplomats themselves.

LEAD: TRYING to wring residents for every dollar they owe, the state is offering delinquent taxpayers a chance to pay up without penalty. State officials, trying to cope with a budget deficit of at least $200 million, are starting their tax-amnesty program this week, with a warning: ''If you don't pay now, we'll make you pay later.

LEAD: Right to Co-op Documents Question: I am a real estate broker specializing in residential loft sales. The lawyer of a client who is interested in a co-op requested access to the financial records but the board refused to comply. Doesn't Section 624 of the New York Business Corporation Law gives prospective buyers the right to see these documents?
LEAD: The kids don't have .38's anymore. They have Uzis. - Jose Resto, resident of a crime-plagued Bronx community after neighbors stabbed a robbery suspect to death.

LEAD: I was grateful for Ze'ev Chafets's article ''The Tragedy of Detroit'' (July 29). For years I've been mystified by the fact that no one really talks about what's happened there - that this national shame is treated as if it didn't exist.

LEAD: Add team dynamics to the lengthening list of strains to come out of the tumultuous 1980's.

LEAD: THE contract was extended, and so Shane Conlan's season no longer stands to be shortened.

LEAD: ''Why should we do Shakespeare? Shakespeare's already done Shakespeare.'' George Balanchine once made that scornful declaration about the way some choreographers base works on literary classics, including the plays of Shakespeare. However, by choreographing his own ''Midsummer Night's Dream,'' Balanchine himself ''did Shakespeare.
LEAD: MOST people who know me are aware of my fondness for the sport of tennis. I was first introduced to the game more than 40 years ago in Trenton by my good friend Dr. Bill Hayling.

LEAD: So much in commerce and politics hinges on the once-a-decade census that experts by the swarm leap to dissect and interpret even the most incomplete and preliminary data. As a result, the Census Bureau has grown a bit testy on the subject of its accuracy.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: How much is good corporate management worth? A great deal, no doubt, when markets are in upheaval and economic prospects grow cloudier every day; even in sunny times, nobody expects corporate executives to toil for free.

LEAD: DIMMER switches allow adjusting lighting levels; they also save energy and extend the lives of light bulbs. Most often, dimmer switches are used for controlling incandescent ceiling lights. Installing one is easy. The job involves simply replacing the conventional wall switch with the dimmer.

LEAD: Alix Cleveland did not think that climbing to the top could become so routine. But this summer, as one of New York State's first ''summit stewards,'' she climbs 5,344-foot Mount Marcy five days a week.

LEAD: With German unification now only weeks away, the 12-nation European Community has hurriedly drafted a set of provisional measures aimed at smoothing the integration of East Germany's backward economy into this prosperous region.

LEAD: Veterans from the unit that dropped the atomic bombs on two cities in Japan in World War II today dedicated a peace memorial, but they caused a furor when they scratched a Japanese writer off the speaker list for saying the bombings were not necessary.

LEAD: When Nicholas Cammarato, a Brooklyn developer, first saw the neighboring homes of a father and son, Eric and Richard Stockley, on East 23d Street in the Sheepshead Bay section during an exploratory drive through the neighborhood a few years ago, it was not just their Victorian-styled residences that caught his eye.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Norman Burg of Woodstock, N.Y., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Barbara Burg and Steven Schieffelin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Schieffelin of Albany.

LEAD: It's 3 A.M. on Mount Fuji as we grope our way up a massive scree slope in the dark. In this hour of reckoning, thin air and night silence fuse with exertion, exhilaration and lack of sleep. We're high. The objective is to be on top of the sacred peak at sunrise. The trail is indistinct but there's enough light to be aware of the elevation and the infinite black space that is not rock.

LEAD: EVERY family has its share of characters ranging from the stoics to the Pollyannas, the troubled to the troublesome, the heroes to the villains. In my family, I was cast in the role of comedienne.

LEAD: NABISCO BRANDS owns four manufacturing companies, of which the one at East Hanover produces eight of the country's ''top 10'' cookies and crackers. It also maintains an art gallery - the better to warm up the atmosphere of its main building, a ''layer cake'' of concrete and glass that dominates the hill bounded by River Road and DeForest Avenue.

LEAD: West African troops sent to Monrovia to end Liberia's eight-month-old civil war repulsed an attack today by rebels loyal to Charles Taylor, the Ghana news agency reported.

LEAD: Designers are catching on to what the horsy set has long known: that riding clothes are comfortable, stylish and flattering. And they are adapting the look for women's everyday fashions. Epitomizing the equestrian style is one of the pillars of America's horsy society, C.Z. Guest. Known for her skill as an accomplished horsewoman (she rises most mornings at 7:30 for a one-and-a-half-hour ride), Guest has always had an eye for clothing that suits her passion.

LEAD: The oversized shirt, loose and easy, seems perfect for the winding-down days of summer. It is cool and airy on hot and humid days, and can work up a good billow on windier ones.

LEAD: An all-white American Legion post that refused membership to a Vietnam veteran last month because he is black has now agreed to let him re-apply and has adopted a bylaws change that virtually insures he will be accepted.

LEAD: An article on July 22 about Budapest, and an accompanying caption, misidentified the sculptor of a statue of Persephone. As a reader has recently written to point out, he was Benno Elkan, not Benno Elkan Roma.

LEAD: A SCOUTING party has taken to the woods and backroads to mark a trail that will offer, if you are fit and eager, the opportunity to take an eight-month nature walk across the United States. But the purpose for staking out the new path has to do as much with image as reality.
LEAD: Hurricane Gustav spun toward the northeastern Caribbean today with winds of 80 miles per hour.
LEAD: The last meeting of the 92-year-old New York City Board of Estimate should finally come to an end today - nearly two weeks after it began.

LEAD: This summer, residents of this town at the confluence of the Missouri and Yellowstone rivers may have finally hit on a way to combat its oldest problem, mosquitoes, by using natural forms of control: bats and birds.

LEAD: The United Nations Secretary General, who said this weekend that he would personally intervene in the Persian Gulf crisis, is to meet with the Iraqi Foreign Minister on Thursday in Amman, the Jordanian capital, a spokeswoman said today.
