LEAD: Melanie Cohen and Lawrence Greenberg, 1986 magna cum laude graduates of Harvard University, were married yesterday at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A man whose driver's license was taken away because he has epilepsy was charged with homicide after he suffered a seizure while driving and struck and killed a 7-year-old boy, the authorities said.

LEAD: Molly Macklin Fowler, an associate producer for ''The Phil Donohue Show,'' and Jack Levine, a photographer and film maker, were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Rosen, the bridegroom's sister and brother-in-law, in Patterson, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated. The bride, 33 years old and a graduate of the University of Utah, is keeping her name.

LEAD: Is there life after the Merce Cunningham Dance Company? LEAD: Iraqi authorities reportedly entered the Chinese Embassy in Kuwait and tightened their grip on other foreign embassies there today by shutting off their water supply, Administration officials said.

LEAD: The Trump Shuttle plans to become more than a shuttle by expanding its charter flights to the Caribbean and Mexico and by expanding service to Atlantic City in a move to make better use of its fleet and broaden its customer base.

LEAD: A report in the Currents column of The Home Section on Aug. 2 about the Design Review of ID Magazine misidentified a photograph. LEAD: Taiwan returned to business as usual today, topping Shippensburg (Pa.), 9-0, to earn the 14th championship since Taiwan teams began playing in the Little League World Series in 1969.
LEAD: Cox Landey & Partners has won the $8 million to $10 million account for the Tri-State Acura Dealers. The campaign created by the New York agency will begin in October.

LEAD: * Analysis & Technology Inc., North Stonington, Conn., an engineering service, named John P. Cretella a senior vice president.

LEAD: An impending legal battle over prayers at public school graduations has divided Utah residents on religious lines perhaps more sharply than any other issue since efforts to permit liquor served by the drink failed in 1968.

LEAD: The Kellogg Company has filed suit in Federal District Court in Iowa to protect the company's right to make what it says are truthful claims in advertising for its Frosted Flakes, Special K and Bran Flakes cereals.

LEAD: MEL TORME has finished ''Traps, the Drum Wonder,'' his biography of Buddy Rich. The singer started it in 1975, put it aside for his own autobiography and completed the manuscript last month. It has been submitted to publishers by STERLING LORD, who says that one will be chosen by mid-September.
LEAD: Saks Fifth Avenue will build a new 120,000-square-foot store in White Plains, which will replace the chain's existing store there, the company said last week.
LEAD: A huge withdrawal of deposits and the cutting of vital Western and Japanese credit lines have dealt severe blows to the banking systems and economies of the Persian Gulf region.

LEAD: With a flourish of patriotism, the Chrysler Corporation's latest advertising campaign, ''Advantage: Chrysler,'' takes aim at the company's Japanese competitors, but the company is being accused of hypocrisy.

LEAD: Less than two years ago, Arturas Karnishovas did not speak English. He had never heard of Seton Hall University. And he lived in Vilnius, Lithuania, which is a long way from New Jersey both geographically and culturally.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: TO those who follow professional bowling, Earl Anthony is a household name - the name, of course, of bowling's first $1 million man, the winner of 41 tournaments in a 14-year-career that ended, for the first time, in 1983.

LEAD: EIGHT blocks from Mexico City's ancient central plaza and historic cathedral is a major shopping district. The streets are as packed with shoppers as Fifth Avenue in New York before Christmas. The shops are mostly makeshift sidewalk stalls, but they display a huge variety of clothing, shoes, household wares, toys and electronic products.
LEAD: Looking a little like a high-rise construction project, three tall trees stand surrounded by scaffolding here in an experiment to gauge damage to them from the pollutant ozone.

LEAD: The Boston Red Sox swept to a third straight shutout for the first time in 28 years and increased their largest lead of the season in the American League East to four games today, beating Toronto, 1-0, on a combined two-hitter by Greg Harris and Jeff Gray.

LEAD: New York City's Board of Estimate, due to die on Sept. 1 under the new City Charter, in its protracted final session last week reached acceptable compromises on four disputed matters. A last issue remains for today.

LEAD: The greater Bay Area, with San Francisco to the west and Berkeley to the east, is generally considered so philosophically far from the Bible Belt that some might argue it constitutes an emotionally different country.

LEAD: Microchip Technology Inc., a semiconductor manufacturer based in Chandler, Ariz., has named Steve Sanghi president and chief operating officer. He has been vice president for operations of Microchip, a privately held company that was spun off by the General Instrument Corporation in September 1987.

LEAD: In the struggle to revive America's schools, the news is bittersweet. Despite growing evidence that more and better qualified people are choosing teaching, educators say there are nowhere near enough of them.
LEAD: The group of gypsies had gathered for an evening of poetry and song, and their language and music bounced out over the audience, round and strong, full of dark tones and hissing sounds.

LEAD: Sikh gunmen raided the home of a police interrogator in Punjab on Saturday and killed four members of his family, the police said today. Elsewhere in the state, eight deaths on Saturday were attributed to Sikh militants who are leading a violent campaign for an independent homeland, news reports said.
LEAD: AN event that may provide some excitement along with a lot of fun and good eating will take place in Crisfield, Md., Labor Day weekend.

LEAD: Shock waves from the crisis in the Persian Gulf are rippling through Brazil's economy, swelling the bill on oil imports, threatening an anti-inflation program, deepening a recession and freezing a close trade relationship with Iraq.

LEAD: As the U.S. moves closer to military confrontation in the Middle East, people are beginning to wonder how long the American public will support the enterprise. Historical experience suggests a few answers.
LEAD: The second-half surge of the Yankees has been one built for the most part on the youthful strength of players like Kevin Maas, Oscar Azocar and Jim Leyritz.

LEAD: Francine Amy Kravetz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Kravetz of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Pepe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene N. Pepe of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. Mrs. Pepe, 25 years old and a graduate of Boston University, is a registered sales assistant at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Consumer Markets in White Plains.

LEAD: The Israeli military announced its first tangible involvement in the gulf crisis today by saying it will begin blocking exports of Palestinian-produced fruits, vegetables and other items shipped through Jordan to Iraq.

LEAD: Washington budget summit negotiators have been engaged in a political tug of war over which taxes to raise to pay for the savings and loan bailout. LEAD: Summer is ending soon, but the lure of the beach remains strong -especially for magazine readers.
LEAD: Dr. R. Caird Watson, a radiologist and chairman of the medical-imaging department at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, died there on Thursday. He was 61 years old.

LEAD: When houses and apartments were selling in days or weeks during the mid-1980's, real-estate closings were the bread and butter of many law practices in the New York metropolitan region. Some lawyers conducted hundreds of closings a year, collecting from $750 to $1,000 for each one.

LEAD: For nearly a decade, followers of Elizabeth Clare Prophet have come to the spectacular Upper Yellowstone Valley, drawn by the woman they call Guru Ma. LEAD: The tendency for women to continue working out while they are pregnant has prompted Avia, the athletic footwear company, to design a special line of fitness clothing for mothers-to-be.
LEAD: THE Durham Bulls, undaunted by cinematic fame and unprecedented attendance levels, are continuing their efforts to lead the renaissance of minor league baseball in the United States.

LEAD: A freight train with no one aboard started up and traveled more than 15 miles and as fast as 35 miles an hour on Saturday before an engineer hopped aboard and halted it, the police said. Railroad crossing lights, which are normally activated by train engineers, were not working so the police blocked crossings with patrol cars.

LEAD: Confronted with a fragile economy and haunted perhaps by the slide of the 1970's, consumers in the New York region are cutting spending and delaying purchases in a display of frugality that seems likely to make the slump worse.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said Friday that an engine parts shortage would force it to extend a two-week shutdown of its Dearborn assembly plant for another two weeks, until Sept. 10. Initially, the factory, which makes Mustang automobiles, was closed because of a shortage of dealer orders. The shutdown this week was attributed to the parts shortage.

LEAD: United Airlines will increase its air freight rates 5.3 percent on all domestic flights effective Oct. 1 to cover rising jet fuel costs, the airline announced Friday. United will also impose a 5.3 percent fuel surcharge on passenger flights, beginning at the end of August.

LEAD: The job is daunting and she knows it. Barbara J. Sabol, New York City's new Human Resources Administrator, is struggling -some say without success - to nudge a mammoth bureaucracy not known for compassion into being more responsive to the city's most vulnerable citizens.

LEAD: Morley Callaghan, a Canadian writer who lived in Paris in the 1920's and mixed with Ernest Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald, died Saturday, his son Barry said today. He was 87 years oldandlived in Toronto. The cause of death was not disclosed.

LEAD: The historic Treaty Oak, a centuries-old tree that was poisoned with a powerful herbicide early last year, will be severely pruned later this year in an effort to save it, the city forester says. The pruning will leave only one living section, he said. The tree is supposedly where Stephen F. Austin, founder of the American colony in the Mexican territory of Texas, signed a treaty with the Indians.

LEAD: * Young & Rubicam bought a minority share of Javelin, a Dublin advertising agency, which will be renamed Javelin/Young & Rubicam. The agency's billings are about $3 million.

LEAD: EARLY morning. A businessman recovering from back surgery works through his water-therapy routine in his backyard pool. Across town at the Y.M.C.A., a marathoner runs in the shallow end of the pool to vary his road-running routine. In an apartment nearby, a ballerina reads the morning paper as she moves her sprained ankle up and down, then in circles, in a large bucket of ice water.
LEAD: In his eighth month on the job, Mayor David N. Dinkins finally seems to have met a man he doesn't like.

LEAD: A top United States military official said today that the Saudi Arabian Government is providing the bulk of the fuel, transportation, food and installations for the thousands of American soldiers sent here.

LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools dropped by 11.9 percent in July, according to a monthly report by the Association for Manufacturing Technology. Economists said the figures showed that the nation's economy had begun slowing before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

LEAD: GOLF Olazabal Wins by 12: Jose-Maria Olazabal started out with consecutive birdies yesterday and went on to a 12-stroke victory in the World Series of Golf in Akron, Ohio, shooting 18-under-par 262. The 24-year-old Spaniard's edge was the largest margin in 15 years on the PGA Tour. After going 12 in front on the second hole, Olazabal turned the last round into a victory lap over the Firestone Country Club course, which he dominated as no one ever had.

LEAD: Suzanne Elizabeth Mumma, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Mumma of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William Edward Hegarty Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hegarty of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Joseph deSantos performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: Former United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., an independent running for governor, has enjoyed nothing less than a political honeymoon for the last six months. He has held wide leads in all public opinion polls. His campaign has been gentlemanly and issue-oriented. He also has been successful at raising funds, frequently attracting the news media and collecting endorsements from Democrats and
LEAD: The all-white Selma Country Club has reversed itself and extended membership to a Japanese businessman barred last month amid lingering ill feelings about World War II.
LEAD: In their 17-7 exhibition loss to the Giants on Saturday night, the Jets lost their most experienced player on defense when Marty Lyons suffered a torn right bicep muscle.
LEAD: Not too long ago, The National Mortgage News could not give away its reports about the savings and loan crisis.

LEAD: Max Gordon, an architect internationally known for his mastery of exhibition spaces, both public and private, died on Friday in London, where he lived. He was 59 years old.
LEAD: The Coast Guard found a yacht that had been crippled in rough seas southwest of Guam and sent a patrol boat today to tow the boat and its crew to safety, officials said.
LEAD: Carlos Menem, the Peronist who as President has startled Argentines with frugal government and plans for an open-market economy, has encountered a sort of Catch-22 in his attack on inflation.

LEAD: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that unreasonable demands by militant Mohawk Indians may force the Canadian Government to send in the army to end six-week-old standoffs at two places in Quebec.

LEAD: A police officer accidentally shot his partner in the leg last night when they attempted to halt a dispute between two tenants at an apartment building in Jamaica, Queens, and were attacked by a pit bull, the police said.

LEAD: Randi Michele Justus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Justus of East Northport, L.I., was married yesterday to Howard Keith Simon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Simon of Jericho, L.I. Cantor Marvin Antosofsky performed the ceremony at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I.
LEAD: The Pentagon disbanded its Persian Gulf news media pool today, saying it was no longer needed because open coverage was now being permitted.

LEAD: Runners Left Stranded Q. When the Dodgers beat the Atlanta Braves, 5-4, a month ago in Los Angeles, they left 25 players on base in the 12-inning game. What team holds the mark for runners left on in a regulation game of nine innings? A. The National League mark is 18, shared by nine teams going all the way back to Boston in 1897 and a short trip back to Atlanta in 1986, also in a game against the Dodgers.

LEAD: America is about to enhance its reputation as a nation of immigrants, and not just for tired, huddled masses. Legislation moving through Congress would increase the number of immigrants, making it easier for families to unite and for businesses to recruit skilled workers. This first major overhaul of legal immigration in 25 years would be as welcome as it is overdue.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The week before Labor Day is normally one of Wall Street's slowest periods. But with the Persian Gulf crisis becoming increasingly volatile, the atmosphere in the financial markets will hardly be holiday-like in the coming days.

LEAD: As the closing tribute to Charles Mingus on the 10th anniversary of his death, several pop musicians have recorded his works. ELVIS COSTELLO sings the lead song, ''Weird Nightmare,'' on the album of the same name to be released at the end of the year on A & M Records. Other performers include SONNY ROLLINS, KEITH RICHARDS and CHARLIE WAT

LEAD: The Federal Election Commission has sued a Republican Party fund-raising organization, charging that in 1986 the group illegally gave Republican senatorial candidates more than $2 million raised through solicitation letters signed by Vice President George Bush.
LEAD: An armed-robbery suspect was shot and critically wounded and three other supects arrested by police officers in a Times Square grocery last night, the police said.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday headed Washington at Work, about Representative Joe Moakley, referred incorrectly in some copies to the late Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador. The Archbishop was not a leader of the Arena Party; the party was organized after he was assassinated in 1980 by a gunman who was later linked to a current party leader.

LEAD: Several hundred rioters tonight stormed the headquarters of Bulgaria's Socialist Party, the country's former Communist Party, to protest the continued presence of Communist symbols in public places throughout the country.

LEAD: It is only fitting that the tightest and most competitive race of the Saratoga meeting will probably turn out to be the one that decides the riding title.
LEAD: The television season doesn't start until Sept. 17, but last week was a kind of phony war anticipating the competition to come.

LEAD: Allison B. Greenhut, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald N. Greenhut of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday to James P. Godman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Godman of New York. Rabbi Dov Lerner performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation.

LEAD: Rebels killed a prominent political activist and his 8-year-old son today as the family took a drive outside the capital, the police said. Arturo Pacheco, a member of the Aprista party of former President Alan Garcia Perez, was killed by a dynamite charge that was placed on his chest after the assailants stopped the car, officers said.
LEAD: THE name is J. C. Penney, but the advertising portrays a style-conscious retailer that is sort of a Saks Fifth Avenue for the masses.

LEAD: STEFAN EDBERG, the world's new No. 1 tennis player and for the longest time the most prolific shrinking violet on the men's tour, swiveled and swayed on the first tee of the Fresh Meadows Country Club last week as he got set to play host to a celebrity golf tournament.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to bill and note auctions, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. Tomorrow there will be an auction of new two-year notes and on Wednesday an auction of new five-year notes.

LEAD: Publishing used to be about trust. But today, the old relationships between authors and publishers have given way to growing differences over the contracts that define the business ties between them.

He was 81 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens. He died of a cerebral hemorrhage, his son Paul said. Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach performed the ceremony at the James House in North Tarrytown, N.Y. Mrs. Amiel, 29 years old, graduated from Boston University and is an account supervisor at DCA Advertising in New York.
LEAD: Osel Tendzin, the first Westerner to lead an international Tibetan Buddhist sect, died Saturday, members of the religious group said today. He was 47 years old.
LEAD: * Robin Davenport has been appointed senior vice president of Sudler & Hennessey, a New York agency.

LEAD: Dale Caryn Reyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Reyer of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Jonathan Mondschein, a son of the late Saul Mondschein and the late Gloria Mondschein Warshaw and the adoptive son of Milton Warshaw of New York. Rabbi Robert S. Widom and Cantor Henry Weintraub officiated at the DeSeversky Conference Center in Old Westbury, L

LEAD: A small red-and-green Viking boat, a kayak in the shape of a beer bottle and a lobster boat that looked a lot like a small brown bathtub were part of an unseaworthy armada that sloshed about on the Hudson River yesterday afternoon during New York City's strangest annual regatta.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: STARTING a varsity football program can be difficult, especially at a small commuter school like Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn., which doesn't even have a football field.

LEAD: Naomi Anne Super, a doctoral candidate in materials science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Jesse Mackenzie Fried, a Harvard University law student, were married yesterday at Congregation Shaarei Tefilla in Las Vegas, Nev. Rabbi Abner Weiss officiated.

LEAD: The star of the proceedings at the Federal Reserve's annual summer retreat, dedicated this year to a discussion of central banking in Eastern Europe, turned out to be the Finance Minister of Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Klaus.

LEAD: SIR PETER HALL is not looking back, his untimely resignation on Aug. 7 as artistic director of the Glyndebourne Festival Opera notwithstanding. He will direct ''The Homecoming'' in London in October to celebrate the 60th birthday of his pal, HAROLD PINTER. Sir Peter first directed the play 25 years ago, which won a Tony award on Broadway.

LEAD: So far, the chief critics of President Bush's bold military action in the Middle East are not liberals but conservatives such as Patrick Buchanan, Robert Novak and Edward Luttwak - yesterday's most redoubtable hawks and interventionists. Strange new world! The sudden disappearance of the cold war has pulled the rationale out from under the internationalist foreign policy that America has pursued for 40 years.

LEAD: The first major-label album by the Geto Boys, a rap group from Houston, was withdrawn last week on the eve of its release because its distributor, Geffen Records, would not endorse its explicitly violent and sexual lyrics.

LEAD: The United Automobile Workers is expected to name the General Motors Corporation on Tuesday as its ''negotiation target'' in talks covering half a million industry workers in the United States, just two weeks after the No. 1 auto maker granted concessions to strikers in Flint, Mich.

LEAD: The Dinkins administration scrambled yesterday to prevent a new boycott of a Korean-owned grocery in Brooklyn from resembling the bitter protests against another Korean-owned store in the borough, the Family Red Apple.
LEAD: A jury decided against awarding money today to Eugene Hasenfus, whose plane was shot down in Nicaragua while he was flying supplies to the contras.

LEAD: Tens of thousands of South African blacks stayed away from work today to commemorate the deaths of 515 people in factional clashes over the last two weeks that have drawn widespread accusations of police bias against the African National Congress.

LEAD: In a move destined to make air bags as common in cars as seat belts are now, the General Motors Corporation said today that it would install the bags on the driver's side in all its cars built in the United States starting in the fall of 1995.

LEAD: A steep $4-a-barrel drop in oil prices and what traders saw as a slight easing of tension in the Persian Gulf served as a tonic to the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose sharply and interest rates fell.

LEAD: A table with an article on Saturday about preliminary figures from the new census misstated the 1980 population and preliminary 1990 count for Oklahoma, and in some copies misstated the Census Bureau's 1990 estimate for the District of Columbia.

LEAD: Someone poured gasoline outside Sgt. Johnnie Peters's home at a defunct Nike missile site here last week in another expression of vandalism and hostility surrounding a plan to turn the old military base and its 36 bungalow-style homes into a project for the homeless.

LEAD: Precious metals prices plunged yesterday, with gold bullion posting its biggest one-day drop since early 1983. Platinum and silver prices also dropped, as investors and traders who bought bullion in reaction to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait on Aug. 2 sought to unload their holdings.
LEAD: Mary Papajohn Haris, vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in Manhattan. She was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A report released by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights asserts that the Government of Zaire has engaged in a ''systematic pattern of abuses'' that includes arbitrary arrests and beatings, banishment of political opponents and severe restrictions on freedoms of speech and the press.

Tisch, who is also the president of CBS Inc., has acquired a 7.92 percent stake in Champion International Corp. for $204 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Loews said it had acquired the shares of the paper products company based in Stamford,

LEAD: Scientists have identified the chemicals that produce underarm odor, they reported at a meeting here today. The culprits are two forms of a chemical that produces odors when exposed to certain bacteria.
LEAD: Junior Seau, the San Diego Chargers' top draft choice, became a reluctant millionaire yesterday, signing a five-year, $4.5 million contract that left him feeling underpaid.

LEAD: The decision of William A. Wilson, the head of the United Technologies Corporation's Carrier Corporation unit, to take early retirement next spring has cleared the way for 41-year-old Karl J. Krapek to add another famous industrial name to his resume.
LEAD: A good samaritan was shot and killed early yesterday when he tried to intervene after a robbery, the police said.
LEAD: Reggie Rembert, who became expendable before the opening of training camp, was traded today to the Cincinnati Bengals as the Jets cleared up their contract squabbles.

LEAD: IN the last 10 years, scientists and engineers have taken long strides toward the day when alternative energy sources can compete with oil from the Middle East, and some of the more promising alternatives are on the verge of practicality.
LEAD: MANY corporate managers in charge of quality control may be talking to the wrong people, says Dale Winston, president of Battalia and Associates Inc., a management recruiting firm.
LEAD: Reflecting a further tightening of credit conditions for commercial borrowers, the Federal Reserve Board said today that the nation's banks had increased restrictions on lending since May.

LEAD: Spurred by an ambitious American entrepreneur, a tiny South Pacific kingdom has started what amounts to a turf battle in space that could affect the future control of satellite communications between Asia and the United States.

LEAD: The average verbal skills of college-bound high school seniors declined to their lowest level in a decade and the average mathematics skills showed no improvement, according to college admissions test data to be released today by the College Board, which administers the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

LEAD: American Airlines Inc. today accused United Airlines Inc. of misleading passengers in the Chicago market by filing false schedule information. In a lawsuit filed in Federal court in Fort Worth, American said United schedules that take effect Oct. 1 reflect an as yet unapproved deviation from Federal guidelines governing takeoffs and landings at O'Hare International Airport.

LEAD: Jordanian officials and others expressed hope today that Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations could create a breathing space in the Persian Gulf crisis where diplomacy might, at least for now, take center stage.

LEAD: The Board of Estimate died yesterday in much the manner that it lived for more than nine decades: with a series of protracted behind-the-scenes maneuverings, an emotional head-butting with the public and a quick vote. In the end, a 7-to-4 vote approved a United Parcel Service proposal to expand a sorting plant in lower Manhattan by up to a million square feet.

LEAD: In Presidential elections, California is regarded as a showdown state. But in Presidential primaries, Calfornia hardly shows up. The reason the most populous state has so little to say about who runs is simple: California's primary is held in June, after nearly all other states have voted and the race in both parties has largely been decided.
LEAD: FOR anyone who often deals with matters of interest - interest on money, that is - PercentEdge can be a great timesaver.
LEAD: For the first time in 20 years, the Conservative Party and its candidate for governor are waging a serious statewide campaign with the goal of making deep inroads into the Republican vote.

LEAD: Charles H. Keating Jr., the chairman of the American Continental Corporation, former operator of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, resigned on Friday, a lawyer for Mr. Keating has said.
LEAD: Meadow Star won the Spinaway Stakes and Chris Antley won the riding title as the 122d season of racing reached the finish line today at Saratoga.
LEAD: Osel Tendzin, the first Westerner to lead an international Tibetan Buddhist sect, died Saturday at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center here. He was 47 years old.

LEAD: Hadar Polak was ambling past a bicycle rack, looking like a primitive astronaut in the plastic chemical warfare protection suit he was demonstrating, when a friend drove past and shouted at him, ''Don't publicize our factory too much, or we'll be Saddam Hussein's No. 1 target!''

LEAD: The premiere of a work by Robert DeCormier, a festival of antiphonal and liturgical music and a performance of the Bach B-minor Mass are among the highlights of the New York Choral Society's 1990-91 season. The group will sing three concerts, each to be conducted by its music director, John Daly Goodwin.

LEAD: Every visitor to this mountainous park is warned not to approach or feed the grizzly bears. But the other night 180 paying customers at the daily Western cookout at Yancey's Hole got a rare close-up glimpse of a grizzly, and promptly abandoned their meals to him.

LEAD: After a night of violence that left much of their party headquarters in ashes, about 15,000 undaunted backers of the Bulgarian Socialist Party, this country's renamed Communist Party, rallied in Sofia's main square this evening against what their party leaders called ''newborn neo-fascism.''
LEAD: For the moment Joe Morris is still a Giant, and Ottis Anderson is one, too. ''Yes, I survived,'' Morris said today at his locker-room stall in Giants Stadium.
LEAD: Federal securities regulators began an administrative action today against a Florida man accused of selling more than $4 million in unregistered or risky securities.

LEAD: Charges of simple assault filed against two Los Angeles Dodger players after a scuffle with a bartender at a nightclub in Pittsburgh were withdrawn yesterday after an out-of-court settlement was reached.

LEAD: Although the management of the Philadelphia Orchestra, still enmeshed in its labor negotiations, will neither comment nor confirm, it seems likely that shortly after Labor Day, Wolfgang Sawallisch will be named to succeed Riccardo Muti as the orchestra's music director.

LEAD: The Mets were back home yesterday beating the bushes for a hitter to energize a comatose offense. But they were physically hurt and artistically scarred, and admitted they were worried about their chances of catching the Pittsburgh Pirates in the last 37 games of the season.

LEAD: Imports of steel into the United States fell by 9 percent in the first half of 1990, chiefly because of lower shipments from Japan, Western Europe and Brazil, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today.

LEAD: Egypt is eager for a breakthrough but skeptical that King Hussein will find a formula that will persuade Iraq to move toward an early withdrawal of its troops from Kuwait, diplomats here said today.

LEAD: The new spirit of unanimity at the United Nations reflects an emerging partnership between the two superpowers at the end of the cold war era. But it also affirms a basic principle of international relations: collective action works when national interests coincide. Sweeping Security

LEAD: Negotiations continued today between the Giants and Lawrence Taylor's agent. But agreement on a contract extension for the holdout All-Pro outside linebacker did not seem imminent, although both sides indicated that could change quickly.

LEAD: Msgr. Thomas J. Gillhooly, a former dean at Seton Hall University and a retired priest, died on Saturday at Newton (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old and had lived in Sparta, N.J., since retiring in 1987.

LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday overturned a $148.8 million judgment awarded to the Liggett Group, the cigarette maker, against the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation. Liggett had accused its larger rival of predatory pricing intended to kill its business.
LEAD: At the combined Joint Information Bureau the sign-up sheets for today's press activities have long been filled.

LEAD: Facing a Federal deadline to stop dumping sewage sludge into the ocean by the end of 1991, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors today authorized a $3.5 million plan to study building a plant to process sludge for burial in landfills.
LEAD: In a bid to lure local investors, the Montreal Expos reached a $23 million agreement with Labatt's Brewery for television rights over the next five years.
LEAD: George Steinbrenner signed his resignation a week ago yesterday and tendered it the next day, leaving Yankee Stadium in other hands for the first time since 1972.
LEAD: President Bush said today the Voice of America television station aimed at Cuban viewers has passed a five-month preliminary test and will become a permanent operation.
LEAD: The German mark, the currency of the soon-to-be-united Germanys, is rivaling the dollar in its pre-eminent role in the world economy.

LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday announced three real estate mortgage investment conduit security offerings totaling more than $2 billion. LEAD: WITH circulation down, publishers of many of the nation's best-known magazines are grappling with ways to keep the bad news from further scaring off skittish advertisers.

LEAD: The United Nations Secretary General said today that when he meets in Jordan this week with the Iraqi Foreign Minister he will seek ''full implementation'' of Security Council resolutions calling for the full withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait.

LEAD: Trade embargoes have often proved feeble instruments of coercion. Those who favor quick military action against Iraq argue that the present blockade won't work, or will take many months to bite. They may prove right.

LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

LEAD: Facing billions of dollars in cleanup costs it can hardly afford, New York City has undertaken an aggressive legal and regulatory effort to preserve its high-quality drinking water, which is increasingly threatened by pollution.

LEAD: ''Usually I have one good tournament a year. A lot depends on the opponents' play.'' That was how Lev Alburt explained his winning the 1990 United States Championship, which ran from Aug. 5 to 16 at the Jacksonville Hotel in Jacksonville, Fla.
LEAD: Thurman Thomas, who led the National Football League in total yards from scrimmage last season, agreed to a contract extension yesterday evening with the Buffalo Bills and ended his holdout.

LEAD: Nigerian warships have captured a gunboat carrying weapons for a Liberian rebel group, a spokesman for the West African forces trying to impose a cease-fire said today.
LEAD: BellSouth Enterprises and the Celltelco Nationwide Paging Partnership announced plans today to begin a joint nationwide paging service.

LEAD: Every Sunday, tens of thousands of Filipino women stream into the heart of Hong Kong, filling the park in front of City Hall and spilling out along the sidewalks beneath the stylish skyscrapers and luxury hotels.

LEAD: With a crowd gathered around him tonight in the Yankee clubhouse, Andy Hawkins said he would not attempt to dissect what has been a season of inconsistency and frustration. If he did, he might never find an answer.
LEAD: Britons held hostage by Iraq appeared on Iraqi television today, addressing the camera with assurances to their families.

LEAD: Even before an unpredicted tempest touched down and saturated the United States Open yesterday afternoon, forcing the defending women's champion, Steffi Graf, to make an inelegant scurry from her first-round match on the stadium court, opening day had offered up a controversy, an upset, and the first assault by heat prostration, the event's perennial plague.
LEAD: While the cat suit, or stretch bodysuit, is heralded as the base for the ''easy'' modern wardrobe, many women are discovering drawbacks to one-piece dressing.

LEAD: A jury in Covington, Ky., cleared two St. Louis Cardinal players yesterday of disorderly-conduct charges stemming from a brawl May 19 at a service station.

LEAD: Stevie Ray Vaughan, one of the leading blues and rock guitarists of his generation, came from obscurity to enjoy a meteoric success in the early 1980's. Mr. Vaughan was a technical virtuoso who played with lightning speed and was a master of the explosive sound effects that had been pioneered by Jimi Hendrix, one of the most significant of many influences on his playing.

LEAD: The city of Detroit, which lost the Formula One auto race through its downtown streets in 1988, lost the race that replaced it for the last two years when Championship Auto Racing Teams voted this past weekend to drop the event from its 1991 Indy-car schedule.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The borderline between politics and political theater is crossed with polemical results in ''Indecent Materials,'' two one-act plays that opened last night at the Public Theater. The plays, one dealing with AIDS, the other with Senator Jesse Helms's attack on the National Endowment for the Arts, come to New York from the Manbites Dog Theater Company of Durham, N.C.

LEAD: Exxon will spend $2.8 million to upgrade environmental safeguards at its Bayonne refinery to settle a 1989 lawsuit brought against the company for fouling the Kill Van Kull, officials said yesterday.

LEAD: On his last night in the small village of Ballybeg, Ireland, 25-year-old Gareth O'Donnell sits at tea with his father, a sad, uncommunicative man with whom Gar has been trying unsuccessfully to connect all his life. On the morrow, Gar is leaving Ireland, escaping the failure of his old world for the hope of a new life with his aunt in Philadelphia.
LEAD: The possibilities seem infinite, the waiting interminable, and the worst scenario frightening: to be left out, alone.

LEAD: TRACK AND FIELD A Record 3 in a Row for Mota Rosa Mota of Portugal fought off Valentina Yegorova of the Soviet Union yesterday and won the gold medal in the women's marathon for a record third consecutive time at the European championships at Split, Yugoslavia. The 32-year-old Mota, world and Olympic champion, opened a big lead from the start, but had to fight to stay ahead of Yegorova late in the 26-mile-385-yard race.

LEAD: The price of oil for October delivery tumbled $4 yesterday, to $26.91 a barrel, as commodity traders reacted to an apparent easing of tensions in the Persian Gulf and the possibility that some OPEC members would increase production. The decline of 12.9 percent was the largest daily selloff in the crude oil futures markets in four years.

LEAD: A surprising, fast-moving line of thunderstorms swept across the New York metropolitan area yesterday afternoon, disrupting traffic, causing a number of injuries and bringing the area within a fraction of its normal quota of rain for the year. More thunderstorms were forecast for today.
LEAD: A St. John's University dean said yesterday that she would not reinstate six suspended students until charges that they sexually assaulted another student are resolved.

LEAD: Ellis Burks became the second player in Red Sox history to hit two home runs in one inning and Mike Boddicker extended Boston's shutout streak to 33Z innings in a 12-4 victory tonight over the Cleveland Indians.

LEAD: Meticulous, clear, lovers of light, the French hide somewhere a lust for exaggeration. It is less advertised today, in a time when conservation at the gas tank and light socket is a virtue and grandeur for its own sake a sin of taste.

LEAD: James Galanos designs for wealthy women who go to luncheons and cocktail parties, dine at the finest restaurants and are invited to the best parties. His clothes are rarely seen in business offices. It isn't only because of the five-figure price tags, although they are daunting to all but the highest-paid executives.

LEAD: The manufacturer of the Army's main combat radio, E-Systems Inc., pleaded guilty today to conspiring to defraud the Government by falsifying test results on the radios. It agreed to pay $4.65 million in fines and restitution to settle the civil and criminal charges.

LEAD: In two weeks, a handful of American pairs will go into action in the semifinal stage of the World Women's Pairs in Geneva. Among them is likely to be the New York partnership of Jacqui Mitchell and Amalya Kearse, who won the title four years ago in Miami Beach.

LEAD: Iraq has reversed orders to its merchant ships, instructing them not to resist if American or other naval forces try to board the vessels for inspections as part of the international blockade, United States officials said today.

LEAD: IN the first debt-for-nature swap that cancels both trade debt and bank debt, the Central Bank of Madagascar has agreed to allow a private conservation group to pay $5 million of the Government's international debt in exchange for a commitment to try to save Madagascar's unique and endangered plants and animals.
LEAD: A teen-ager was charged today in a robbery spree that began when he reportedly stole a car and ended after he was tracked down by a police dog, Suffolk County authorities said.

LEAD: * Apple Bancorp shareholders have until Sept. 4 to tender their common shares for $38 a share under the offer whose deadline was extended yesterday by the investor Stanley Stahl.

LEAD: Gasoline prices rose more than a nickel a gallon at the pump in the last two weeks in a jump attributed to the effects of the Persian Gulf crisis, the Lundberg survey has found. LEAD: A United Airlines jumbo jet with 323 people aboard skidded to a safe emergency landing today at Los Angeles International Airport when it was unable to get its front landing gear down, the authorities said. The passengers and crew safely evacuated the Boeing 747 by the emergency chutes. The aircraft was on approach when the crew notified the tower it was unable to get the landing gear down, said Fred O'Donnell, spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.

LEAD: THE narrow, twisting road down to Peter Cox's house at the end of Indian Point in this little community is like a path back to another era. It dips and winds between salt marshes on one side and the long reach of Sagadahoc Bay on the other. The tang of the ocean is all around, and when the car stops to let an ancient truck cross an even more ancient bridge, the clean smell of the tide drifts through the window, mingling with the fragrance of balsam fir from the woods and rock roses along the shore.

LEAD: The New York investor Julian H. Robertson Jr. has acquired a 5.1 percent stake in the Georgia Gulf Corporation, an Atlanta-based chemical company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Robertson said he had bought the shares as an investment.

LEAD: Floundering like a fish out of water on a hot, dry day, Stefan Edberg found himself quickly ambushed and ultimately hogtied on the Stadium Court at the United States Open yesterday as he was defeated, 6-3, 7-6, 6-2, by Aleksandr Volkov, an unheralded baseliner who wears the No. 3 ranking back home in the Soviet

LEAD: An 8-year-old girl, two women and a man were struck by shotgun pellets fired yesterday by men trying to rob a Brooklyn grocery, the police said. Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman, said two or three men entered the store at 39 Mott Avenue in the Brownsville section about 5:30 P.M. One man man fired a shotgun, striking a 46-year-old man in the groin, a 33-year-old woman in the stomach and a 27-year-old woman in the leg.

LEAD: As American soldiers mobilize in the Saudi Arabian desert, hundreds of American companies are mobilizing in their own way to deliver to the armed forces everything from bullets to bug spray. While no one is hoping for a war, many companies have a chance to reap unexpected profit from the military buildup.
LEAD: An Annual Delectation

LEAD: Peter S. Kalikow, owner of the financially beleaguered New York Post, has called a meeting next week with leaders of the paper's unions to request significant cost cuts that he says are needed to avoid the possibility of closing the paper.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Old Republic International Corporation announced yesterday that A. C. Zucaro had been appointed chief executive of the insurance holding company based in Chicago. Mr. Zucaro, 51, succeeds William R. Stover, 67, who had served as chief executive for the last 14 years.

LEAD: Two little-noticed provisions of the cable television franchise contract passed by New York City in June will likely banish nearly all sexually explicit programming, a much-debated broadcast feature in the city for 14 years, from television sets in Manhattan.

LEAD: The eight-month-old civil war in nearby Liberia is threatening to become a wider conflict as neighboring West African countries begin to take opposing sides, African and Western diplomats said today.

LEAD: Almost seven years after a New York law ordered Long Island to close most landfills by the end of 1990, a third of the Island's towns and cities do not know how they will meet the approaching deadline.

LEAD: Shares of the Oracle Corporation, a leading producer of data base management software, fell today in heavy trading after the company restated its earnings for three quarters in its fiscal year ended May 31.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Joe Falcon, the world's fastest miler this year, will miss the rest of the track season because of a tear in the sheath of his left Achilles' tendon.
LEAD: HOW much energy insurance is really enough?

LEAD: YOUNG & RUBICAM and Ogilvy & Mather opened offices with great fanfare in Moscow 18 months ago, and while both have been busy learning the ins and outs of doing business in the Soviet Union, the one thing they have not been doing much of is creating advertising.
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. will introduce a lower-priced line of Macintosh personal computers in October.

LEAD: The All Nippon Airways Company of Japan has ordered $580 million worth of aircraft engines from the General Electric Company, G.E. said. The airline ordered G.E.'s CF6-80C2 engines for 17 Boeing 747's. With the new order, G.E. will supply the engine to 43 All Nippon 747's. All Nippon will take delivery of its first 747 later this month, with deliveries for the new order scheduled to begin in 1995, G.E.

LEAD: Cecil Fielder, who hit 38 home runs for the Hanshin Tigers of the Japanese league last season and has 41 for the Detroit Tigers of the American League this season, will be heading back to Japan as part of a major league team that will play an eight-game series against Japanese all-stars beginning Nov.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq during a visit with Western hostages, as broadcast by CNN and recorded by Federal News Service, a transcription company. Mr. Hussein's remarks were translated by an Iraqi interpreter.

LEAD: Martha Dodd Stern, an American author who in the 1930's and 1940's wrote popular books about Nazi Germany and later fled behind the Iron Curtain when she and her wealthy husband, Alfred K. Stern, were accused of being Soviet spies, died on Aug. 10 in Prague, friends reported. She was 82 years old and had lived in the

LEAD: Henry L. Duncombe Jr., a retired vice president of General Motors, died on Aug. 18 at Baptist Memorial Hospital in Miami. He was 76 years old and had homes in Key Biscayne, Fla., and Southampton, L.I.

LEAD: Five years ago, a group of teachers met on this idyllic site in the Green Mountains to recall how six weeks of intensive study here at Bread Loaf's School of English, a graduate division of Middlebury College, had changed their way of teaching. But while praising the Program in Writing for what it taught, they also celebrated the liberation it offered from their isolated lives in rural communities or small towns.
LEAD: Seven years after Michael Stewart died following his arrest by the transit police, his family has won a $1.7 million settlement of a damage suit.

LEAD: At the University of California campus that was once the national stage for student unrest, young men and women with bright eyes and promising futures warily started a new semester this week in a world poised for war.
