LEAD: The South African police raided the Johannesburg headquarters of the country's biggest black labor federation and arrested several of its senior leaders today after union members reportedly abducted a black undercover agent, assaulted him and then forced him to address a news conference.
LEAD: Paul Russell Fitchen, a former banking executive, died on Saturday at his home in Brewster, N.Y. He was 88 years old.
LEAD: The former chairman and chief executive of Guinness P.L.C. was sentenced today to five years in prison for his role in one of Britain's biggest financial scandals in decades.

LEAD: New York City's First Lady, Joyce B. Dinkins, sporting a button that said ''Make The First Day Second to None,'' began a campaign yesterday to encourage parents to accompany their children to school on the first day and to get businesses to give employees time off to do so.
LEAD: Arthur Rich, a professor of physics at the University of Michigan, died Saturday at his home in Ann Arbor at the age of 52. His family said he died of a brain tumor.
LEAD: Poverty, like beauty, resides in the eye of the beholder. Many Americans think they know it when they see it, but definition has proved difficult.
LEAD: James E. Snyder, a professor and art historian, died Thursday at Mercy Hospital in Port Jervis, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived in Sunrise Lake, Pa.
LEAD: Two days before Syracuse opens its 101st football season with the challenge of facing Southern Cal in the eighth Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium, two quarterbacks wonder which one will start.

LEAD: The ''Week in Connecticut'' column of the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday misstated the admission policy for the Eli Whitney Folk Festival at Edgerton Park in New Haven on Saturday. It is not free; tickets are $9 in advance and $12.50 at the gate.

LEAD: Iran's oil minister, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, whose country said it would not support an accord proposed by a majority of the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise output, asked today that the OPEC meeting be postponed a week to consider alternative courses.
LEAD: Bergdorf Goodman held a cocktail party last night to celebrate the opening of its swank new men's store. A lot of suits showed up.
LEAD: Federal futures regulators announced plans today to explore changes for handling the liquidation of customer accounts, in the wake of the collapse of Stotler Group Inc. The Commodity Futures

LEAD: As New York City's doomed Board of Estimate gathered this month for its last marathon series of hearings and meetings, Mayor David Dinkins, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and some others on the eight-member board actually showed up. That was notable: in recent years, elected officials took to sending surrogates to listen to the speakers at public hearings and to cast votes according to their masters' wishes.

LEAD: In the early 1950's, when Abstract Expressionism was first gaining widespread attention and the New York art scene was heating up, a quieter revolution was taking place in San Francisco. The Abstract Expressionist style, already embraced by many of the city's forward-looking painters, was being abandoned for a return to figuration that was heavy on the use of raw color and muscular paint handling, and light on traditional drawing.

LEAD: President Bush is right to be skeptical that Saddam Hussein will withdraw from Kuwait soon. But he is also right not to block talks with Baghdad. Washington cannot appear to oppose efforts to promote a peaceful resolution of the Persian Gulf conflict. What it can do is stress the minimum conditions for a settlement - that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally, and stop threatening the region.
LEAD: * United Parcel Service in Korea to McCann-Erickson Worldwide with a budget of $500,000.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities yesterday continued to move in tandem with world petroleum markets, as a small rise in oil prices prompted credit market participants to sell notes and bonds, lifting interest rates.

LEAD: Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday gave the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York permission to exhume the remains of Pierre Toussaint, a former slave, as one of the first steps toward canonizing him as the first black American saint.
LEAD: * Bill Dunlap, chief executive officer of Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising, has been named chairman of the central region of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

LEAD: Dr. Selvan Davison, a rheumatologist who was chief of the arthritis clinic at Mount Sinai Hospital and clinical professor of medicine emeritus at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, died on Sunday at the hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens. He died of leukemia, his family said.
LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq announced tonight that he would allow the departure of all foreign women and children, whom he had previously barred from leaving his country.

LEAD: Joe Morris is still here with the Giants. Lawrence Taylor is not here yet, but may be soon. That is the latest report on the ins and outs of a team preparing for the start of the National Football League season in 12 days.

LEAD: The Bush Administration has agreed to sell Saudi Arabia a $6 billion emergency package of advanced weaponry, including F-15 fighter planes, M-60 tanks and Stinger anti-aircraft missiles, Defense Department officials said today.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the criminal case arising from Guinness P.L.C.'s takeover of the Distillers Company in 1986 misstated a business affiliation of Roger Seelig, a defendant. He is a former corporate finance director at the investment banking firm of Morgan Grenfell in London.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mike Greenwell had three hits, including a two-run triple that drove in the tying and lead runs in the ninth inning, as the Boston Red Sox beat the Cleveland Indians, 6-5, tonight and continued to pull away in the American League East. It was the Red Sox's fifth straight victory and gave them a six-game lead over
LEAD: * Chesapeake Packaging Co., a division of the Chesapeake Corp., Richmond, appointed George F. Barnes president of the Display and Packaging Co., a unit in Sandusky, Ohio.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: A third century mosaic panel depicting the head of Medusa will be returned to the Sparta Museum in Greece, from which it was stolen four years ago. TORKOM DEMIRJIAN, president of New York's Ariadne Galleries, will present the panel during a ceremony Sept. 18 at the Greek Consulate General in New York.
LEAD: John Johnson, the manager of the heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, was out of character last week in Columbus, Ohio.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: In this preseason of surprises for a Jets team in ferment, Coach Bruce Coslet has waited until virtually the last moment to make changes that could drastically revamp the club.
LEAD: A hand-scrawled, blue-and-white banner hangs limply over the arms factory entrance, proclaiming, ''Democracy. Full Employment. Economic Welfare.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Jack O'Donnell, who recently quit as president of the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, was named to run Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel.

LEAD: Andre Ware, the Heisman Trophy winner from the University of Houston, joined the Detroit camp Monday night after he signed a four-year contract with the Lions. The contract will pay Ware $1.15 million a year, plus a $2 million signing bonus. (AP)

LEAD: The Kansas Gas and Electric Company said it might explore a merger or recapitalization to thwart a hostile $857 million offer from the Kansas City Power and Light Company. The disclosure in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission was the first in which the Wichita, Kan., utility said it might talk to third parties to fight the Kansas City

LEAD: Stock prices moved ahead slightly yesterday on slow volume as some investors and traders took to the sidelines. Many said they were waiting for further signs as to where oil prices and the Middle East crisis might be heading.

LEAD: Saying that the three-city introduction of its new PS/1 home computer in June had been well received by customers, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had begun selling the computer nationwide.

LEAD: The Fluor Corporation said it had won a contract worth more than $200 million to upgrade a Valero Refining and Marketing Company oil refinery in Corpus Christi, Tex. The construction giant, based in Irvine, Calif., also announced a $50 million contract to engineer, build and manage a copper ore and molybdenum processing plant 200 miles north of Santiago, Chile.

LEAD: The new head of the Drug Enforcement Administration today defended the agency's role in the abduction of a Mexican doctor charged in the 1985 torture and killing of an American drug agent in Guadalajara.

LEAD: Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov today criticized police idleness at a fire that destroyed the headquarters of the governing Communist Party but said it might be ''the price we have to pay'' for avoiding clashes with protesters.

LEAD: Victims of a spinal nerve disease sued the Eastman Kodak Company and four other companies over a dye used for diagnostic purposes. The 25 plaintiffs, who live in 18 states, contend they were not adequately informed of the dangers of Pantopaque, a dye that is injected into the spinal membrane.

LEAD: Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait nearly a month ago, several dozen Arab-Americans have reported being threatened with death or receiving harassing telephone calls in what leading Arab-Americans describe as a nationwide wave of anti-Arab sentiment.

LEAD: A year after racially charged rioting on the waterfront here left a hundred stores looted, dozens of people injured and scores more arrested, this resort city says it is trying to do the right thing.

LEAD: With images of racial polarization dominating the tube, a documentary about black politicians who have won support from sizable numbers of white voters comes as a relief and a corrective. ''Politics: The New Black Power,'' tonight at 8 on Channel 13, focuses on three men who are making it in the mainstream: Gov.
LEAD: Blacks and whites have agreed to rotate control of the troubled Selma school system in an effort to end months of racial tension, protests, arrests and lawsuits.

LEAD: An investment group led by the New York money manager Michael H. Steinhardt has raised its stake in the USAir Group to 9.46 percent from 8.38 percent, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

LEAD: ''If it's drug-related, I can count myself out. If it's a domestic situation, I'm safe. But with this, you wonder who's next.'' - Laura Dougherty, a University of Florida student who has moved back with her parents after a string of murders in Gainesville. [A1:3.]

LEAD: On front lawns in many cities along the California coast, the for-sale sign has become almost as common as the palm tree, and to some sellers seemingly as permanent. After several years of breathtaking price increases and demand so strong that houses were snapped up within hours of being listed, California's giant real estate market has slowed drastically.
LEAD: Lyle Alzado's dream of returning to the National Football League at the age of 41 ended yesterday when the Los Angeles Raiders announced his retirement.

LEAD: New York City, already plagued with one of the nation's worst smog and carbon-monoxide problems, is also violating the Federal health standard for the soot and dirt emitted by the diesel engines of buses and trucks, new government data show.

LEAD: In a country that takes its champignons seriously, Larousse, the venerable French publishing house, has suspended sales of the new edition of its famous dictionary because the book errs in saying that some highly poisonous wild mushrooms are harmless.
LEAD: Dr. Hugh C. Banks, assistant chancellor at New York University, died on Saturday at New York University Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The shot to left was gone. Tim Teufel, watching as the ball smashed off the first deck of seats, nearly crashed across first base, then downshifted deliberately, did not trip, and safely touched each bag. At last, his cleats hit the plate as he completed probably the most exquisite 360 feet he has traveled in a disorienting season.

LEAD: A Seattle company has developed a personal computer program that ''evolves'' the best solution among various models run on spreadsheets by financial planners for businesses. The new program, called Evolver, was developed by Axcelis Inc.. It works as an addition to a computer spreadsheet and finds the best answer by using principles taken from theories of natural selection and evolution.

LEAD: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV has a new spokesman, according to a Reuters dispatch from Moscow. He is VITALY IGNATENKO, editor in chief of New Times magazine, who was named assistant to the president and head of Mr. Gorbachev's own personal press service.

LEAD: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Recalled Terry McGriff, catcher, from Nashville of the American Association. Sent Chris Hammond, pitcher, to Nashville. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Traded Ronnie Lee, offensive tackle, to the Seattle Seahawks for an undisclosed draft choice. Placed Titus Dixon, wide receiver, on injured reserve and Malcolm Taylor, defensive lineman, on the waived-injured list.
LEAD: Wall Street, it is said, is an odd sort of market, a place where demand regularly rises as the price goes up.

LEAD: SUMMER'S finale coincides with a finish-line rush from my garden, yielding a plethora of zucchini, squash, tomatoes, peppers and more. Many home gardeners become diligent canners when Labor Day approaches. I do not have the time or patience to do that. Most of my excess produce becomes my neighbors' windfall, and
LEAD: As Sri Lankan troops inch toward Jaffna Fort along a causeway carpeted with mines, Tamil guerrillas have opened another front on Sri Lanka's east coast, a Government spokesman said today.

LEAD: The police have identified an American mountain climber killed last week on the Matterhorn as Marc A. Swanson of San Francisco. Mr. Swanson, 37 years old, a mathematician working for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, died Aug. 20 when a roped three-member party fell 240 feet while climbing down from the most famous peak of the Swiss Alps, the authorities said.

LEAD: President Bush won overwhelming support today from more than 170 members of Congress whom he briefed on the crisis in the Middle East, but several senior lawmakers expressed worry about the patience of the American people in supporting a strategy that may take months to work.

LEAD: It is a measure of just how political the subject of the Supreme Court and the Constitution have become that it took Saddam Hussein to get Judge David Souter off the front pages. Perhaps the only benefit we have reaped from Iraq's aggression is the sudden disappearance of opinion pieces by law professors who think that a man who is a bachelor and lives in a small town cannot have the proper ''sensitivities'' (read ''politically correct positions'') on women, minorities and the poor.

LEAD: A suspected gang member, believed to have been shot accidentally by another gang member, died yesterday after being disconnected from a respirator at the family's request, hospital officials and the police said.

LEAD: Sylvia Deutscher Kushner, a bassoonist who played with the New York City Opera and other orchestras, died on Monday at St. Patrick's Hospital in Lake Charles, La. She was 65 years old and lived in Lake Charles. She died of lung cancer, her sister, Martha Deutscher, said. A graduate of the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, Mrs.
LEAD: Rocking Rabble-Rouser
LEAD: Thousands of civilians employed by military contractors are being sent to the Middle East as part of the military buildup in and around Saudi Arabia, industry and military officials say.

LEAD: CHILDREN are thought to be the taste makers when it comes to peanut butter, so last week at the House of Little People, a child-care center in the Yorkville section of Manhattan, 14 children were asked their impressions of four peanut butters - the three top-selling national brands and Krema, a smooth natural peanut butter sold in the

LEAD: Now more than ever, New York City's jails need well-motivated guards; as recent events demonstrate, a collapse of their morale could prove as dangerous to the public as a collapse of a jail's walls. That's a point city officials easily overlook. And it doesn't help when the head of the guards' union ignores it as well.

LEAD: Robert H. Brooks, a theatrical booking agent, died on Monday in a helicopter crash in East Troy, Wis., which killed the blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughn and three others. He was 34 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

LEAD: As the other great harbors of Nassau County have succumbed to mistreatment and pollution, Oyster Bay Harbor has remained relatively untroubled: a home or rest stop for dozens of species of waterfowl and fish, a place where people can still swim, sail and harvest the oysters that flourish in its waters.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Three more arrests have been made in southeastern Connecticut under the state's rarely enforced adultery law, bringing the total since June to four.

LEAD: As the Persian Gulf crisis drags on, Israelis are coming to the conclusion that the United States wants a political solution and is not looking for a military confrontation with Saddam Hussein. That has caused many Israeli politicians, academic experts and ordinary citizens to grow restive, nervous and in some cases angry.
LEAD: The rating on $1.2 billion in long-term debt and commercial paper issued by the Bank of New York Company has been lowered, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

LEAD: A TODDLER is sitting alone in a psychology laboratory with a hidden game, and she has a problem. Should she peek at the game even though the adult told her not to? And if she does peek, and if the adult asks, should she admit her transgression or tell a lie?

LEAD: When 30-year-old Andres Gomez accepted his French Open trophy, his first memorable booty in more than a decade of Grand Slam endeavors, he likened the experience to watching his career ascend and explode like a sunrise.

LEAD: Research at Harvard Medical School suggests that women at high risk of having a baby with a neural tube defect can be screened just as well with ultrasound as with the standard method, amniocentesis, which is more expensive and can itself cause miscarriage.

LEAD: Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C. will sell a 15 percent stake in itself to a Japanese retailing group for $58.3 million. The British retailer said it would sell 35.2 million newly issued shares of its stock to the Aeon Group of Japan for $:29.9 million. The price represented a 73 percent premium over the closing price of the company's shares on

LEAD: Carlos Grosso, the Peronist Mayor of this sprawling and beautiful city, is embarking on the ''privatization'' of parking-law enforcement and the maintenance of a street system that includes some of the most impressive boulevards in the world.

LEAD: HOME is the two top floors of a condominium apartment building in Manhattan, near Central Park, which were demolished and rebuilt over the past year as a French palace. It is a work in progress: a butler in a white jacket serves soft drinks in crystal goblets as workers on tall ladders adjust the wiring for a chandelier in the rotunda.
LEAD: The Chief of the Dallas police was charged with seven counts of perjury today over statements he made this month to a panel investigating the fatal shooting of a civilian by a police officer.
LEAD: The Financial News Network is beginning its largest advertising campaign in its nine years as a cable network.
LEAD: THE story of In-Store Advertising Inc. as a publicly held company is now six weeks old, but to many buyers it probably seems much longer.
LEAD: Long Island Show House, Lot 1, Redcoats Lane, North Haven Point off Sunset Beach Road, Sag Harbor; (212) 551-7028.
LEAD: A four-part financing totaling more than $4.2 billion was priced yesterday by the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation.

LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn, fell into the Colorado River during a rafting expedition through the Grand Canyon last weekend, a park spokesman said today. Mrs. Quayle was thrown from the raft when it was in Lava Falls rapids, said Chuck Lundy, a spokesman for Grand Canyon National Park.

LEAD: Two summers ago the Gate Theater, Dublin, jolted New York audiences with the festering, dark-brewed, tragic reality of its ''Juno and the Paycock,'' a brief Broadway tenant courtesy of the New York International Festival of the Arts. Now the Gate is offering Londoners an equivalent thrill with its visiting production of ''The Three Sisters'': a stunning collaboration between Ireland's acting dynasty -Cyril Cusack and a trio of his daughters - and the English director Adrian Noble, the newly named artistic leader of the Royal Shakespeare Company.

LEAD: * American Travellers Corp., Warrington, Pa., an insurance company, appointed John Riordan president and chief operating officer. Thomas Parry was named vice president of product development and compliance.

LEAD: TRACK AND FIELD British Record Set Kriss Akabusi set a British record and posted the second-fastest time in the world this year when he won the men's 400-meter hurdles yesterday in 47.92 seconds at the European championships at Split, Yugoslavia. Sven Nylander of Sweden clinched the silver medal with a time of 48.43 and a countryman, Niklas Wallenlind, was third in 48.52.

LEAD: Leaders of the largest Arab-American civil rights group said today that President Bush and other members of the Administration had inadvertently fostered an atmosphere of animosity toward Americans of Arab descent by using heated oratory directed at President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson arrived in Baghdad today to interview the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, for a syndicated American television program. The Iraqi press agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Mr. Jackson was met at Baghdad airport by Foreign Ministry officials. Mr. Jackson has said that he is making the trip as a journalist and that he will not be involved in any diplomatic negotiations.
LEAD: The police said today that they believed a ''shrewd, methodical'' killer was behind a string of five slayings that has traumatized this university town.

LEAD: Every year, pro football teams generally bring two or more place-kickers to training camp. And almost every year, the incumbent makes the team and the bright-eyed newcomers are cut loose and float in the huge pool of midseason emergency replacements.

LEAD: SO much attention has been paid to the English country house that the American country house heritage may seem insignificant by comparison. But according to two new books published by Yale University Press - ''The American Country House'' ($55) by Clive Aslet and ''The Architect and the American Country House'' ($55) by Mark Alan Hewitt - the

LEAD: Armenia's Parliament declared a state of emergency throughout the republic today after a member of the Parliament was shot dead by a rogue paramilitary group, Soviet press accounts and Armenian officials said.
LEAD: The lines of oil wells that stretch across Lake Maracaibo here are pumping higher volumes of crude to help offset the shortage caused by the embargo of oil from Iraq and Kuwait.

LEAD: When the black wind stopped howling and the terrible roar faded, the first thing Bernice Lea noticed, as she huddled inside her bedroom, was the rain, cold and hard on her back. She looked up and saw that the roof and most of the walls of her house were gone.
LEAD: Somewhere in the world may be another person who could have conceived and organized this extraordinary Oslo conference, but the name does not come to mind.

LEAD: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan and the Tandy Corporation of Fort Worth will produce personal computers at a Texas plant under a joint venture, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday. The size of the planned investment was not known, the newspaper said.

LEAD: The agreement of the five permanent members of the United Nations on the essentials of a political settlement of the Cambodian conflict may finally force the warring Cambodian factions to negotiate seriously and confront the real risks of peace.

LEAD: The Rev. F. Sanford Cutler, an Episcopal priest who was active in the peace and women's rights movements died on Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Donald J. Trump is about to enter Round 2 of his financial crisis, and the sale of the Plaza Hotel is likely to be part of it.

LEAD: Small guerrilla bands in Kuwait have killed or wounded ''a couple hundred'' Iraqi troops and have destroyed a handful of tanks and more than 20 trucks and small military vehicles, a United States Government official says.
LEAD: * Apache Corp., Denver, an oil and gas company, said it would buy certain oil properties of CNG Producing Corp., a unit of Consolidated Natural Gas Co., Pittsburgh, for $23.5 million.

LEAD: A disarming quiet pervades the docks here each morning, but the stillness is misleading. Anxious yachtsmen are up at dawn preparing to race round the world in the BOC Challenge. They are moving with purpose through the innards of their boats. In two weeks, these sailors - for the first time, both men and women - will be setting sail in a competition that has no mercy for the unprepared.

LEAD: The Federal judge presiding over the biggest music payola trial in 30 years threatened today to dismiss all charges against the record promoter Joseph Isgro and two other defendants after defense lawyers told him the prosecution had apparently withheld a key document in the case.

LEAD: An investigation by the State Commission of Correction has concluded that correction officers on Rikers Island used excessive force during the Aug. 14 melee that left more than a hundred inmates and guards injured.

LEAD: Mired in a slow back-to-school season, America's biggest retailers have expressed deep concern that the Middle East crisis will hurt their business even further in the weeks heading into the all-important Christmas season.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Bill White, the National League president, yesterday disputed Joe West's interpretation of what White said about breaking up player fights and the umpire's handling of an ejection.

LEAD: None of the roughly 1,000 American women and children trapped in Kuwait and Iraq left today, despite President Saddam Hussein's promise on Tuesday to permit them and other Westerners to depart. Baghdad said that it would require each one to procure an exit visa first.

LEAD: Grace Eddy Peabody, an abstract artist, died on Aug. 19 at her home in San Francisco, where she had lived for the last 14 years. She was 66 years old. Mrs. Peabody died of cancer, her son, Reese, said. She was a native of West Hartford, Conn. She graduated from Mount Vernon Seminary in Washington and studied at the Museum of Modern Art.
LEAD: The Oil Jolt

LEAD: After weeks of deliberations, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries authorized its key oil producers today to begin pumping all the oil they can immediately, averting a feared shortage that has sent prices surging on world markets.

LEAD: MILES INC., a maker of health and household products in Elkhart, Ind., agreed yesterday to stop making health claims in advertising for its One-A-Day vitamins that Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York said were ''false'' and ''unfounded.''
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday threw out a civil racketeering lawsuit that claimed that Leona Helmsley illegally took millions of dollars from her husband.
LEAD: An obituary yesterday about Sylvia Deutscher Kushner, a bassoonist with the New York City Opera, omitted a survivor. He is her husband, William Kushner.

LEAD: Being second in command at the Justice Department under Dick Thornburgh has proved a high-risk career choice. But William P. Barr, the Attorney General's third appointee to the post, seems to be settling in. His daunting task: to turn around one of the Bush Administration's more troubled departments.
LEAD: An article in The Home Section last Thursday about the Collapsible Classics furniture line gave an incorrect number for the designer, Bower Studios. Its number is (802) 877-6868.
LEAD: In an age of Stealth fighters, the A-10 is among the least glamorous in the Pentagon's panoply of weapons.
LEAD: For months the Soviet press studiously ignored Pavel Lungin's new film, ''Taxi Blues,'' about the relationship between an alcoholic Jewish saxophone player and a bigoted Russian taxi driver.

LEAD: John J. O'Hara, a former Internal Revenue Service intelligence agent and a member of the Justice Department's Organized Crime Strike Force, died on Tuesday at the Community Medical Center in Toms River, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Berkeley Township, N.J.
LEAD: A 10-year-old boy from Utica, N.Y., was shot in the stomach yesterday in Brooklyn while he and an older boy were playing with a pistol, the police said.

LEAD: Sandy, who overcame abuse as a puppy and was nearly put to death at a pound before achieving Broadway fame as the best friend of Little Orphan Annie and a member of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's inner circle, died in his sleep yesterday at the age of 16. The dog, a beige terrier mix, lived in Haddam, Conn., with his owner and trainer, William

LEAD: Two major indexes of consumer confidence, which for many economists is the most sensitive measure of a nation's vulnerability to recession, plunged sharply in August, indicating that frightened Americans might finally be pushing the United States into a recession, after months of weak economic growth.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Late in a game late in August. The score deadlocked. The nightly stakes readily apparent to anyone who cares to look at the scoreboard.

LEAD: Interest rates fell and the price of Treasury securities rose yesterday, with the benchmark long bond jumping more than a point. The gains were fueled by a drop in oil prices and rising hopes among market participants that the Federal Reserve Board may move to ease short-term interest rates soon, perhaps by the end of the week.

LEAD: Researchers exploring how and when allergies begin are finding that allergic reactions and asthma in infants are often caused by exposure to foods and tobacco smoke introduced by parents, sometimes before the babies are born.

LEAD: Raymond St. Jacques, an actor who helped lower racial barriers for blacks in television and films, died Monday in Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 60 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.
LEAD: A judge yesterday set bail for a former professional baseball player, prompting an emotional outburst from the family of the 9-year-old girl he is accused of killing with a stray bullet.

LEAD: Ken Griffey was signed by the Seattle Mariners yesterday, joining Ken Jr. to become the first father and son to play on the same major league team. Last year, the Griffeys became the first father and son to play in the major leagues at the same time.

LEAD: The Persian Gulf crisis is giving members of Congress second thoughts about making major cuts in military spending for the next fiscal year and has muted but not silenced the hopeful talk of a peace dividend from the end of the cold war.

LEAD: The British Government said today that it would send to the Court of Appeal the case of six men who were convicted of murdering 21 people in the bombings of two pubs in Birmingham, England, in 1974.
LEAD: The stock market continued to gain yesterday as crude oil prices slid further, bond prices advanced and the danger of war with Iraq seemed increasingly distant.
LEAD: Masked Mohawks helped soldiers today to tear down barricades set up seven weeks ago near the Mercier Bridge, avoiding a bloody confrontation.

LEAD: MARK SIMON and Michael McDonough have discovered that it takes more than ingenuity to build a structure sound enough to lead a dog's life. Both architects designed doghouses made of dog biscuits for the Cooper-Hewitt Museum's ''Doghouse,'' exhibition, which runs through Oct. 14. But their doghouses disintegrated, or almost.
LEAD: Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner, said yesterday that the league was considering revising its new speed-up rules to get three or four plays back into the game.

LEAD: California moved closer to its first execution in nearly a quarter of a century today when a divided Federal appeals court upheld the death sentence of Robert Alton Harris, who was hours away from execution at San Quentin prison last April when his sentence was stayed.

LEAD: Robert H. Phillips, a photographer whose work has appeared in the nation's leading magazines and is in the photography collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art, died on Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 64 years old.

LEAD: If you frequent a health club, you probably don't expect to see an 80-year-old person pumping iron or working out on a nearby machine. But based on the results of recent studies involving people up to the age of 96, strength training is likely to become increasingly popular among old and very old Americans.
LEAD: Talbert Abrams, an aviation pioneer and the developer of aerial mapping, died Saturday at a nursing home in Lansing, Mich. He was 95 years old and lived in Lansing.
LEAD: RICHARD EKSTRACT has long had a passion for Italian food and wine, siestas, Palladian architecture and the Tuscan countryside. He has studied Italian and thinks he was Italian in another life.
LEAD: One of three homeless people sleeping on a sidewalk grate near Penn Station was killed last night when the grate gave way and plunged 30 feet into an empty vault, the police said.

LEAD: An organization of black New York City correction officers announced yesterday that it would begin a petition and picketing drive aimed at forcing Phil Seelig, the president of the officers' union, out of office.
LEAD: WEATHEREND, a company in Rockland, Me., that makes outdoor furniture, is holding an art exhibition called ''Construction - Works.''

LEAD: Three former employees of MAI Basic Four Inc. today settled Federal insider trading charges accusing them of buying Prime Computer Inc. securities after they learned that MAI Basic was planning to make a hostile bid for Prime in the fall of 1988.

LEAD: Despite a preponderance of $4 million homes, espresso cafes and galleries run by people with European accents, this golden mountain community still prefers to think of itself as somewhat of an Old West geezer in need of a bath and a shot of bourbon.
LEAD: * Jeffrey Soinski has joined Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc., New York, as vice president and management supervisor. Margot Pitlor has joined as an account executive.

LEAD: Italian finance officials proposed today that prices of petroleum products be frozen for three months to combat rising inflation resulting from the Gulf crisis. The Treasury Minister, Guido Carli; the Finance Minister, Rino Fomica, and the Budget Minister, Paolo Cirino Pomicino, will ask the Cabinet on Friday to approve a freeze that would be in effect from September through November.
LEAD: Dana Kiecker (6-6) shut out Cleveland on three hits for seven innings as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Indians, 7-1, tonight for their sixth consecutive victory on the road.
LEAD: Julian Bingham Abbott, an interior designer based, died on Aug. 20 at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.
LEAD: Breathing Under Water and Other East European Essays By Stanislaw Baranczak Harvard University Press. $22.50. 258 pages.

LEAD: From the Persian Gulf to Phnom Penh, the end of the cold war has brought no respite from deadly regional conflicts. But the superpower role in these confrontations has been dramatically transformed. The agreement on Cambodia announced Tuesday by the Security Council's five permanent members converts major sponsors and suppliers of the rival factions into peacemakers.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: * Litton Industries Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of liquid yield option notes due 2010. The sale is expected to bring the company about $265 million in proceeds.
LEAD: Lehman Brothers, a unit of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., is searching for an agency to handle its print advertising account, a spokesman said yesterday.

LEAD: Refco Inc., a Chicago-based commodities broker, today settled Federal disciplinary charges that one of its floor brokers had aided a customer's violation of the speculative limits in pork belly futures for more than a year beginning in June 1988.

LEAD: New-home sales fell 2.3 percent in July, the fifth drop in seven months, the Government said today, and industry observers predicted rising mortgage rates linked to the Middle East crisis would compound the decline in the months ahead.

LEAD: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico yesterday tentatively priced $274 million in tax-exempt public-improvement bonds with a maximum yield of 7.80 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
LEAD: Riot policemen used clubs and tear gas today to disperse thousands of ethnic Albanians awaiting a United States Congressional delegation to complain about human rights abuses.
LEAD: A smoky electrical fire in the basement of the New York Hilton, the city's largest hotel, forced a power shutdown at the 45-story building for much of yesterday.
LEAD: A Federal district judge has ordered a ban on imports of tuna fish caught by five nations until they can show that they are not killing more dolphins than United States law allows.

LEAD: The Citizens and Southern Corporation of Atlanta and the Sovran Financial Corporation of Norfolk, Va., which plan a merger on Saturday that will create the nation's 13th-largest bank, have named a management team for the new company.

LEAD: After weeks of negotiations between the Department of Correction and lawyers for inmates, a Federal judge yesterday approved a revision of the rules on the use of force by jail guards that have been at the heart of the recent turmoil at Rikers Island.

LEAD: Lost amid the billion-dollar development deals approved by the Board of Estimate in its final meeting, which ended on Monday, was a modest proposal for a 28-story office building on West 34th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.
LEAD: A painting of a crucifixion scene that has hung on the wall of a school auditorium in upstate New York for 25 years must be taken down, a Federal judge in Syracuse ruled today.

LEAD: Earl E. Veron, a judge of the United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana, died Tuesday at Tulane Medical Center in New Orleans. He was 68 years old. He collapsed at the Federal courthouse in New Orleans and was pronounced dead of heart failure at the medical center.
LEAD: LeRoy Makepeace, a career Foreign Service officer, died Friday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Massachusetts. He was 75 years old and lived in Washington.
LEAD: Six months after it began conducting AIDS tests in all autopsies, the New York City Medical Examiner's office has found infection rates as high as 38 percent in some groups.
LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company is giving the Campbell Kids speaking roles in a commercial for the first time since 1958.

LEAD: Syrian Army units may have killed dozens of people in several Syrian towns who were demonstrating in support of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and against Syrian involvement in the allied military force based in Saudi Arabia, the British Broadcasting Corporation and The Associated Press reported today.

LEAD: Wax Buildup on Tile Q. Over the years, the slate tile floor in our entrance hall has been washed with warm water and polished with a liquid wax. The tiles now have a blotchy look that is apparently due to wax buildup. How can we remove this, and how should we maintain the tiles to keep them shiny?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: From the Mississippi River delta to the Appalachian mountains of Kentucky to the high plains of North Dakota, rural America suffered far greater losses in population during the 1980's than had been expected, according to preliminary figures from the 1990 census.

LEAD: SOOT can be sublime. Those who doubt it need travel no farther than Trinity Church, which looms at the foot of Wall Street in lower Manhattan. For most of this century, the moody, pinnacled facade of the church, Richard Upjohn's 1846 Gothic Revival masterpiece, has been distinguished by a jet-black layer of grime.
LEAD: Despite President Bush's nearly flawless handling of the Persian Gulf crisis, several key issues still dangle dangerously, unresolved or unclarified.

LEAD: CBS News plans to use Dan Rather's exclusive interview with the Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, which was broadcast last night, to begin a continuing series of late-night news specials focusing on the crisis in the Persian Gulf. The specials may evolve into a regular news program to compete with ABC's ''Nightline.
LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation today presented its version of a futuristic fighter proposed for the 21st century. Lockheed's display of the

LEAD: The Philadelphia Phillies and the center fielder Len Dykstra agreed yesterday to a three-year contract. Financial terms were undisclosed and the deal includes a fourth year at the club's option. Dykstra, the National League's leading hitter at .340, could have become a free agent at the end of the season.
LEAD: The first effort to insert foreign genes into human patients has succeeded on every possible front, researchers say in a new report.

LEAD: PARENTS, rejoice. Manufacturers are making children's furniture fashionable again. Just as in the 19th century, when miniature chairs were common, furniture makers are offering scaled-down versions of their designs.
LEAD: After a cross-country journey that has little to do with their traditional goal of a Pacific-10 Conference championship, will the Southern California Trojans show that they want to be here?

LEAD: * Leo Burnett Worldwide, Chicago, bought a share of Allied Communications, a new agency in Seoul, South Korea. The venture was created after the agency ended their three-year association with Dong Bang Advertising Co. because of a client conflict. Allied will serve local and multinational clients, including Procter & Gamble, Philip Morris and Cathay Pacific.

LEAD: Japan unveiled a long-awaited program on Wednesday night to help finance the international effort against Iraq, but the package drew unusual criticism from American officials for the absence of direct tangible aid to the military buildup in the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: IN Japan, shoji screens are found in nearly every home, used instead of curtains to create privacy while letting in light. But Westerners have devised less traditional uses for these elegant screens, originally formed from wood and rice paper, says Hisao Hanafusa, a partner in Miya Shoji, a Manhattan company that has made customized Japanese screens for more than 40 years.

LEAD: Kevin Elster, one of the National League's premier defensive shortstops, whose absence because of injury has provoked the Mets into an array of dramatic lineup shuffles, will undergo surgery to repair his right shoulder next week and be lost for the season.

LEAD: The Oakland Athletics, in their second big deal of the day yesterday, acquired the outfielder Willie McGee - the National League's second-leading hitter - from the St. Louis Cardinals for the outfielder Felix Jose and two minor leaguers. McGee, 31, was batting .335 for the Cardinals. He was eligible for free agency at the end of the season and indicated he would not stay in St.

LEAD: WHEN I go home at night, the light is different from what it was only a few weeks ago. Inside the bus it is cold, but outside heat is rising up from the sidewalks and pushing down from the sky. The people streaming into Penn Station are jacketless if they are men and bare-armed if they are women, and the boys on bikes are stripped to singlets and shorts.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: NANCY REAGAN had a cancerous tumor removed from her face yesterday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., a family spokesman said. She and former President RONALD REAGAN left for their home in Los Angeles later in the day.

LEAD: The phone call to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Aug. 22 at his Wyoming ranch was not the first to interrupt his vacation, but it was one of the most important. The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, called Mr. Baker's remote mountain retreat to say Moscow was leaning toward supporting a United Nations resolution giving the world's navies the right to enforce the international trade embargo against Iraq.

LEAD: A Brooklyn woman who neighbors said walked the streets of Red Hook in search of the stray dogs and cats she kept in a nearby warehouse that was her home was charged yesterday with cruelty to animals.
LEAD: The winner of the Jets' quarterback showdown Thursday night may not win the starting job after all.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo drove to a news conference here today in a light blue, methanol-powered Ford and announced that the state would buy 268 cars and buses powered by alternative fuels in the next five years.

LEAD: John J. Snodgrass, founding director of the Division of Radiology at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., died at the hospital on Monday. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhasset.

LEAD: Christopher Taylor, a 20-year-old pianist from Boulder, Colo., has won first prize in the 1990 University of Maryland International William Kapell Piano Competition, which ended in July. His award includes $20,000 in cash and a recital in November at Alice Tully Hall.

LEAD: Preliminary 1990 census figures show New York City with a population of 7,033,179, significantly smaller than the Census Bureau estimated in 1988 and at least 600,000 people short of estimates by city planners and at least one outside expert.

LEAD: The Pentagon has ordered worldwide spending cuts in supplies, maintenance, travel and training to free money to help pay for the Persian Gulf military operation, Defense Department officials said today.
LEAD: A ceremony at Euston train station in London yesterday marked the official departure of the Sadler's Wells Royal Ballet Company from London and its reincarnation as the Birmingham Royal Ballet.

LEAD: An obituary headline in some editions on Tuesday about Ozel Tendzin misstated his affiliation with Tibetan Buddhists. Mr. Tendzin was the leader of the Vajradhatu International Buddhist Church, a Tibetan Buddhist sect in Boulder, Colo.; the Dalai Lama is the head of Tibetan Buddhists.

LEAD: Caryle Murphy, a reporter for The Washington Post who escaped from Kuwait on Monday after almost a month of eluding Iraqi troops, said today that she finally fled to Saudi Arabia because remaining seemed largely fruitless and increasingly dangerous.

LEAD: ''This is unadulterated nonsense. The Census Bureau itself admitted that its 1980 count missed some 450,000 New Yorkers.'' - Mayor David N. Dinkins, reacting to the latest census figures. [A1:1.]

LEAD: In the first scientific results from the crippled Hubble Space Telescope, an unexpected concentration of stars, attracted by some mysterious force, has been discovered around what once appeared to be an ordinary galaxy, and a glowing ring of gaseous matter, equally surprising and puzzling, has been detected around the remnant of a star seen to explode three years ago.

LEAD: Among the hundreds of Americans who will be competing in the world championships beginning on Sunday in Geneva will be two who have a very short journey. Bill Russ and Irene Rothenberg are New Yorkers who have lived in Switzerland for many years and now represent that country.
LEAD: Eric Dickerson will miss the first six games of the National Football League season after the Indianapolis Colts placed him on one of the league's reserve lists yesterday.
LEAD: All winter and all spring, and part of the summer too, Lou Gorman looked for a starting pitcher.

LEAD: VIRTUALLY all building codes now require that the outlets in new and remodeled kitchens, bathrooms and garages be protected by a ground-fault circuit interrupter, usually called a G.F.C.I. or G.F.I. This protection is recommended for all outlets in damp locations. A G.F.C.I. protects you from shock by shutting off the power to an outlet when it detects a leak in the flow of electricity, as when a faulty appliance or cord touches a wet floor.

LEAD: Karen Finley, a performance artist who was recently denied a grant by the National Endowment for the Arts, has withdrawn as a host of this year's Bessie Awards ceremony because one of the event's sponsors is a supporter of Senator Jesse Helms.

LEAD: Roger L. Werner Jr., the president and chief executive of ESPN, is leaving the cable sports service to become the president and chief executive of Prime Ventures Inc., a new company being formed by Bill Daniels, a leading cable entrepreneur.
LEAD: FOR those fanatics who like everything to match, a 20-month-old company in St. Louis called Dyeing to Please might be a dream come true.
LEAD: The Emergency Medical Service began taking trauma patients to the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center again yesterday, ending a five-day suspension.

LEAD: The Kremlin moved ever closer in spirit to the White House today as President Bush's chief of staff worked within on the Soviet ''paper flow,'' and a tent city of disgruntled citizens maintained its encampment in a park just across the way.

LEAD: The new production of Leos Janacek's ''From the House of the Dead,'' unveiled on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, amounts to Christopher Keene's calling card as the new general director of the New York City Opera. It is the first new production - indeed, the first opera - he has conducted since he took over the company in

LEAD: A Federal court has cleared the way for the Meredith Corporation to sell its printing business to the R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company for $568 million, but the Government has appealed the ruling on antitrust grounds.

LEAD: The Swedish car maker Volvo said it would cut 5,000 jobs this year and next because profits in the first six months of 1990 have declined by half. The company has already dropped 1,000 employees in the car and truck sector this year and plans to reduce the work force by another 4,000 through 1991.
LEAD: The projected value of United States farm exports this year is holding steady at $40 billion despite a decline in the volume of wheat shipments, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday.

LEAD: Oil prices fell sharply yesterday as traders responded to the decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to allow an immediate increase in oil production, as well as to reduced fears of war in the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: THE Contel Corporation, which earlier this month signed a definitive agreement to be purchased by the GTE Corporation, provides another example of a company forced into a deal at least in part because of debt it took on to make acquisitions.
LEAD: CBS yesterday named Johnathan Rodgers president of its television stations division, replacing Eric W. Ober, who was named president of CBS News last week.
LEAD: The chairman of the Ameritrust Corporation, which reported big losses in the first half of this year, has resigned, the bank holding company said on Tuesday.
LEAD: Something there is that doesn't love a dictator - and that something may be television.

LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino reversed a long-held policy today and said she was willing to negotiate cease-fires with Communist guerrillas and with rebel soldiers who have staged coup attempts against her.
LEAD: Football

LEAD: Despite denials just a day earlier, the Bank of Japan said this morning that it was raising its discount rate for the fifth time in a little more than a year. The new rate is 6 percent, from 5.25 percent, effective today.

LEAD: Their winning streaks have been so rare and so sporadic this summer that in times like these, when the Yankees are finally playing well in their tiresome season, they are enjoying the luxury of looking forward.

LEAD: Gilbert Lesser, a designer of theater posters and a former promotion director for Life magazine, died on Tuesday at the Milstein Hospital of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: It's so quiet out there on the courts that Martina Navratilova hears every syllable the umpire utters, Monica Seles has felt it incumbent upon her to smother her grunts, and Goran Ivanisevic has discovered that it's the odor of the hamburgers and hot dogs sizzling atop the vendors' grills that really distracts him from playing his best tennis.
LEAD: Harris Levin, a lawyer who specialized in bankruptcy law, died yesterday at Franklin Medical Center in Valley Stream, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

LEAD: An article on Monday about financial disclosures by Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the independent candidate for governor in Connecticut, misidentified his grandfather. The grandfather was not E. R. Squibb but Theodore Weicker, one of three partners who founded the Squibb Corporation.

LEAD: In a shock to the computer industry, a virtually unknown California inventor has been issued a patent that he says covers a fundamental development of the computer revolution - the microprocessor.

LEAD: Jennifer Capriati came out to play tennis Tuesday evening wearing a white shirt with polka dots as orange as pumpkins. Her short tennis skirt was also white, and with three polka dots, all on the right side. Her brown ponytail was caught up in a band, which was orange. When she prepared to serve, in the course of her first-round match against Anke Huber of West Germany in the United States Open at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Capriati slid a second ball under her skirt at the left hip.
LEAD: If the rest of the races at Belmont Park this fall are anything like those on yesterday's opening card, the meeting is going to seem a lot longer than 54 days.

LEAD: Three thousand people have been called as prospective jurors for the September trial of a man charged in the slayings of 11 women. The man, Arthur J. Shawcross, 45 years old, will be tried in Monroe County in the murders of 10 of the women. He faces a second trial in neighboring Wayne County in the 11th slaying.
LEAD: Litton Industries' fourth-quarter earnings fell 2 percent despite higher sales, the company said today.

LEAD: Concerned about the huge potential for fraud and abuse in the savings and loan bailout, the Government agency managing the rescue effort will name an overseer within the agency to ferret out corruption among Federal officials and private firms managing the assets of failed institutions.

LEAD: Consumer Confidence Down Two major indexes of consumer confidence plunged sharply this month, indicating that the economy may be sliding into recession. Page D1. Japan Raises Interest Rate The Bank of Japan raised its discount rate, which it charges commercial banks, to 6 percent from 5.25 percent to fight inflation.

LEAD: Mark di Suvero's career has had its share of spectacular moments, but the American sculptor has never had an opportunity like the one he has been presented with this summer. He has essentially been given a city in which to showcase all the facets of his art.

LEAD: Sometimes homeowners go through the prudent steps of obtaining three or four bids for pruning or cutting large trees and find that one estimate is significantly lower than the others. It would seem sensible to accept the low bid, the National Arborist Association says, but only if the tree contractor can show proof of liability insurance.

LEAD: Campbell-Mithun-Esty Detroit has split its account management team into two parts. One group will serve the agency's primary client, Chrysler Jeep Eagle. The other will try to find new accounts.
LEAD: Beginning Saturday, for the first time the United States will have a single data base to identify incompetent doctors, dentists and other licensed health practitioners.

LEAD: Resorts International Inc. announced yesterday that a Federal Bankruptcy Court in New Jersey had approved its plan to emerge from bankruptcy law protection. In a separate move, the company said it had named Jack O'Donnell, the former president and chief operating officer of the Trump Plaza hotel and casino in Atlantic City, as executive vice president and chief operating officer of Resorts' Atlantic

LEAD: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is trying to smooth the way for development of a huge office tower on Madison Avenue as a necessary first step in its efforts to buy Grand Central Terminal and begin a $400 million renovation of the mid-Manhattan landmark.

LEAD: WHEN Brian Clarke was an art student, he was shown some photographic slides that a teacher had made on a vacation in Italy. A few tourists had wandered into the frames and were dwarfed by the great frescoes.

LEAD: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said on Tuesday that the drilling of test wells in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge should be considered in response to the situation in the Middle East.

LEAD: * Warner-Lambert Co., Morris Plains, N.J., to J. Walter Thompson, New York, for their new Medi-Flu flu reliever. Billings were not disclosed.
