LEAD: Yields of tax-exempts and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

LEAD: Tom Trebelhorn, whose job was rumored to be in jeopardy, will continue as manager of the Milwaukee Brewers. In an interview with The Milwaukee Journal on Tuesday night, Harry Dalton, Milwaukee's general manager, said the Brewers would honor Trebelhorn's contract, which runs through the 1991 season.

LEAD: There are certain pieces in the Mozart canon that make us wonder whether Mr. Kochel's chronological catalogue may not have taken a wrong turn or two. How, for instance, could so vast and operatic a piano concerto as the E-flat (K. 271) have appeared as early as Mozart's 22d year and how possibly could the great Sinfonia Concertante for Violin and

LEAD: A Federal appeals court today overturned a $5.2 million libel award to the singer Wayne Newton against the National Broadcasting Company, ruling that the network's news reports suggesting links between Mr. Newton and organized crime had not been shown to be deliberately or recklessly false.

LEAD: I. A. Lewis, who in the late 1960's was one of the first poll takers to predict election results by surveying voters leaving polling places, died Aug. 18 at the Glendale Adventist Medical Center in California. He was 68 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

LEAD: The European, a weekly newspaper begun in May, exceeded the circulation guaranteed to advertisers in June and July, its publisher, Robert Maxwell, said this week. Mr. Maxwell said weekly sales were estimated to be 360,000 in June and 340,000 in July. Advertisers had been guaranteed circulation of 225,000, Mr.

LEAD: International passengers at 15 airports in the United States routinely waited two hours or more to clear customs this summer, the president of an airline trade association says, calling for action by the Government to correct the problem.

LEAD: When Mark Bavaro underwent reconstructive surgery on his left knee in January, the Giants hoped he would be ready for the season opener 10 nights from now against the Philadelphia Eagles. At this stage, it appears the former All-Pro tight end will be ready, but perhaps not for a full game.
LEAD: Dizzy Gillespie's Be-Bop
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Norman Richard DeHaan, a Chicago architect and interior designer, died at Passavant Hospital in Chicago on Aug. 24. He was 63 years old.

LEAD: Robert H. Phillips, a photographer whose work has appeared in the nation's leading magazines and is in the photography collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art, died last Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 64 years old.
LEAD: Friday HAVEL'S 'TEMPTATION'

LEAD: An article on Monday about Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr.'s comments on the Church Universal and Triumphant referred incorrectly to its bomb shelters in a mountainside in Montana. The shelters are not known to be stocked with automatic weapons.
LEAD: If Iraq has a good face that it wants to show to the world, then Tariq Aziz is the man to do it.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums CENTRAL PARK ZOO, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday to Friday (until 8 P.M. on Tuesday) and 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. on weekends; gift shop and cafeteria are open the same hours. Admission: children under 3, free; ages 3 to 12, 25 cents; 65 and older, 50 cents; others, $1. Information: 861-6030.

LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said its engineering applications group would phase out of the business of developing electronic design automation software, which allows the computerized design of chips and circuit boards. The group will now concentrate on developing mechanical engineering and data-management software.

LEAD: For all the coaches, trainers, physiotherapists, psychotherapists and other experts who travel the world in care of this tennis player or that one, few members of the entourage ever attain the profile of the dad whose offspring has suddenly exploded into the public consciousness.
LEAD: Baseball
LEAD: Lunch Afloat
LEAD: Negotiations over a contract extension for Lawrence Taylor stalled today, and Joe Courrege, Taylor's agent, said the Giants had given him permission to shop Taylor to other teams.
LEAD: The Yankees may have been at the center of trade rumors in recent weeks, but when August turns to September at midnight Friday, they will probably still not have made a deal.

LEAD: ''No Futuro - Rodrigo D'' (''No Future - Rodrigo D''), a 1990 film by the Colombian director Victor Gaviria, and ''Papeles Secondarios'' (''Bit Parts''), a 1989 Cuban film directed by Orlando Rojas, shared the award for best feature film at the Festival Latino Film Awards, presented last night at the World Wide Plaza Cineplex Odeon Theater.
LEAD: After following more than 2,000 leads, interviewing dozens of suspects and consulting astrologers, the police are tempering their approach to tracking the so-called Zodiac gunman.

LEAD: One of three armed men who led the police on a car chase through the Upper West Side of Manhattan was shot and killed last night by officers while trying to flee into a subway tunnel, the police said.

LEAD: Yannick Noah left the stadium court at the United States Open yesterday with his head bowed, a meek position he has been assuming on a weekly basis this year not because he has become a devout churchgoer, but because he has become a dependable loser.

LEAD: Mao Zedong's image was one of half-emperor and half-god in the days when he presided as Great Helmsman of nearly one-quarter of humanity. But now it turns out that his wife could reduce him to tears.

LEAD: THE Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and the subsequent plunge in stock market prices, drew a surprisingly muted reaction from mutual fund investors, several mutual fund companies said yesterday. Some managers said investors even stepped up their purchases of stock funds.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Sharon Bonnie Muhlstock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Muhlstock of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Neil Sheinker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Sheinker of Montville, N.J. Rabbi Philmore Berger performed the ceremony at Temple Avodah in Oceanside, L.I.
LEAD: * Canadian Airlines to Chiat/Day/ Mojo, Toronto, with a budget of $25 million.

LEAD: The Federal judge presiding over the payola and racketeering trial of the record promoter Joseph Isgro and two other defendants ruled today that the Federal prosecutors had violated rules of evidence in the case by withholding a key document from a grand jury and defense lawyers.

LEAD: Roger Clemens became a 20-game winner tonight for the third time as the Boston Red Sox scored seven runs in the ninth inning and beat the Cleveland Indians, 9-2, for their seventh consecutive victory.
LEAD: It began like a paparazzi of angels popping flashbulbs in the sky: the electric storm that swept into New York City just after midnight Tuesday, one of the season's grandest shows.
LEAD: HOSTAGES LOSE JOBS: A Texas oil company has cut off pay to the families of six of its workers who are being held hostage in the Persian Gulf. National news, page A18.

LEAD: The New York Urban League's board has appointed DENNIS M. WALCOTT as its president and chief executive. Mr. Walcott had been executive director of Harlem Dowling-Westside Center for Children and Family Services, a voluntary welfare agency. Before that he was associate director at the Greater New York Fund/United Way.

LEAD: The financial markets here reacted positively to Thursday's increase in the Bank of Japan's discount rate, but a number of economists warned that it was unlikely to be the last such jump in Japanese interest rates because of growing inflationary pressures.

LEAD: In drawing up the burden-sharing plan announced today by President Bush to help sustain United States forces in the Persian Gulf, the Administration was mindful that the American people and Congress might become impatient with a drawn-out crisis, State Department officials said.
LEAD: Charles Shackleford, who spent two troubled seasons with the Nets, was waived at his request yesterday and will play in the Italian League this season.

LEAD: In the heyday of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver, its officials and major borrowers contributed more than $1 million to politicians in both parties. Now officeholders and national Republican and Democratic officials are looking for a way to get rid of the money, which they regard as a curse.

LEAD: The newly elected board of the Comprehensive Care Corporation yesterday appointed James Carmany as president and chief executive of the St. Louis-based provider of programs to treat chemical dependency.

LEAD: Monday is Labor Day. Here are holiday schedules: NEW YORK Parade: Begins at 11 A.M. at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street and heads north to 72 Street. Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that Europeans were in danger of losing the global military protection of the United States unless they took a broader view of their security interests than they have in the Persian Gulf crisis.
LEAD: Commissioner Fay Vincent is reviewing a complaint about the National League president Bill White's criticism of the umpire Joe West.

LEAD: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today that the Bush Administration was responding to the Persian Gulf crisis with a ''short-term strategy'' for stabilizing oil markets by raising domestic production and encouraging conservation. It will not speed up a new national energy policy now being developed, he said.
LEAD: Representatives of 13 of the 21 Arab League members met here tonight to seek a way to avoid war with Iraq.

LEAD: Morgan Stanley & Company has been selling a large number of ''junk bonds'' as part of a liquidation of a portfolio of these high-yield, high-risk securities. The selling has some traders worried that similar funds might also have to sell bonds.

LEAD: Shuttle Delayed Again The space agency again delayed the launching of the space shuttle Columbia, this time so that technicians can repair a part on the observatory in the shuttle's payload bay. Page A20. Tornado Alert: An Inquiry Deadly Illinois tornadoes had already struck before a warning was issued, prompting an inquiry into the effectiveness of the National Weather Service's alert system.
LEAD: * J. Walter Thompson's New York office has created a new campaign for the Council of Independent Colleges that promotes small colleges and focuses on minority students.

LEAD: Dr. John K. Frost, a physician and researcher who specialized in early detection and diagnosis of lung cancer, died on Wednesday at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 68 years old and lived in Brooklandville, Md.

LEAD: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a biotechnology company, said Pierre Cardin, the French designer, would reacquire the worldwide rights to his fragrance trademark and brands from the company. No terms were disclosed.
LEAD: Two advances in tracing the cause of a mysterious blood and muscle disorder linked to consumption of the food supplement L-tryptophan were reported yesterday by Federal health officials.

LEAD: Dr. Paul P. Casamassimo, a retired dentist who was on the staff of the North Central Bronx Hospital for almost 50 years, died on Monday at Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Mel Stottlemyre, uncomfortable in trying to be both diplomatic and enthusiastic, stood on the steps of the dugout at Shea Stadium yesterday and answered one awkward question after another.

LEAD: When Mayor David Dinkins of New York appointed a commission in April to investigate a black boycott of two Korean grocery stores in Brooklyn's Flatbush section, cynics suggested the move was merely a device to diffuse responsibility for an intolerable display of racism. The commission's report, issued yesterday, makes even the cynics look starry-eyed.

LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest automobile manufacturer, plans to triple the sales of its non-automotive divisions by 1994, Masami Iwasaki, an executive vice president, said. He also said Toyota's consolidated profit had risen 27.4 percent in its latest fiscal year.

LEAD: FOR quite some weeks now, visitors to New York have been asking, ''What's new in the museums?'' And what have they heard, all too often, from host and hostess alike? ''Oh, nothing much. Just the permanent collection.'' So they decide that it's quite all right to give the museums a miss.
LEAD: Lillian Pickard, a theater and television press agent, died yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center. She was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Federal Government is an adroit procrastinator, ever ready to postpone such routine chores as balancing the budget. If Uncle Sam saw a therapist, he would surely be told that the habit is self-destructive.

LEAD: To some, the measure of a man's life is the length of his obituary. By that standard, Jack Lipson's legacy, like his life, was short. When he died of a heart attack last November at 45 years old, he rated only a few column inches of print.

LEAD: Herbert C. Johnson, retired chairman and president of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten Island. He was 81 years old and lived in Dongan Hills, S.I.
LEAD: Opportunities for creative non-labor in the three-state region this holiday weekend include gazing, giggling, browsing, buying, hurling, and making ice cream.

LEAD: Things had gone so well for the Yankees that they almost could not have expected this: a rough night, an end to their winning streak, two errant throws by Dave LaPoint and a sudden lack of offense.

LEAD: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 10.00 10.00 10.50 DISCOUNT RATE 7.00 7.00 7.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 8.00 8.00 8.87 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 7.44 7.47 7.90 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 7.40 7.44 7.78 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 8.74 8.71 8.29 30-YR.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The space agency late tonight delayed the launching of the space shuttle Columbia for at least four days to repair a broken part on its astronomical payload.

LEAD: BRASH and booming Thailand, which has been enjoying some of the world's highest growth rates in the last few years, has suffered something of a nervous breakdown this month, as the shock waves set off by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq have ricocheted around the world.

LEAD: The complaints of New York City about undercounting in the 1990 census figures grew to a chorus today as officials from cities and states across the country argued that they, too, were underrepresented in the preliminary data.
LEAD: Mullen Advertising Inc., Wenham, Mass., scored a victory and a loss yesterday.
LEAD: Sega of America, a maker of video games, will begin a campaign next week that takes a hit at rival Nintendo of America.
LEAD: In the Footsteps of 'Sarafina!'

LEAD: Faced with Washington's wrath, Japan stopped some of its hemming and hawing yesterday and pledged at least $1 billion for the multilateral effort in the Persian Gulf. But regrettably, Tokyo remains vague about its promises to help beleaguered front-line gulf states.

LEAD: Two powerful explosions ripped through an army barracks belonging to Gen. Michel Aoun east of here overnight, killing 10 soldiers and wounding 30 others, as warring Christian factions battled with mortar guns and tanks, shattering a three-month cease-fire, security officials said.
LEAD: ''We're more than willing to bear our fair share of the burden, but we also expect others to bear their fair share.'' - President Bush. [A1:6.]

LEAD: On a tropical Monday evening in late August, when many restaurants in town are so quiet they could double as library annexes, Lola on West 22d Street resembles a Club Med social. To the background of a blues pianist, the buoyant, well-dressed crowd gets louder in direct proportion to the wine and tropical cocktails consumed.
LEAD: Dan Rooney, president of the Pittsburgh Steelers, was given the Pete Rozelle Award yesterday, the second annual presentation of an award in recognition of service to the N.F.L. (AP)

LEAD: Wholesale gasoline prices surged yesterday, reflecting traders' concerns about low supplies and strong demand. Crude oil prices also rose, with the contract for October delivery up 85 cents a barrel, or 3.3 percent, to $26.77 on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

LEAD: Officials at the International Energy Agency, which represents 21 oil-consuming nations, predict that a substantial oil shortage will develop late this year. At present, however, daily worldwide demand for oil is only slightly greater than supply, despite the embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude.
LEAD: Dance Theater Workshop announced yesterday that it would hold its seventh annual Bessie Awards ceremony as planned, despite the withdrawal of Karen Finley as a host.
LEAD: * American Express Publishing Corp., a subsidiary of American Express Co., appointed Tracey Crane-Hennessy manager of its Midwest office in Chicago.
LEAD: Alice Pentlarge Loeb, a writer and producer, died Friday at her home in Baltimore. She was 95 years old.

LEAD: Picture a company with a patchwork of ownership interests in assets collectively worth $20 billion, assets that range from unglamorous textile and paper mills to trophy holdings like the Seattle Mariners major league baseball team. Just when some of those investments are due to be turned into cash, unrest in the Middle East sends oil prices soaring and threatens to usher in a recession.

LEAD: DeWitt Stetten Jr., a biochemist and former deputy director of the National Institutes of Health who in the 1970's headed a committee that drafted guidelines on genetic engineering, died Tuesday at the Fernwood Nursing Center in Bethesda, Md. He was 81 years old.
LEAD: There are two major stakes races at Belmont Park this holiday weekend, and for the first time Belmont bettors will also be able to watch and play two other important out-of-town races.

LEAD: Asserting that the ''shape of the post-cold-war world'' was at issue in the Persian Gulf crisis, President Bush said today that he was asking other countries to help pay the multibillion-dollar cost of military operations and economic sanctions in the region.
LEAD: Doug Williams, the only black quarterback to start in the Super Bowl, says that racism is still common in the National Football League.

LEAD: As the dead are buried after South Africa's newest convulsion of violence, the tallies of destruction have been complemented by another consideration: the fighting showed more the limits than the strengths of those contending for leadership in this country. For Chief Mangosuthu
LEAD: Gary Watson was named yesterday as president of a newly consolidated newspaper group at the Gannett Company, effective Oct. 1.
LEAD: New York City began a statistical, legal and political counterattack yesterday in an effort to prove that it is much bigger than preliminary figures from the Census Bureau show.

LEAD: DIANA RIGG, the British actress who rose to stardom as the karate-chopping Emma Peal in the television series ''The Avengers,'' is seeking a divorce from Archie Stirling. An Associated Press dispatch from London said her agent, Jean Diamond, declined to comment on the reasons for the decision.

LEAD: Providing troubling evidence that the savings and loan deterioration is worsening, the Government reported today that even the healthiest segment of the industry has sharply declined in the last three months.

LEAD: The Philadelphia Eagles yesterday waived Dave Rimington, an eight-year center who was a two-time Outland Trophy winner at Nebraska and a first-round draft pick by the Bengals in 1983. Cincinnati waived him during the 1988 preseason, after which he was signed by the Eagles. He started every game in 1988, but he started just one regular-season game last season.

LEAD: Tornadoes that killed dozens of people had already touched down in the Chicago area this week before the National Weather Service issued a warning. Now, throughout the Middle West, where spring and summer mean the season of tornadoes, people are questioning the warning system's performance.

LEAD: Among New York's veteran cabaret performers, Barbara Lea is the only one of note who continues to carry on a sultry Southern-flavored pop-jazz tradition popularized by Ethel Waters and embellished by Mildred Bailey, Connee Boswell and Lee Wiley. Like her forerunners, Miss Lea is understated when it comes to dramatizing song lyrics.

LEAD: The Alleghany Corporation, the New York-based financial services concern, has raised its stake in Cyclops Industries, the Pittsburgh-based steel company, to 10.7 percent, from 8.4 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Alleghany said it might acquire more Cyclops shares, depending upon market conditions, or it might seek to dispose of its stock.

LEAD: Iraq has been avoiding military actions that could provide the United States with the justification for a strike at Iraqi forces, senior American military officials say. They say that Baghdad instead appears to be trying to turn the crisis here into an endurance contest.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's use of state aircraft referred incorrectly to payment for trips that are partly political or unofficial. During campaigns, his campaign committee or the State Democratic Party will pay at least half the cost on any day that involves such activity.

LEAD: ''Actually, we're practicing great economy of motion here,'' said Olga Bloom, the founder of Bargemusic Ltd. Since 1977, Mrs. Bloom has been presenting weekly concerts in the refurbished coffee barge that she transformed into a floating concert hall on the Brooklyn side of the East River, near the Brooklyn

LEAD: Two exponents of hard bop, the tenor saxophonist Jimmy Heath and the trumpeter Donald Byrd, will perform in a free concert tonight closing Jazzmobile's 26th summer season of performances by outstanding jazz musicians in New York City streets.

LEAD: The new Government of Soviet Armenia said today that it had faced down and disarmed the leaders and scores of guerrillas of a vigilante group that has alarmed the republic with factional violence.
LEAD: Sexual Anarchy Gender and Culture at the Fin de Siecle By Elaine Showalter 242 pages. Viking. $19.95.

LEAD: Susan Buchner Rauch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Rauch of Hewlett, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Howard Epstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Epstein of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Mark Wittstein and Cantor Howard Stahl officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, conducted Wednesday in Baghdad by Dan Rather of CBS News, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

LEAD: Always more inclined to spend money on the campaigns of proven winners than on risky newcomers, political action committees have donated 12 times as much to incumbents as to challengers in this year's Congressional elections, said a study made public today.

LEAD: Ever since the U.S. Open tennis tournament moved from the staid West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills to the bigger, brasher complex in Flushing Meadows 13 years ago, it has been difficult to balance the populism of the New York crowd with the gentle traditions of tennis.
LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation opened a diner-style restaurant here last week that is in sharp contrast to its fast-food outlets.

LEAD: An agreement between Mohawk Indians and the national and Quebec Governments to dismantle barricades across a main bridge in Montreal fell apart today as Indian leaders complained of continued harassment by the police.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Tonight's edition of ''20/20'' at 10 on ABC is given entirely to ''Depression: Beyond the Darkness,'' a report on a still mysterious illness that takes different forms and may affect 20 million Americans a year. It's an informative hour. Through interviews with sufferers and their doctors, the program describes the main forms of therapy now being used to control an often incapacitating affliction that sometimes ends in suicide.

LEAD: An Army soldier who served in the United States invasion of Panama went on trial this week, charged with murdering a Panamanian, in a case that raises the question of what justifies the use of deadly force in combat. It is the first such court-martial since the Vietnam War.

LEAD: Perrier mineral water, having weathered a storm early this year about contamination of its water, now faces another blow: bowing to government pressure, it can no longer call its water ''naturally carbonated.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The California Supreme Court will allow two passengers who witnessed a fatal accident aboard a park tramway ride to bring a civil lawsuit because they say they suffered emotional trauma from what they saw.
LEAD: The Rev. Allan J. Burry, a Methodist minister and an official with the campus ministry section of the United Methodist Church, died Tuesday at his home in Nashville, Tenn. He was 56 years old.

LEAD: The question was never whether Marvin Graves was going to be the starting quarterback at Syracuse University, not after his displays of arm strength on the practice field and his willingness to spend hours as a student of the game. The only question was when. And the bold answer is now. Dick MacPherson, the coach of the Orangemen, selected Graves, a freshman in his second year with the Syracuse program, over Mark McDonald, a junior, as the starter against Southern California on Friday night.

LEAD: Dennis O'Connor stood out in a company of fine dancers when he performed with the Merce Cunningham troupe in the late 1980's. And gifts as a dancer are among the foremost delights of Mr. O'Connor's ''Renaissance Solos,'' at the atmospheric little Gas Station theater tonight. But in this promising first independent program as a choreographer, Mr.

LEAD: Lisa Ellen Lieb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morrie Lieb of Cliffside Park, N.J., was married yesterday to David Neal Malamed, the son of Bernice Malamed of Lynbrook, L.I., and Paul Malamed of Brooklyn. Rabbi Philmore Berger performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck in Kings Point, L.I.

LEAD: Iraq moved some of its hostage women and children from outlying areas where they had been placed at potential military targets into Baghdad today, apparently in preparation for their being allowed to leave the country.

LEAD: WITH the East Village to the north and SoHo to the south, Houston Street is downtown's great divide. As wide as a river, it has sprawling four-way intersections that dwarf the twinkling traffic lights above. The most interesting storefront is actually a lot stocked with funky secondhand furniture.

LEAD: TOMORROW NEW YORK RENAISSANCE FESTIVAL, Sterling Forest, Tuxedo, N.Y. Storytelling, puppet shows, rides, crafts demonstrations. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission, $12.50 ($10.50 for the elderly; $5 for those 6- to 12-year-olds; free for those under 6. Weekends through Sept. 16.
LEAD: After a five-hour session this week to paper over differences, Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin appeared for 15 minutes together on Soviet television.

LEAD: Prime Minister Petre Roman wants very much to come to Washington this autumn and has let the Bush Administration know of this desire. But so far, the Romanian official has received no positive response.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 520 money market mutual funds decreased $542.2 million, to $407.45 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 162 institutional funds decreased by $772.5 million, to $98.7 billion. The assets of the 253 general-purpose funds were up by $931.9 million, to $143.38 billion.
LEAD: New York City bgan a statistical, legal and political counterattack to prove that there are more New Yorkers than the Census Bureau's figures indicates.

LEAD: A committee appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins to investigate the bitter black-led boycott of two Korean-owned grocery stores in Brooklyn released its final report yesterday and criticized the Brooklyn District Attorney for moving too slowly in the emotionally charged case.
LEAD: An article and a map yesterday about the 1990 census referred incorrectly in some copies to the percentage increase in Texas' population.
LEAD: WEIGHT WATCHERS INTERNATIONAL will start a yearlong national television campaign next week for its weight-loss programs, again using its pursuasive selling tool - Lynn Redgrave.

LEAD: A New Yorker who begins her day with the astrology column and spends much of it knocking on wood went out looking for omens recently. The weather was fine, too fine for anyone to be stuck in an office, and she was in search of something that would tell her to go home. She found that something. Thrice.

LEAD: In a ''binding declaration'' that will be recorded in the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty, Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher of West Germany said today that a united Germany would limit its ground and air forces to 345,000.

LEAD: President Najibullah of Afghanistan made it clear here today that he did not see himself as a barrier to a political solution in Afghanistan and was not prepared to give up effective powers to a transitional government in Kabul.
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about Donald J. Trump misstated the portion of a $65 million bank loan package that was for interest payments on one of his casino bonds.

LEAD: When office workers dunk a lonely tea bag in a paper cup or a ceramic mug of hot water, they are participating in a tradition that modern life has reduced to the barest essentials. In the good old days, especially in 18th- and 19th-century England at the high end of the social scale, afternoon tea was a ritual of considerable substance and extensive accessories.

LEAD: Dan Rather, the CBS News anchor, said yesterday that several weeks of dogged contact with Iraqi officials paid off on Wednesday night in Baghdad when an armed Iraqi soldier awakened him in his hotel room and escorted him to the presidential palace, where he interviewed President Saddam Hussein. It was the President's first interview by an American jounralist since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug.

LEAD: Bruce Coslet, the Jets' rookie head coach, went into tonight's final preseason game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers with some answers that needed to be questioned before putting his new team in the jeopardy of the regular season.
LEAD: Larry Jackson, who pitched for three National League teams and was named to three All-Star teams, died of cancer Tuesday. He was 59 years old.
LEAD: Because political power drains from places where population has been lost, New York City and western New York may bear the worst political consequences of the 1990 census of New York State.
LEAD: The National Football League, upon determining that the changes made to shorten the length of games had gone too far, yesterday announced a modification of the timing procedure after kickoffs.

LEAD: Here on the fishing docks in this seaside village near the Rhode Island border, stacks of empty lobster traps bake like driftwood in the noonday sun. ''Must mean people are buying lobster, else they wouldn't be empty,'' said Arthur Medeiros, the captain of the Rosemary R., a 40-foot dragger that combs Fishers Island Sound and Little Narragansett Bay.
LEAD: A reduction in the Federal capital gains tax ''could not be counted on'' to increase American economic growth significantly, the Congressional Budget Office said today.

LEAD: International A2-14 The cost of the military operations in the Persian Gulf should be shared by other countries, including West Germany, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Japan and South Korea, President Bush said. Page A1 Japan pledged $1 billion in aid to help pay for the military build up against Iraq.
LEAD: The Army is behind schedule and over budget in its destruction of old chemical weapons, but Congress shares blame for some of the problems, the General Accounting Office says.
LEAD: Spies and Presidents From the Kremlin to the White House.

LEAD: After three weeks of quietly tolerating the buildup of United States military forces in the Persian Gulf, Soviet officials sharply challenged the American presence today and questioned whether it might be intended as a permanent foothold in the region.

LEAD: The Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons disclosed today that he had raised his stake in Lockheed Corporation to 19.8 percent, as high as he can without triggering the company's ''poison pill'' anti-takeover plan.

LEAD: Luigi Beccali, a prominent and popular long-distance runner in the 1930's and the gold medalist in the 1,500-meter run at the 1932 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, died of natural causes Tuesday in Rafaello, Italy. He was 83 years old.
LEAD: Emmet V. Murray, a lawyer who had retired from the Caltex Petroleum Company, died yesterday at his home in Quogue, L.I. He was 64 years old and also lived in Gulf Stream, Fla.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday. An 85-cent rise in oil prices, to $26.77 a barrel, helped persuade bond traders to sell securities, but anticipation that the Federal Reserve Board might be on the verge of easing monetary policy helped push up prices of shorter-term notes and bills.
LEAD: Latin America's foreign debt climbed last year despite efforts to curb it, according to a study that says the debtor nations failed to honor $18 billion in financial obligations.
LEAD: Government troops evacuated more than 40 wounded soldiers from a camp beseiged by Tamil rebel forces, a top military official said today.

LEAD: EVERY Labor Day weekend, geography warps to place New York City unmistakably in the Caribbean. This weekend brings a West Indian carnival tonight through Monday in Brooklyn, featuring calypso, steel-band and reggae music; a major salsa concert on Sunday at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., and a marathon of Dominican merengue tonight at Roseland in Manhattan.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: A hitch has emerged that might derail plans for an early Presidential primary in California, despite the support of both national political parties and the agreement of California's legislative leadership and Gov. George Deukmejian.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington today, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: OPENING STATEMENT

LEAD: Chile will formally bury former President Salvador Allende Gossens next week in a ceremony that has revived the controversies surrounding his Government and his death in a military coup nearly 17 years ago.

LEAD: New results from tests of an AIDS drug, DDI, show that it continues to protect some patients from progression to AIDS for 15 months or more, and that most of its toxic effects can be avoided, said a study released today.
LEAD: Stocks fell yesterday in the slowest trading in three months as many investors lightened their holdings before the Labor Day weekend.

LEAD: In a move to take advantage of the current boom in the gold industry, the Newmont Mining Corporation, the large gold mining concern that is 49 percent owned by Hanson P.L.C. of Britain, said yesterday that it plans to sell 3.6 million new common shares in a public offering.
LEAD: A 30-year-old Bronx prosecutor was shot to death yesterday as he bent over to pick up a dozen doughnuts in a bodega near the county courthouse.

LEAD: The president of Brazil's central bank announced today that the country would not make any payment this year on overdue interest owed on its $114 billion foreign debt, the largest in the developing world.

LEAD: Paul Zukofsky will conduct musicians from the Juilliard School in Stravinsky's ''Fanfare for a New Theater'' (1964), ''Epitaphium'' (1959), ''Orpheus'' (1948) and Symphony in C (1940) at the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art, 14 West 54th Street, tonight at 7:30. The program will be repeated tomorrow evening at 7:30.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Vander L. Beatty, a flamboyant former State Senator who was convicted of vote fraud after he ran for Congress in 1982, was shot and killed yesterday in his storefront campaign headquarters in Brooklyn.
LEAD: Preliminary census figures show Essex County, where the population of Newark and East Orange dropped sharply, being surpassed as the state's most populous county by suburban Bergen County.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Saying the Persian Gulf conflict has eliminated its only source of income, a Texas company has cut off paychecks to the families of six oil workers who are hostages of the Iraqi Government.

LEAD: SERGEI N. KHRUSHCHEV, son of the deposed Soviet leader, is to spend a month this fall at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University in Boston. Theresa Donovan, a spokeswoman for the school, said Mr. Khrushchev, a 55-year-old engineer, would use the libraries and talk to the faculty while conducting research for his second book, the theme of which has not been disclosed.
LEAD: * Leslie Beal has been promoted to assistant media planner at Martin Williams Advertising Inc., Minneapolis.

LEAD: THE OIL JOLT The Administration has a ''short-term strategy'' for stabilizing oil markets by raising domestic production and encouraging conservation, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said. It will not speed up a new national energy policy, he said. [Page A1.] Wholesale gasoline prices surged, reflecting concerns about low supplies and strong demand.

LEAD: The Sutton Holding Corporation, a New York investment firm, said it was still interested in acquiring DeSoto Inc., even though the company was liquidating most of its assets and distributing the proceeds to shareholders. Since July, DeSoto has sold its industrial coating and solvent business to a unit of the Union Carbide Corporation for $200 million and its consumer-paint business to the Sherwin-Williams Company for $80 million.

LEAD: A man considered by officials in the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan to be a prime suspect in the disappearance of Etan Patz, pleaded not guilty yesterday to two charges of child molestation in Pennsylvania.

LEAD: The Government decided on Wednesday to investigate whether some equipment made by Japanese electronics companies is imported at less than fair value into the United States, threatening the domestic industry. The International Trade Commission ruled that there was reasonable indication that imports of some electronic display screens used in computers and their sub-assemblies materially injure the American industry.

LEAD: A decision by Japan to pledge $1 billion in aid for the military buildup against Iraq came after United States officials expressed unhappiness over the original package announced by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, American and Japanese officials said today.

LEAD: The infant mortality rate in the United States reached the lowest level ever last year, but it remains higher than those in many industrialized nations, Federal health officials reported yesterday.

LEAD: William J. Cibes Jr., the challenger in the Democratic primary for governor, was about an hour into his interview with a group of local newspaper editors when the question came. It was a long slow looper of a pitch that many politicians would have smacked clean over the fence: What was your childhood like, growing up in rural

LEAD: An instant after it's unleashed, the curveball looks like it's headed for the dugout instead of the plate. An instant after that, it's over the plate and the batter is ducking for the dugout. Sid Fernandez, the pitcher for the Mets who is equipped with one of the game's most deceptive and disabling fastballs, last night had that curveball magic.
LEAD: The deputy chairman of the British Petroleum Company said today that he expected the new OPEC production agreement to keep oil prices in the mid-$20's.

LEAD: Gov. Jim Florio has chosen a longtime friend and his closest political adviser for 16 years, Joseph C. Salema, as his new chief of staff, according to members of the Legislature who have been informed of the Governor's decision.

LEAD: Allison Kendall Sands, a daughter of Adrienne Sands of New York and Bruce A. Sands of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Evan Tamis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford H. LEAD: Brian Keenan, the Irish teacher who was released after four and a half years as a hostage in Lebanon, urged negotiations today for the release of remaining captives in Lebanon, with whom he formed an ''enduring and unbreakable bond'' during years in tiny basement cells.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the National Endowment for the Arts misstated the origin of an anti-obscenity pledge required by the agency from grant recipients. John E. Frohnmayer, the endowment chairman, instituted it last year after Congress amended the endowment's appropriation to prohibit Federal support for art considered obscene.

LEAD: Orders to factories for manufactured goods grew 1.6 percent in July, the Government reported today. But analysts said the fluctuating performance so far this year suggested an anemic industrial economy even before the Persian Gulf crisis.

LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation today formed a new consulting services business aimed at helping large corporate customers build complex computing systems using its products. The new group, Information

LEAD: Last year Americans reported 1.5 million cars stolen, a startling 42 percent increase since 1985. An expanding anti-theft program, pioneered in New York City, now offers car owners inexpensive protection against this epidemic.

LEAD: Edmund H. North, a screenwriter who shared an Academy Award with Francis Ford Coppola in 1970 for their script for ''Patton,'' died Tuesday in St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Brentwood, Calif.

LEAD: Gerald L. Norman, a retired administrative judge for the Workmen's Compensation Board, died on Sunday at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 78 years old and lived in Brooklyn. He died of lung cancer, his sister, Winifred L. Norman, said. Mr. Norman served as a judge for the Workmen's Compensation Board for several years before he retired in 1980.
LEAD: Opening With the Blues
LEAD: It doesn't seem fair.

LEAD: A growing number of experts are questioning the usefulness of the animal tests used to decide whether chemicals cause cancer. These animal tests, they say, can themselves cause conditions that give rise to malignancy.

LEAD: TRACK AND FIELD East German Woman Gets 2d Gold Katrin Krabbe of East Germany sprinted to her second gold medal by winning the women's 200 meters in 21.95 seconds at the European championships yesterday at Split, Yugoslavia. She won the 100-meter dash on Tuesday. The holder of the world record in the pole vault, Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union, lost his first major event in seven years when he failed to clear 19 feet 1/4 inch.

LEAD: The Trump Organization denied yesterday that the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan was being looked at by prospective buyers and might be sold within several months. But a person close to the organization repeated earlier statements that potential buyers had been shown the property.

LEAD: Since its infancy in the late 1960's, video art has had to contend with a contradiction. As art, it aspires to be taken seriously, but as a relative of television it needs to entertain. This may explain why some of the most memorable examples of early video art - William Wegman's tapes of his dog's deadpan performances, Vito Acconci's risque monologues - use humor as an esthetic device.

LEAD: From the top row of the tennis stadium, you absolutely cannot tell how much topspin is on the ball. But once the weather clears, you can surely see the New York skyline, shimmering a few miles to the west.

LEAD: Deloitte & Touche, the large accounting firm, has decided to thin its partnership ranks by as many as 100 people in the next few months, executive recruiters and others who specialize in the industry said yesterday.

LEAD: Leonard Marshall, one of the two holdout Giants, signed a three-year contract extension today worth $2.6 million. The signing came only hours after negotiations broke off between the Giants and the other absent defensive star, Lawrence Taylor.

LEAD: The police are searching for a retired correction officer and college classmate of Vander L. Beatty in connection with the fatal shooting of the former State Senator in his campaign headquarters in Brooklyn on Thursday.

LEAD: The two Germanys have signed their treaty of unification, the last major act of the German Democratic Republic before it disappears into a single Germany on Oct. 3. The question of its role in Europe, indeed the role of nation-states in Europe, becomes increasingly urgent as the countries to the East move on from the euphoria of freedom to the agony of transformation.
LEAD: Samuel Houston Mayes, the principal cellist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Philadelphia Orchestra for many years, died on Aug. 24 at his home in Mesa, Ariz. He was 73 years old.
LEAD: B'nai B'rith has a new two-year term president. On Wednesday, KENT E. SCHINER of Baltimore defeated RICHARD HEIDEMAN of Washington in close balloting at the group's convention in Dallas.

LEAD: Between the time ''The Lemon Sisters'' was scheduled to open, a year ago, and its actual opening yesterday, a story surfaced that this much worked-over film would be renamed so no one would make cheap remarks like, ''It's a lemon.'' Relax; you won't hear any bad lemon jokes here. Just imagine Diane Keaton at her most hysterical, as an asthmatic cat lover who returns from a stay in the hospital to find that her two best friends have thrown her a cat-free welcome-home party.

LEAD: Abdullah Ibrahim, the South African pianist, tells a story about a man who collected birds, among them a rare bird from Africa. When the collector planned a trip to Africa, he asked the bird if there was anything he could bring back. ''The best thing to do is to let me out of this cage,'' the bird said, but the man refused.

LEAD: Your name, address and telephone number are no longer yours to give out only as you choose. Direct marketers all over the nation have them and are using them with increasing intensity to sell products and services.

LEAD: Spring flowers - next spring's - should be on the minds of gardeners now. It's time to make planting plans and to order bulbs. All bulbs, including the three showiest, trumpet daffodils, tulips and hyacinths, must be planted over the next two months. Although most small-flowered species are grown in nursery fields, some bulbs are being dug from the Mediterranean region, which threatens their survival.

LEAD: * American International Group Inc., New York an insurance company, said it completed the acquisition of International Lease Finance Corp., Beverly Hills, Calif., a jet-aircraft leasing company. Each outstanding common share of International Lease was converted into the right to receive $32.50.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is preparing to transfer as much as $1 billion worth of advanced weapons to Israel to buttress the country's defenses against Iraq and address Israeli concerns about recent arms sales to Saudi Arabia, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: A Federal district judge has sentenced a key witness in the trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington to five years' probation on drug charges.

LEAD: Eileen B. Jaffe, a daughter of Mildred Goodman of Margate, N.J., and the late Morris Jaffe, was married yesterday to Richard Ekstract, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mack Ekstract of North Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at the bridegroom's home in East Hampton, L.I.
LEAD: Rebels have killed about 200 foreigners in Liberia whose governments contributed soldiers to a West African force sent to end the nation's civil war, the Ghana News Agency reported today.

LEAD: The World Bridge Championships beginning here on Sunday will be by far the biggest ever staged, thanks to the efforts of Jimmy Ortiz-Patino, former president of the World Bridge Federation, Jose Damiani, president of the European Bridge League, and many others. For the first time, almost all players can compete regardless of experience.

LEAD: With nine days to go before the football games in his rookie season as Jets head coach begin to count in the standing, Bruce Coslet still hasn't decided on a starting quarterback. Ken O'Brien? Tony Eason?

LEAD: John McEnroe, a fallen but not forgotten star, played one of the best matches of his latest comeback attempt last night to gain the round of 16 of the United States Open, a tournament he has won four times but not since 1984.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it plans to close two assembly plants for one week beginning Sept. 10 because of a shortage of dealer orders for the Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz cars made at the plants. Sales of the Topaz are off 21.9 percent so far this year compared with 1989, while sales of the nearly identical Tempo have fallen 1.5 percent in 1990.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about American acquisitions in Europe included an incorrect report from Translink's European Deal Review about a transaction between the GTE Corporation and Thorn Lighting in Britain. While GTE is discussing the acquisition of Thorn Lighting, no agreement has been reached.

LEAD: A new diplomatic effort to persuade Iraq to pull out of Kuwait began here today with five hours of talks between Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations, and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Johnny Bailey, a rookie running back with the Chicago Bears, rushed for 65 yards on 11 carries in a victory over Buffalo on Thursday night. Yesterday he found himself in the clear again when a judge in Houston released him from the final 10 months of a probation imposed on him in 1986.

LEAD: Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland are now vigorously competing to be the first to throw off their remaining Communist shackles and free their markets. In time, these steps will benefit them economically. More immediately, they'll help attract Western capital and assistance.

LEAD: Iraq is beginning to take severe measures to stretch food supplies. They include issuing coupons and setting up food distribution centers in preparation for the imposition of rationing today and encouraging urban dwellers to join their relatives in the countryside.

LEAD: Elizabeth Schub, the daughter of Stephanie Rose of New York and Michael A. Schub of Garrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Peter DeCarlo, a son of Sandra Bratti and Libero DeCarlo, both of Toronto. Judge Richard M. Palmer of Family Court in Brooklyn performed the ceremony at the Anthology Film Archives in New York.

LEAD: President Bush's son Neil has asked an administrative law judge to dismiss the Government's case against him, which charges him with conflict of interest as a director of a failed savings and loan, according to documents made available today.
LEAD: Levels of carbon monoxide sometimes experienced by urban dwellers can induce potentially fatal disturbances of heart rhythms in cardiac patients during exercise, a new study has shown.
LEAD: Wholesale gasoline prices jumped again yesterday, but crude oil prices rose more modestly. Demand for gasoline remains strong, because of shortages of refinery capacity, traders said.

LEAD: ''They're all in hiding because they know what the Iraqis are going to do to them. They're going to round them up in their houses. They knock on the door at midnight and take people away. We never hear from them again and they are interned.'' - Barbara Badine of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, referring to Americans there.

LEAD: William C. Schraft Jr., a pathologist and president of the Westchester County Board of Health, died on Thursday while vacationing with his family in Stonington, Conn. He was 69 years old and lived in New Rochelle.
LEAD: An Army paratrooper was acquitted today of charges that he murdered an unarmed Panamanian man at a roadblock during the United States invasion of Panama last year.

LEAD: Norway may be able to maintain its current annual oil output for another 40 years, double previous estimates, the state-funded Petroleum Directorate said today. A directorate spokesman, Jan Hagland, disclosed the new projections but declined to give further details.
LEAD: Willie McGee, with a .335 average set in statistical stone, could win the National League batting title while finishing the season with the Oakland Athletics.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An entry in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Thursday misidentified the new position of Samuel A. Schulhof at the General Electric Research and Development Center. He is director of the center's new environmental research unit, not of the center itself.

LEAD: Normally the introduction of a new chardonnay by a Napa Valley winery causes no great interest here, especially at harvest time when winemakers are working seven days a week and keeping a wary eye on the weather. But prices of Treasury bills and short-term notes continued to rise on hopes that the Federal Reserve would have to lower interest rates soon to stimulate the economy.
LEAD: After weeks of intense political maneuvering, representatives of the two Germanys signed a treaty of almost 1,000 pages today detailing the mechanics of reunification, now only 33 days away.

LEAD: The Most Rev. Lawrence J. Kenney, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese for the Military Services, died Thursday at the residence of John Cardinal O'Connor in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Washington.
LEAD: The broad, sweeping boulevards of Kuwait's capital were all but deserted today except for clusters of Iraqi troops.

LEAD: The New York Chamber Symphony will open its season at the 92d Street Y with a program on Oct. 6 and 9 at 8 P.M. and Oct. 7 at 3 P.M. Gerard Schwarz will conduct David Diamond's ''Music for Romeo and Juliet,'' Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, and the original 1924 arrangement of Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' with Misha Dichter as the piano soloist.

LEAD: Although Iraq is closer to the Soviet border than New York is to Boston, the gulf crisis that has fixated the rest of the world seems almost peripheral to residents of this capital of competing crises.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled on Thursday that Trans World Airlines could prohibit broker sales and other transfers of ''frequent flier'' discount coupons. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit at least temporarily set back T.W.A.'s attempt to enforce the ban through an injunction and lawsuit seeking damages against a company that buys unused coupons and sells them at cut rates.

LEAD: Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, suffered a severe cut above his right eye when he and a sparring partner hit heads yesterday during a workout at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. Forty-eight stitches were required to close the cut. Because of his injury, Tyson's bout against Alex Stewart, which had been scheduled for Sept.

LEAD: Laurence A. Tisch and members of his family have acquired sizable stakes in three bank holding companies whose stocks have fallen on hard times recently: Continental Bank, Baybanks and Equimark.
LEAD: At a shady hilltop complex overlooking Lake Managua, Francisco Franco Espinoza went for a walk this week.

LEAD: One month after Iraq overran Kuwait, American companies are struggling to maintain increasingly tenuous communications links with employees trapped in the two countries and are reluctant to say much about their efforts for fear of endangering those workers.

LEAD: Barely two weeks after the Dinkins administration began requiring a police escort for Emergency Medical Service workers entering the Rikers Island jail, the city and the workers' union agreed yesterday to end the plan.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A man convicted of five murders was put to death by injection early today for killing an elderly woman 11 years ago.

LEAD: New Federal rules go into effect today that reduce the maximum time banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions can hold most deposited checks before crediting them to your account. Local checks cannot be held now for more than two business days, and nonlocal checks for more than five business days.
LEAD: Scientists said yesterday that they had found no convincing evidence that the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania in 1979 had caused a rise in cancer rates.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: It may not actually be the last weekend of summer, but for the vast majority of people Labor Day means the end of the season.

LEAD: The Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government today gave its qualified endorsement to a new United Nations peace plan under which it would share power with the three guerrilla groups it has been fighting for 11 years.

LEAD: Pearl Sacerdote, an artist whose works in oils, acrylics, collage and mixed media were exhibited widely in the last two decades, died Wednesday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. She was 68 years old, and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and in East Hampton, L.I. Her family said she died of an immune-system disorder.

LEAD: Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, suffered a severe cut above his right eye yesterday when he and a sparring partner, Greg Page, struck heads in a workout at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. Tyson was taken directly to the Margate, N.J., office of Dr. Ira Trocki, who used 48 stitches to close the cut.
LEAD: The leader of a religious cult has been convicted of killing a family of five last year and burying them on a farm where his group lived.

LEAD: International 2-6 Israel will get $1 billion in weapons from Washington to buttress its defenses against Iraq and to offset arms sales to Saudi Arabi. LEAD: Saying that oil supplies remained nearly in balance with demand despite the embargo against Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, the International Energy Agency, which represents 21 industrial nations, decided today not to recommend that members begin drawing down emergency reserves.

LEAD: Could a city that enjoyed its greatest economic boom since World War II, experienced a dizzying rise in housing prices, attracted the largest wave of immigration since the days of Ellis Island and seemed to grow more crowded in every conceivable way actually be smaller now than it was in 1980?

LEAD: Dr. Lot B. Page, a physician associated with the National Institute on Aging who also served as chief of medicine at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Manchester, N.H., died on Wednesday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: After standing unused and mothballed for nearly three years on a desolate bluff over the central coast of California, the Gaviota Oil and Gas Plant here is emerging as a key element in the American response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

LEAD: Herbert A. Waggener, a researcher at Lepton Inc. in Murray Hill, N.J., has patented a new kind of mask that makes it easier to produce computer chips through the still-experimental process of X-ray lithography.
LEAD: Yesterday was a bad day for Andre Agassi, the men's fourth-seeded player, and he didn't even play.
LEAD: Gov. William A. O'Neill today ordered state agencies to cut spending by 5 percent to help offset a $379.4 million deficit that has accumulated in the budget year that began just two months ago.

LEAD: In another in a string of recent cases involving abuses in the stock market, the Ministry of Finance today ordered suspensions for four securities firms, including a unit of Citicorp, for aiding a speculator's manipulation of a stock last April.
LEAD: There is only a month or so left, but there is no race for the Yankees in Fenway Park. Not this summer.
LEAD: Stock trading slowed yesterday to the lowest point of the year, and the Dow Jones industrial average chalked up a modest advance, ending with its first weekly gain since mid-July.

LEAD: The spiraling violence in black townships around Johannesburg is a grievous setback to hopes for a peaceful transition to democratic rule in South Africa. More than 500 people have already been killed in battles between supporters of Nelson Mandela and the African National Congress and the Inkatha movement of Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi.

LEAD: Pacificorp, the utility based in Portland, Ore., that last year bid $2.08 billion to acquire the Arizona Public Service Company, agreed today to several long-term transactions with the Arizona utility worth a total of $222 million.
LEAD: The previously announced merger between Genentech Inc. and Roche Holding Ltd. is on track to be completed by the end of next week, the companies said today.
LEAD: The Paris Theater, one of America's most venerable theaters for French and other foreign films, went out of existence yesterday after nearly 42 years at 58th Street near Fifth Avenue.

LEAD: Families who have disabled or impaired children need to take particular care in estate planning. Generally, this means putting assets in trust for those who cannot handle their own financial affairs, but coming to grips with the matter within the family, setting up the trust and choosing the right trustee can be nettlesome.
LEAD: A couple of minor trades had left the dugout shaken up. One major comeback left it nearly torn apart.

LEAD: Edmund G. Love, a writer whose book ''Subways Are for Sleeping'' was the basis for the Broadway musical of the same name, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Flint, Mich. He was 78 years old.
LEAD: An article in Weekend on Friday about Bargemusic Ltd. referred incorrectly to a flutist who appears there. He is Ransom Wilson.

LEAD: He spent 10 superb seasons with the Chicago Blackhawks, and when they traded him two months ago, Denis Savard looked forward to several more good ones with his next organization, the Montreal Canadiens. Yesterday, veteran player and new team took a step in that direction by agreeing on a three-year contract.
LEAD: The first time Linda Ferrando stood across the court from Monica Seles, in practice earlier this year in Chicago, she made so little impression that Seles failed to remember it ever happened.

LEAD: The New York Civil Liberties Union and the Legal Aid Society sent a letter yesterday to the Correction Commissioner, Allyn R. Sielaff, imploring him to stop ''unfair disciplinary proceedings'' against inmates stemming from the Aug. 14 disturbance at Rikers Island.
LEAD: The commander of American forces in Saudi Arabia said today that there would be no fighting here unless Iraq launched an attack.

LEAD: The Iraqi Government put new conditions today on the departure of others in a group of 237 foreign women and children, including 14 Americans, that Iraq has said would be allowed to leave the country.

LEAD: A chart in Business Day yesterday headed ''Filling the Void'' misstated the amount of oil that may be drawn by India and Malaysia from reserves to help offset world oil shortages. It is 600,000 barrels a day, not 400,000.

LEAD: TRACK AND FIELD> Britain Wins 8th Gold: Colin Jackson needed a strong finish to win the 110-meter high hurdles in 13.18 seconds, giving Britain its eighth gold medal at the European championships yesterday in Split, Yugoslavia. (AP) VOLLEYBALL> United States Falls: China trounced the United States, 15-7, 15-8, 15-7, in just one hour and the Soviet Union beat Cuba, 17-15, 15-7, 15-8 yesterday in the semifinals of the women's world championship in Beijing.

LEAD: The Federated and Allied department store chains said they intended to negotiate claims filed by the Internal Revenue Service for payment of more than $500 million in additional taxes. Federated Stores Inc., the retailers' parent company, said the claims were based on an I.R.S. audit of the company for 1984 to 1988.

LEAD: Even for these post-Cold War days, it was an unlikely scene. Former Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the ideological enemy of the Reagan years, comfortably ensconced in an Upper East Side mansion, seated in an armchair upholstered in golden silk, talking to American corporate officers about a six-figure deal.

LEAD: The rains of August had been taking their toll on ''Richard III,'' the New York Shakespeare Festival's production in Central Park, canceling or halting performances and making forecasts the topic of moment.

LEAD: In what Federal researchers called a strong indication that the nation's cocaine epidemic may have peaked, Government figures released today show that cocaine-related visits to hospital emergency rooms dropped 4 percent in the first quarter of the year.
LEAD: The folks who run the World Trade Center stole my friend Jon's bicycle. They smashed the lock, then demanded $30 to give the bike back.
LEAD: Glenn Wilson's single capped a three-run, two-out rally in the ninth inning tonight as the Houston Astros defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2.

LEAD: ''I'm what you call a displaced homemaker,'' said Doris Gibson, who is 66 years old and by any measure poor. She traces her poverty to the day 13 years ago when her husband walked out on her, and her survival to a Federal paycheck that will be harder and harder for future Doris Gibsons to get.
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company sued a former top movie executive on Thursday and accused him of trying to lure away other Disney employees and projects after the company released him from a contract.

LEAD: The work to remove the barricades set up by Mohawk Indians across the Mercier Bridge resumed today, after being halted on Thursday in the seven-week-old standoff between the Canadian Government and Mohawk Indians.

LEAD: Todd Martin sat in the players' lounge at the United States Open the other day, soaking up the glitz and glamour of a world in which he finished his debut about 45 minutes earlier. The 1990 Big Ten tennis player of the year had played the first match of his professional career and lost in straight sets, 7-6, 6-3, 7-6, to Jean-Philippe

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission is proposing rules aimed at eliminating overcharges and other abuses by companies that connect callers at hotels, motels, hospitals and similar public places to long-distance carriers. Some consumer advocates say the rules do not go far enough.

LEAD: The United States Transportation Department selected the United Parcel Service Company to operate a new all-cargo route to Japan. A U.P.S. spokesman, Ken Sternad, said the company had not yet placed a value on the route but said the award was ''significant.'' Emery Worldwide Airlines was awarded backup authority.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that his country would need a six-month stabilization period to control inflation and resolve emergency consumer shortages before embarking on the transition to a market economy.
LEAD: Space agency officials said today that the launching of the space shuttle Columbia might be delayed up to a week so that a failed electrical device on the payload can be fixed.

LEAD: In the baking heat of eastern Saudi Arabia, Marine tank emplacements dot the desert sand. Four-man crews sit under camouflage nets with their M-60 tanks, which lie dug into the earth to make them less visible against the horizon.

LEAD: Faced with an angry outcry over tax increases, Gov. Jim Florio today appointed a new chief of staff and in doing so signaled a turn both toward more openness and a closer coordination of politics and government.
LEAD: The Labor Department is establishing a test program in the meatpacking industry to protect workers from painful and crippling injuries caused by repetitive motions.

LEAD: A growing armed resistance to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, managed from an air base in the Saudi Arabian desert, has won American encouragement and advice, United States officials said this week. But the officials insisted that neither the Central Intelligence Agency nor the American military is directly supporting the movement.

LEAD: James H. Donovan, a longtime State Senator who played an important role in shaping state policy on education and transportation during the last 25 years, died today at his home in Chadwicks, near Utica. He was 66 years old.

LEAD: Two inventors in Southern California obtained a patent this week on a flip top for aluminum cans that they said is resealable and can be opened without damaging fingernails.

LEAD: Busy smokestacks reach above the sprawling squat buildings of red brick and not-yet-rusty metal on Rikers Island, testament to a decade of frantic building that has more than doubled the size of the nation's largest penal colony. Except for street names like E-1 and the endless loops of razor wire lining every fence, some blocks look from the outside like any industrial swath of Queens.

LEAD: The worldwide burden-sharing program for the Persian Gulf operation will require tens of billions of dollars in financial aid to third-world countries, repayment for trade lost in the embargo against Iraq, donations of fuel to American military forces and other contributions, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: The Rev. Dr. Wellman Joel Warner, a retired social psychologist and an educator, died on Thursday at Griffin Hospital in Derby, Conn. He was 93 years old and lived in Shelton, Conn.
LEAD: The carefully planned brilliance of Todd Marinovich is no surprise anymore. The varied gifts and surprising calm of Marvin Graves were kept on a practice field in Syracuse before tonight.

LEAD: The Edmonton Oilers goaltender Grant Fuhr used cocaine for about seven years, but says he has been drug free since spending two weeks in a substance-abuse center last summer, according to a published report.

LEAD: THOUGH foggy as a steamed-up bathroom mirror, the early 1990 census figures released last week offered the country its first look at itself as it emerged from the 1980's: the sagging cities, spreading suburbs, and the southern coasts and the Southwestern states bulging with economic and political muscle.

LEAD: Somewhere in the air over Grand Central Terminal - floating like an invisible, enormous, amorphous and very valuable mass - are somewhere between 1.6 million and 1.9 million square feet of unused development rights. LEAD: WITH the prices of cooperatives and condominiums down by 13 percent from 1988 and sales of single-family homes sluggish, the conversion of existing rental apartments to co-ops has virtually stopped in the county, landlords and real-estate brokers report.

LEAD: ''Shareware'' has become increasingly popular with businesses, government agencies and educational institutions. Shareware is commercial software that differs from the more conventional programs primarily in the way it is distributed and priced. The underlying philosophies of shareware are that good software need not be expensive and that users should be able to try software before buying it.

LEAD: A picture caption on page 6 of the Arts and Leisure section today about a Balinese dancer misstates the performance date for a troupe of Balinese children at Montclair (N.J.) State College. It is Friday, Sept. 14, not this Friday.

LEAD: Q. My house has a brick chimney that runs up the outside, with an ash pit at the basement level. The chimney has two flues, one for the furnace and one for the fireplace. Last winter, after several rainy and snowy days, some water ran down the inside of the flues and into the fireplace and ash pit.

LEAD: ''You never knew what was going to happen next. One time you thought you'd be attacked, the next time you thought you'd be here for six months. It was up and down, up and down. LEAD: Police divers searched today for at least 20 passengers reported missing after a bus slid off a highway bridge into a river, a South Korean news agency, Yonhap, reported. LEAD: Celeste Piano Wenzel sounds like a very nice person (''Birthdays Remind Me of What I Miss,'' Aug. 19), but 40 is much too early an age to be contemplating what she'll miss when gone. When she does attain old age, she might more gainfully consider what she won't miss: man's continuing inhumanity to man, sickness, accidents and natural disasters, to name only a few of many calamities in the modern world.
LEAD: Canadian Army troops moved in to dismantle barricades today in an Indian community outside Montreal, seeking to end a seven-week standoff between armed Mohawk Indians and Canadian authorities.

LEAD: The Labor Day weekend signals the onset of a new season. What better time to muse idly about a few of our leading classical-music institutions and artists? LEAD: Tax on Home Sale Question: I am nearing 55 and would like to sell my house and move into a rental unit. On the other side is the American family, searching for quality child care at a reasonable price.

LEAD: THE veteran Israeli politician Abba Eban is widely credited with coining an aphorism about Palestinian diplomacy that has stuck for many years: The Palestinians never miss an opportunity to miss an opportunity. Now some Israelis might modify that: The Palestinians never give up a chance to hurt their chances.

LEAD: Q. My house has a brick chimney that runs up the outside, with an ash pit at the basement level. The chimney has two flues, one for the furnace and one for the fireplace. Last winter, after several rainy and snowy days, some water ran down the inside of the flues and into the fireplace and ash pit.

''Discover the real India,'' the advertisements read. ''Unlimited air mileage for two weeks, just $99 per person!'' It sounded too good to be true.

LEAD: MONDAY: Labor Day. Financial markets, government offices and many businesses are closed. TUESDAY: Construction spending for July. Purchasing managers index for August. Second-quarter productivity. The scheduled trial on charges of bank fraud for Edwin T. McBirney 3d, former chairman of the Sunbelt Savings Association.

LEAD: The talks never moved much beyond the exploratory stage, but Tom Seaver said his brush with the vacancy in the Yankee front office last month left him both intrigued and interested. If another team calls, he will listen.

LEAD: To the Editor: I recently returned from a visit to Mexico that included a round trip by train between Mexico City and San Miguel de Allende. The fare charged by the tour operator was $40 a person. The Mexican tickets listed the price as 33,300 pesos. At the rate of exchange at the time - 2,660 pesos to $1 - the actual price was $12.52; the markup was more than 200 percent.

LEAD: As an English teacher and sometime acronym enthusiast, I agree with Jack Rosenthal that ''the most obvious reason to coin an acronym is mnemonic, to make a term easy to remember.'' My students and I decided last year that our favorite acronym is IACOCCA. Lee Iacocca should have no trouble remembering his position, because he can say with certainty, ''I Am Chairman of Chrysler Corporation of America.

LEAD: Two Jesuit priests said they were pinned down here for two hours and nearly killed by an army sniper in what church officials are denouncing as the most recent in a series of attacks on rural civilians.

LEAD: In the weeks, months and, finally, years after Michael Stewart died following his arrest by the transit police, the New York City Medical Examiner waffled on the question of whether foul play was involved and the police insisted that they had done no wrong. But the fact remained that after Mr. Stewart was arrested in 1983 for writing subway graffiti, he was delivered hogtied and bruised to Bellevue Hospital, where he died 13 days later.

LEAD: More than 700 foreign women and children who had been detained in Iraq as human shields against an American military attack headed for home in the United States, Europe and Asia early today after being released by the Iraqi Government.

LEAD: As senators and various interest groups explore the views of David H. Souter, President Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court, many have turned their attention to his actions as New Hampshire Attorney General from 1976 to 1978.

LEAD: MIXED salads, vegetable tarts and pizzas can be so good at this time of year that the absence of meat or fish in a meal goes unnoticed. I like to mix the best of the produce from the local farmer's stand to make a vegetable antipasto that would give any good Italian restaurant a run for its money.

LEAD: The United States Postal Service will participate in two joint issues this fall, the first with two former trust territories (Micronesia and the Marshall Islands), the second with a former enemy (the Soviet Union).

LEAD: At first the pairing of exhibitions at the Museum of Contemporary Art here comes across as an astute institutional balancing act inspired by these issue-sensitive, multicultural times. However fortuitous, the scheduling implies a rationale: if you're going to exhibit the drawings of Julian Schnabel, that enfant terrible of the early 1980's and epitome of white male artistic success, equal time should go to work from a completely different part of the art realm.

LEAD: THE borders of the Arab countries of the Middle East were drawn largely by Britain and France after World War I when the League of Nations allowed them to carve up the Ottoman domains there. In Syria and Lebanon, France tried to establish republics; in Jordan and Iraq, Britain set up monarchies and installed members of the family that had led the Arab revolt against Turkey; in Egypt, central Arabia and Kuwait, London backed other traditional rulers with whom it had long friendships.

LEAD: To the Editor: On July 29 you ran an interesting article on the Galicia region of Spain and the edible barnacles called percebes. But the caption about a ''Basque fisherman selling the shellfish'' must have been a guess. Maybe a fisherman; probably a merchant. The Gallegos are not Basques, who live hundreds of miles to the east.
